DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF MR WILLIAM PAUL O'CONNOR

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate of the death on 18 September 1987 of Mr William Paul O'Connor, a former member of the House of Representatives for the divisions of West Sydney from 1946 to 1949, Martin from 1949 to 1955 and Dalley from 1955 to 1969.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Card and Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
that we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card.

that this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security;

that we are deeply concerned at the Labor Government's inability to provide effective and efficient methods to combat tax and social security fraud without resorting to expensive, ineffective and authoritarian measures which are alien to the Australian way of life;
that we call upon the Labor Government to improve management systems within the Australian Tax Office and other Departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bishop (from 778 citizens), Reid (from 50 citizens), MacGibbon (from 49 citizens) and Watson (from 29 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 Oct 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government. The Commonwealth has reneged on an established commitment as incorporated in Commonwealth legislation and benefit promise pensions are not being paid in full. In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. We consider this Government-induced penalty to be out of all proportion to the short-term `extraordinary circumstances of the economy' given as the reason for the discounting.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to:

1. limit the pension discounting effect of the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to the period 10 Oct 1986 to 1 July 1987 so that pensions are restored to the 9 Oct 1986 level as a base for the 1987 pension adjustment; and
2. consult with organisations representing pensioners before changing the terms and conditions of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Schemes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Alston (from 17 citizens), Boswell (from 15 citizens) and Short (from 43 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Smoke Free Air Travel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,
(i) are greatly disturbed by the dangers to health posed by passive smoking, and evidence of which is being documented daily by medical authorities around the world;

(ii) note that environmental tobacco smoke has been identified as the major pollutant in aeroplane cabins, and that its direct threat to health is recognised in the special leave provisions for flight attendants specifically on grounds of upper respiratory infections;

(iii) appreciate the government's undertaking to legislate for smoke-free travel on aeroplanes, but are dismayed at the apparent reluctance to follow up the Minister for Aviation's December announcement with action; and

(iv) call upon the government to make smoke-free aeroplane travel a reality without further delay, and to ensure that smoke-free areas which cannot be contaminated by recycled pollutants, are available at all aerodromes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Childs (from 52 citizens) and Reid (from 500 citizens).

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Moreton Island is an invaluable natural resource for Queensland and the world and that mining on Moreton would gravely compromise its unique flora and fauna and its outstanding recreational archaeological and scientific values.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
urge the government to use its proven constitutional powers to halt sand mining on Moreton by supporting the Moreton Island Preservation Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

millions of dollars of taxpayers money is spent at each Federal election in Australia in the drafting, production and distribution of How-to-Vote cards which are unnecessary and pollutant and that this waste is not desirable or essential in assisting the electorate to vote informatively for their parliamentarians.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned, would like to voice our protest at the proposed legislation for the Australia Card. This petition of Australian citizens shows:
1. We reject in principle the need for a national I.D. card on the basis that it will be a gross violation of civil liberties and personal freedoms.

2. We support proper measures by government to stamp out tax avoidance. We equally believe that the introduction of a national system of identification and sensitive data storage, is a massive intrusion into the privacy of those least likely to be involved in tax avoidance practices, and equally less likely to be effective against those who are.

3. We reject the notion that the government, on the basis of it's recent re-election, can claim a mandate for the proposed legislation. The Australia Card was not a debated pre-election policy issue and we categorically state that it does not reflect our will.
We therefore request that you vote to reject this legislation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate should:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) congratulates the United States and the Soviet Union on their historic agreement to eliminate short range and intermediate range land-based nuclear missiles and trusts that further negotiations will be successful and achieve mutual balanced and verifiable reductions in strategic nuclear weapons of the order of 50 per cent in the immediate future; and

(b) notes that this historic reduction is a positive outcome of the policy of deterrence practised by the Western democracies whereby some parity was maintained between the nuclear arsenals of the West and Soviets, thereby allowing mutual and balanced force reductions to take place safely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes with optimism the pending arms agreement on intermediate and short range missiles in Europe, which should be seen as a first step in the right direction;

(b) commends the governments of the United States and the Soviet Union for reaching a disarmament agreement as opposed to an arms control agreement, and the millions of ordinary people around the world who have worked so long to bring pressure on the nuclear powers for such an agreement;

(c) notes, too, that the number of long-range weapons deployed by the United States and the Soviet Union since the Reagan Administration came to office exceeds the number of medium-range weapons that would be eliminated, and that this agreement only covers about 6 per cent of the world's nuclear arsenals; and

(d) urges the Australian government to initiate arms control, security and disarmament talks in the North Pacific involving both the nuclear super-powers and other regional powers, as well as continuing its efforts to achieve a Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Special Minister of State in her capacity as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women and as Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health. I refer the Minister to the comments of her colleague Senator Walsh to the Labor lawyers in Perth yesterday. When speaking of the best way to provide child care services he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The sort of money that's going to be required to make this service, at its present cost even, universal, will not be available.

I interpolate that the estimate of a total service at the time when I was Minister-which is a long time ago now-was $4 billion capital and $4 billion a year recurrent. So I respectfully agree with the statement of the Minister for Finance. He went on to say:

The money could be found through a means-tested voucher system which would then of course, remove child care from the public sector and send it back to the private sector from whence, I believe, it should never have been enticed away.
Does the Minister, and does the Government, agree with Senator Walsh about changing child care funding in the way that he has described?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind Senator Chaney that our Government has an outstanding record in providing additional child care places through subsidised, needs based community child care centres. In 1984 we undertook to provide an additional 20,000 child care places, a commitment that we will meet next year. Next year, for example, we will be funding 106,000 places, compared with just 46,000 places when we came to office, and our commitment is being honoured in the most cost effective and equitable manner. Indeed, recent changes in the mix of child care places, with greater emphasis on family day care, and in the arrangements for providing fee relief, have both been intended to improve cost efficiency and equity. As the Prime Minister spelt out in the election campaign, Labor will continue to support adequate provision of child care facilities.

ANSWER.PARA: There are private operators in the child care area. They do not operate on a needs basis. They are not therefore suitable to be a part of our program of providing child care on the basis of needs. I should add: the Government has no voucher system or similar proposal under consideration in the child care area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The Minister seems to have given us a prepared answer rather than addressing her mind to the point which I raised. I asked the Minister: does she agree with the central proposition of Senator Walsh that a minority of needy parents and children receive any assistance at all in the present limited system? Is the Government prepared to consider more effective ways of directing assistance to the genuinely needy in this community rather than simply persisting with the present arrangements?

—Senator Chaney's supplementary question contained a contradiction. He suggested that our mode of assisting parents who use child care is not needs based. It is needs based. We are constantly monitoring the program to ensure that new services are targeted to areas of need and that the subsidy arrangement, which is on a sliding scale, as Senator Chaney will be aware, does provide the most assistance to parents in need. The statistics which I gave the first time I answered Senator Chaney's question demonstrate that there has been a massive increase in the number of services available and the number of places available. The vast majority of those services and places serve low income parents. Where parents who are on middle or higher incomes have access to places they pay a much higher cost, of course; they receive very little subsidy at all. They pay almost the full cost of the child care place. So, by a combination of where the new services are put, the formula for charging the parents who use the services and the generous subsidies available to low income parents, we are expanding the number of child care places according to principles of need and efficiency.

—Is the Minister for the Environment and the Arts aware of a recent advertisement in a Queensland regional newspaper promoting a public meeting against the proposed World Heritage listing of north Queensland rainforests? Is the Minister also aware that the meeting is to be addressed by a Mr Charles Pinwell, who is described in the advertisement as an associate of Mr Jeremy Lee of the Australian League of Rights? Does the League of Rights have any acknowledged expertise on the preservation of tropical rainforests or the economics of the logging industry? I ask the Minister: If not, why has the League of Rights called this meeting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Aulich for his question. I am not aware that the League of Rights has any special expertise in the preservation of our rainforests and the wet tropics. I am aware that its main role has been to ferment radical hatred in this country over a number of years. It has a history of anti-semitism unrivalled in Australia by any other group. Recently it has been raising antagonism towards Asians and Aboriginals. It now appears that anyone who wants to protect the rainforests will also appear on its list. The League does not merely prejudice against those races; it actively seeks to promote enmity against them. It operates under many different guises. It bobs up in many different places. It has covered such diverse issues recently as apartheid in South Africa and the fluoridation of drinking water. It has recently opposed Asian immigration.

ANSWER.PARA: What the League of Rights has to offer the townspeople in Ravenshoe, Ingham or any of those places affected by World Heritage listing I do not know. I do know, however, that the League does not have the interests of those people at heart. In fact, it does not have the interests of anyone at heart, bar those who share its members' bitterness and hatred towards anything that does not look, sound or act like them. Fortunately, more and more people in Australia do not sound, look, or act like them. More and more they are seen as being on the fringe. I think everyone in the Parliament would like to see them stay there. We have had enough people stirring up trouble in those areas in recent times. We have already had incidents we would all like to forget. TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Special Minister of State and Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Do the Minister and the Government share the view of the Minister for Finance expressed in his reported remarks to Labor lawyers in Perth that `middle class trendies' are the main recipients of tertiary education and that this provides a good argument for the reintroduction of tertiary fees?

—My good friend and colleague Senator Walsh was certainly enjoying himself on Saturday, off the leash. However, regardless of any reports in the newspapers, I would like to assure the Senate that Government policy recognises the general prohibition against tertiary fees as set out in the Australian Labor Party platform. There are no plans to change that platform.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the results of the July Federal election. The Minister will be aware that four House of Representatives seats in Queensland were won by Labor from the conservative parties and that Labor now holds a majority of Federal electoral divisions in that State. What economic factors and Government policies contributed to the electoral landslide to Labor in Queensland?

—I take a point of order, Mr President. There is a little used standing order which suggests that questions shall not ask for an opinion. I suggest that no question could more flagrantly breach that standing order than the question that has just been asked. Any election result can be attributed to any combination of factors. This is reducing Question Time to a farce.
—I will allow the question but I ask the Minister, in answering the question, to deal with only those areas that are directly related to his portfolio.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly, Mr President. The results of the election in Queensland were a stinging rebuff to the Bjelke-Petersen machine, and I think equally there can be no doubt that a major factor in that stinging rebuff, in the swings against the National Party of Australia of 2.8 per cent in the electorate of Fisher, 2 per cent in Petrie and 1.3 per cent in Hinkler-two of those seats having been lost by the National Party-and in the 2.9 per cent Statewide fall in its primary vote was the electorate's rejection of the economic policies put forward by the Queensland branch of the National Party. The optimistic interpretation of that result is that the electorate will not tolerate fiscal irresponsibility and that no party can any longer make promises of enormous tax cuts unless it spells out in detail a credible package of expenditure cuts to pay for them. That was precisely what the National Party in Queensland did not do.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Stone might tell me that in fact the expenditure cuts were spelt out. For the first year they were spelt out in some detail, but in a way that would still have left a Budget deficit of more than $1 billion after the same level of assets sales that the Government had in mind and after the additional revenue which is now expected from the tax base broadening measures had been counted-additional revenue which of course both conservative parties were pledged to renouncing because they were going to repeal the legislation which gave rise to the revenue.

The final point I make is that there needs to be a correction of over $2 billion between the Budget deficit which this Government finally brought down and that which would have been brought down by the National Party in Queensland had its policy been accepted. Beyond that its expenditure cuts covered the first year only. The entire National Party tax program, after the full effect of the company tax reduction was taken into account, on its own figures was in excess of $20 billion, to which, as I said earlier, needs to be added the additional revenue loss from the tax base broadening measures which the National Party was pledged to repealing. So, of a total of well over $21 billion, the National Party spelt out $4.6 billion of more or less specific taxation cuts. Although the electorate might not have been aware of all of those details-indeed it could not have been aware of them at the time-I think the lesson is pretty clear that the electorate knew it was a shonky package which would not be delivered.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: JAPANESE OWNERSHIP OF PROPERTY IN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Finance comment on an article in the Weekend Australian of 19-20 September by Rod Reader which states that many Japanese property buyers are failing to report their purchases to the Foreign Investment Review Board and further that many sales are being organised through Japanese shelf companies to circumvent the FIRB ruling that purchases of over $600,000 must be reported? Is there an Australian register of foreign ownership? If so, can the Minister indicate the extent of Japanese ownership of property and holdings in Australia? If not, does the Government intend to establish such a register?

—I did not see that article in the Weekend Australian and I do not have any information about the matter either, so I will refer that part of the question to the Treasurer. Regarding the second part of the question, to the best of my knowledge there is no Australian register of foreign ownership as such, but some aggregated information is made available to the public each year through the Foreign Investment Review Board's annual report. There is also some level of property purchase-I am not sure what it is for a residential building-below which there is no requirement to notify the Foreign Investment Review Board. As to whether the Government intends to establish such a register, I will refer that to the Treasurer. However, I think it is something that it would be very difficult for the Federal Government to do without the co-operation of the State governments, which, of course, have the records of land titles.

—I ask the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade a question concerning two recent referenda in Palau that sought to amend Palau's nuclear free provisions in its Constitution. Is it not true that, although the United Nations observers were present, United Nations criteria were not followed? Given that on 15 September in another place the Australian Foreign Minister criticised France's conduct of its referendum in New Caledonia, is the Australian Government being inconsistent in failing to criticise the referenda in Palau? Are we treating American designs in Palau more favourably than French designs in New Caledonia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first part of Senator Wood's question, there are no formal United Nations criteria for decolonising acts of self-determination, although there are principles ascertainable from past practice which, for example, the Forum countries have sought to identify in the context of New Caledonia. One centrally important United Nations practice is the attendance of United Nations observer missions. There was no such observer mission for the recent referendum in New Caledonia as the French Government had specifically ruled that out. However, there was, as Senator Wood acknowledged in his question, a United Nations observer mission in attendance in Palau for the 21 August referendum.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the nature of that exercise, the Australian Government considers that the compact of free association between Palau and the United States has been negotiated and approved in a manner consistent with the rights of the Palau people to self-determination. It follows, therefore, that the answer to the last two of Senator Wood's questions is clearly no. It is clear that in Palau and New Caledonia the United States and France are pursuing quite different courses and objectives and the two situations are simply not comparable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: as this tormented island is part of a United Nations strategic trust territory, should the Australian Government seek exposure of this issue in the Security Council?
—For the reasons that I have just indicated, no.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Lest we forget the importance of last weekend's Labor lawyers conference, I refer to the Minister's widely reported comments that the Government lacks the political courage to bite into around 200 indulgent social welfare programs. In view of the Minister's assertion on AM this morning that the reference to the PAW-Peter Alexander Walsh-top 200 list arose out of comments made at the 1986 Australian Labor Party National Conference and that since that time the Government has cut more than $3 billion from recurrent expenditure, does the Minister suggest that the top 200 list, or even the 13 engines of growth identified in his August speech, are now inoperative? If not, will the Minister in due course table a costed and itemised list of the various middle class welfare rorts and ramps which this Government lacks the political courage to eliminate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must agree with John Howard about one thing. He is reported as saying at the weekend conference of the Western Australian Liberal Party that the Liberal Party is slow to learn. He is dead right about that because the first question put to me in the Senate was based on the 200 programs, which, incidentally, I acknowledge was reported accurately by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation this morning as a retelling of an anecdote from the 1986 Federal Conference, and has already been blown out of the water. Also I understand that the Liberal Party is raising a matter of public importance in the House of Representatives on that same matter.

ANSWER.PARA: Since that comment was made in 1986 we have had two Budgets from which we have cut more than $3 billion in recurrent expenditure, plus asset sales, plus an extra $1 billion from the States, and collected about an extra $2 billion in revenue from the base-broadening taxation measures which were part of the Government's tax reform package and which the Opposition was, and I presume still is, committed to repealing. In other words, if none of those adjustments had been made and other things had remained equal, we would be looking at a Budget deficit this year of over $7 billion. We have made the cuts in the Budget, we have made the adjustments-more than $3 billion in recurrent programs-plus a billion from the States, plus a billion in assets sales. That has been done. Our cutting record is on the table. Virtually all of it has been there for the last three months. Where is the Opposition's $2.5 billion of unspecified expenditures cuts? It is as big a mystery now as it was in June. Before that snivelling wimp who leads the Opposition has the audacity to criticise somebody else-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Walsh, will you withdraw?
—I withdraw. Do you mean `snivelling', `wimp' or both?
—On a point of order, Mr President, I suggest that if the Minister is contemptuous in his withdrawal, you should call him to order and he should be made to withdraw properly.
—I ask the Minister to withdraw those offensive words.

—I withdraw. All of our expenditure cuts-if one counts assets sales-the whole $5.5 billion or thereabouts, are on the table. We are still waiting to hear about the $2.5 billion which the Opposition talked about during the election campaign and has failed to specify. I would also remind Senator Alston of what I said in the Senate last week, and it is this. Important though the Budget outcome is-and for the record let it be noted that this Government has produced a balanced Budget in one year; Mr Howard said that he would produce a balanced Budget in three years, that is, if one believes the $2.5 billion-worth of nebulous expenditure cuts and the $1,800m-worth of phantom revenue from incentivation-if one believes that Mr Howard was to deliver a balanced Budget in three years, we have done it in one. As I said last week, important though the Budget outcome is, there are other factors which are arguably more important. Indeed the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and a number of other Ministers, including Senator Button, have said similar things at various times. There are other factors which are very important, foremost among which is that there needs to be further significant attitudinal and behavioural changes in the Australian economy and throughout Australian society. The greatest threat to those attitudinal and behavioural changes being recognised is opportunists like Mr Howard, who go out, as he did during the election campaign, and say, `I will deliver an economic nirvana via tax cuts. There is no need to make these behavioural and attitudinal adjustments. I can lift your living standards by giving you massive tax cuts'-cuts which the country cannot afford. The people did not believe it and that is a good tribute to their judgment; they did not believe it and nor should they have believed it.

—I ask the Minister a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his hectoring non-answer but my question was directed to ascertaining whether the 13 welfare areas which Senator Walsh a mere six weeks ago described as items which were likely to get very much out of hand unless contained are now inoperative, and whether he seriously claims that in view of the balancing trick in the recent Budget we are to take it that the whole of the 200 welfare items that he proudly boasted about have now all been achieved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 200 items, which by their nature are very rounded, was not a precise figure and was not intended to be taken as such, nor at any time was it restricted to welfare expenditures. That shows something about the mentality of that lot over there. Any suggestion of cutting government expenditure sets them twitching and jerking. They say, `We cannot take it out of anywhere else, it must come out of the welfare sector'. Senator Alston betrays his own prejudices by inserting a word which in fact was not there. Welfare programs were not specified either in the list of 13 programs which I put out six weeks ago or thereabouts or in some much less precise list to which I referred anecdotally at a later time. The argument is not restricted to welfare payments. However, that is the way in which the mind of the Liberal Party works. If government expenditure has to be cut its first preference is to take money away from the people who can afford it least. That is the way the Liberal Party's mind works, that is the way its philosophy operates.

ANSWER.PARA: If Senator Alston cared to read my speech-some of his colleagues are avid readers of my speeches but he apparently is not; I assume that someone else just wrote out that question and gave it to him-he would note that the 13 programs which I identified about six weeks ago were selected by the criteria of being programs on which a considerable amount of money is spent and in which there is a significant growth rate. I explicitly said that this does not mean that any or all of those programs necessarily have to be cut or their growth rate restrained. But it does mean, if neither of those things is to happen, that great care must be exercised in other areas of government expenditure; that is, of course-I did not say this in my speech, but I thought it would have been clear to most people who take a serious interest in these matters-unless the Government is willing to let recklessly the Budget deficit blow out, as John Howard did in his last Budget, or alternatively, which is even worse, to promise massive tax cuts which the country cannot afford, as John Howard did in the last election campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Transport and Communications. What is the Government's reaction to the allegations made by Mr Amann yesterday about the coastwatch contract and in particular to his assertion, reported in the Sydney Morning Herald, that Sir Peter Abeles had sought to influence the Government's decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the specific reference to Sir Peter Abeles, the situation is this: Sir Peter Abeles did not contact me or anyone else in the Government to say, as was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald, that `unless the Amann contract was cancelled he would withdraw from a number of Federal government projects'. More generally, there is no truth or substance whatever in any suggestion that might be made that Sir Peter Abeles or anyone acting on his behalf exerted pressure of any kind on the Government to cancel the Amann Aviation Pty Ltd contract. The allegation was described in the Sydney Morning Herald as `extraordinary'. Certainly it does no credit to Mr Amann or his company.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the other allegations that have been made by Mr Amann about the involvement of Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd and, indeed, the allegations that have been made in recent weeks and months by Skywest about Mr Amann and his company, the Government regards all the various allegations that have been made about each other's conduct by Amann and Skywest over the last little while as being essentially matters for the parties themselves to resolve by civil litigation if they so choose. Any information or allegation that either party might wish to lay before or make to the relevant law enforcement authorities will, of course, be dealt with by such authorities in the ordinary way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to the general matter of the Amann Aviation Pty Ltd contract. I refer him to a particular media report over the weekend that the Department of Aviation had warned the Government only 11 days after the coastwatch contract was awarded to Amann Aviation that this company was out of its depth. Are those media reports correct?

—That is an heroic feat of research on Senator Messner's part. Mr Roger Beale, in his report to me on what may or may not have gone wrong in the original administrative process, specifically referred to that very report from an aviation officer which was made a few days after the contract was awarded. I incorporated the full text of Mr Beale's report in Hansard last week. If Senator Messner has not got his act together sufficiently to appreciate that, manifestly he is not doing his job. There was a report. There was a minute signed by a senior aviation officer, who was the regional director in New South Wales. He sat down with Mr Amann and a number of others to work through all the details which were involved in the process of getting Australian registration and certification of airworthiness. That officer reached some conclusions about the great difficulty, as he perceived it, that Mr Amann, his chief pilot and his chief engineer were going to have. He reported as much to the Government. That report certainly created some continuing concern, but it was not concern that anyone could do anything about. The then Minister became aware at that time that there was that concern but, and I have said as much in my earlier comments on this matter--
—The incompetence was earlier rather than later.

—This was after the contract was awarded. It was several days-nearly two weeks-after the contract was awarded. The Minister became aware of that concern, but at that stage the contract had been awarded. There was no question of any contractual deadline not having been met. That question did not arise, as I have constantly said, until 12 September. Although the report certainly gave rise to some concern about the difficulties that would be experienced on the basis of the information at that stage-it certainly led the Government to realise that Mr Amann would have to find some aviation expertise fast if he was to meet his deadlines-there was nothing that the Government could do about it, except wait to see whether the particular contractual deadline was reached and to make various contingency plans, which we did, to ensure that there would be no breach of continuity in surveillance if the contract was not able to be met. That has been the situation-there has been no breach of continuity.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The Minister will recall that the other day, in the House of Representatives, the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support, Mr Duncan, mentioned the existence of a document which apparently made him aware of certain advice to the Government about the Amann contract. Is that the document about which we are talking?
—Senator Messner is in a profound and unhappy condition of confusion.
—It is permanent.

—It is permanent, as my colleague says. It has only just become evident to me how extensive is that condition of confusion. The document to which reference was made was the report of the Aviation regional director made a few days after the contract was awarded at the end of March. It related wholly and solely to questions of aviation expertise. The other documentation to which Mr Duncan was referring-he had not seen it and was not aware of the contract involved-was a later minute, which has also been tabled. I hope that, by now, Senator Messner has had an opportunity to read it, even though he has not yet had a briefing on it. The other document to which Mr Duncan was referring was the Australian Federal Police minute of 16 July, signed by Chief Superintendent Dixon, which makes it clear that, although there had been some investigation of security issues, the AFP felt that there were no security concerns.
—There was no way you said that.

—I am sorry if Senator Messner is still in a state of confusion. He is waving his head around and jumping up and down there in the front row like Billy Bunter. The situation is perfectly clear and as I have described it. There is no ground for any further confusion.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is it not a fact that the United States of America Government has given Australia the most solemn assurances that none of the so-called `joint' facilities are involved in any way with work being conducted under President Reagan's strategic defence initiative (SDI) or Star Wars program? How does the Minister square that solemn assurance with the fact that since 1971 the Nurrungar base has generated information on burn times, burn rates and spectral signatures of over 6,000 Soviet missile and satellite launches, that this information has been handed by the United States Government to its contractor firm, Aerojet General and that precisely this information is a necessary pre-condition-though not a sufficient one-for the successful development of strategic defence tracking and battle management systems under the Star Wars program? Does the Government now admit, in the light of this information, that the assurance given by Washington about Nurrungar has been broken?

—The answer to Senator Vallentine's question is that none of the joint facilities is involved in the SDI research project. The Australian and United States governments have a clear understanding on this point, and this understanding has been publicly affirmed by both governments on a number of occasions. The Government does not respond to speculation about the roles and the operations of the joint facilities. For the definitive position on these matters, I refer Senator Vallentine to the statement made by the Prime Minister on 6 June 1984 and to the Government's policy information paper on defence published earlier this year. However, I can assure Senator Vallentine that the understanding between the United States and Australian governments has not been broken. The joint facilities do not participate in SDI research. I will refer Senator Vallentine's complex supplementary question to the Minister for Defence when she asks it.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the Minister expects the denial to be based on the Prime Minister's statement of 6 June 1984, he must be joking. That told us nothing that had not been widely known in the community. It gave us no new information. I ask: On what specific and precise information, on what evidence, is this denial based? If the Minister cannot answer this question, why should the Australian people believe him without convincing evidence?
—I will refer that to the Minister for Defence for further response.

—My question is addressed to the Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Does the Government believe that equal employment opportunity should apply to diplomatic posts? Is it correct to say that Australia has only two ambassadors, one high commissioner and one consul-general that are women? Is the Minister or the Government aware of any women with the apparently perfect qualifications for a diplomatic posting, namely, those of former Senators Grimes and McClelland, who would be willing to cap off an otherwise perhaps distinguished parliamentary career with a diplomatic posting? Has the Minister encouraged, or will she encourage, the Government to look for such a person to improve our record in this area? In the event of there being a limited supply of such women, will the Minister offer herself for such a posting as a means of increasing the status of women?

—Senator Vanstone is off to quite a good start in trying to come to terms with equal opportunity principles-something with which she is starting from scratch, or even from behind scratch, since she did not see fit to vote for legislation giving equal opportunity, to her eternal shame and to the chagrin of many women in the Liberal Party who were absolutely disgusted with her performance. Poor Senator Peter Baume, who did have the temerity to stand up for his principles, disappeared. He is nowhere to be seen. Perhaps when Senator Peter Baume returns, if he is allowed to return, to the Liberal ranks, he will give Senator Vanstone a few well-needed tutorials in equal opportunity principles. Leaving that aside for one moment, it seems that Senator Vanstone has done some--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Peter Baume is absent from the chamber, having been given leave of this chamber to attend a parliamentary conference in Europe. He will be away for the minimum time necessary and then will return to take his place as a Liberal senator from New South Wales. It is quite wrong to suggest that he is absent for any other or frivolous reason.
—Order! There is no point of order. You have got your message across, Senator Reid.

—Senator Vanstone appears to have done some research on the number of women now holding top positions in overseas embassies, consulates and diplomatic missions. I am not sure whether her assessment is absolutely correct, but from memory I would say that all of those women who are currently holding posts of ambassador or consul-general have been appointed by our Government. When we came into government-Senator Gareth Evans might have some brief on this matter-from memory, there was not one woman head of mission. So we have undoubtedly--
—There was.
—Who? Who was there?
—Ruth Dobson.

—I was thinking of Ambassador Dobson in Ireland, but I think honourable senators will find that she had in fact concluded her service in Ireland. In any event, Ruth Dobson was first appointed to ambassadorial rank by the Whitlam Government. Our Government has an outstanding record in the appointment of women to senior ambassadorial posts. It is a record far ahead of anything done by Liberal-National Party governments in their 23 years and then another seven years in office. I would be surprised if, in all of that time, they made more than two female ambassadorial appointments. I can think of only two. Senator Vanstone has already named seven current--
—No; three ambassadors and high commissioners and one consul-general.

—In four years we have appointed at least four; I think they were all appointed by us. Very clearly, it is part of the equal opportunity program of this Government to make such appointments when they are deserved on the basis of merit, which those four appointments certainly were.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS' AFFAIRS: STATUS OF WOMEN

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Can the Minister give details of Budget initiatives in the Department of Veterans' Affairs which reflect the Hawke Government's commitment to the status of women?

—I thank Senator Giles for her question. I am pleased to remind the chamber that the Treasurer announced in his Budget Speech that ex-servicewomen from World War II will receive treatment benefits. For some years the ex-service community has sought these benefits and in March 1984 the then Minister, Senator Gietzelt, commissioned a study on returned servicewomen from World War II. The study found that these women suffered discrimination and disadvantage both during and after service.

—I do not expect this to be of interest to honourable senators on the other side but I am sure that there are many ex-servicewomen listening to the broadcast of these proceedings who are, indeed, very interested and who cannot understand why members of the Opposition are not interested. —My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Will the Minister confirm that, in its haste for Budget purposes to maximise the profit of a round $200m from the Australian Mint's production of the $2 coin, and because of a shortage of copper in Australia, the Government purchased copper from Chile? In view of the Prime Minister's attack last week on the Government of Chile, in which he accused it of resorting to torture, intimidation and murder, is this not yet another example of the double standards of the Hawke Government which does not let its foreign policy outrage interfere with its other interests?
—I do not appear to have a brief on this, Mr President, but I will ensure that I have an answer for the honourable senator as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Has his attention been drawn to an announcement made at 2 p.m. today by the Queensland Minister for Police, Mr Gunn, that the Commissioner of Police in that State, Sir Terence Lewis, has been asked to stand aside for the duration of the Queensland Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct, the Fitzgerald inquiry? Was Sir Terence in July appointed Chairman of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence? Was the former Deputy Commissioner, Mr Graeme Parker, who resigned last week and subsequently admitted that he was corrupt, liaison officer with the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence? In view of revelations arising daily from the Fitzgerald inquiry, has any investigation been launched by the Federal Government to ascertain whether the activities of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence have been compromised?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to media reports-I cannot confirm anything beyond those media reports-to the effect that the Queensland Police Minister, Mr Gunn, has asked his Commissioner, Sir Terence Lewis, to stand aside. Whether that was a direction or a request that has been acceded to, I am unable to say. It is a fact that Sir Terence is currently the Chairman of the board of management of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, which, as the name suggests, is the supervising body for the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. He is Chairman by way of rotation among the police commissioners who as a body constitute that board of management.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Jones asked about Mr Parker, the former Assistant Commissioner in Queensland. It is a fact that Mr Parker was the liaison officer for the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence appointed by the Commissioner for Queensland liaison work. As I have already indicated to the chamber, it was a similar capacity to that which he held in relation to the National Crime Authority, and that was the subject of an answer I gave last week. I had some discussions with Mr Chalker, the Director of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, on Friday morning in my office, when the Director attended at his own initiative, not by way of direction by me. Of course, honourable senators will understand that it is the board of management which is in control of the operations of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence and not me. Nevertheless, at that briefing I was able to get some indication from Mr Chalker of the degree to which he and his officers felt some concern about the fact that Mr Parker had access to the data passing between the Australian Bureau and the Queensland Bureau of Criminal Investigation. I would not wish at this stage to go beyond saying that I have received a briefing from the Director concerning those matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I have just been informed that Mr Gunn, the Minister, did ask Sir Terence Lewis to stand aside. That has been confirmed. What is the Minister's answer to the question now in relation to that matter and in relation to the Bureau itself?

—In answering Senator Jones my query was rather whether Mr Gunn had directed Sir Terence to stand aside or whether he had asked him, and whether that request had been acceded to. But I accept that, in any case, Sir Terence has stood aside for the duration of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct. Clearly, the board of management of the ABCI will now have to be convened and will have to appoint from within its number a new chairman. I have no doubt that, in the discussions leading to that reconvening, the sorts of concerns which lay behind Senator Jones's questions, which I know are shared by all honourable senators around the chamber, will be very adequately and forcefully addressed.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications and it again relates to the papers which have been tabled in this place relating to Amann Aviation Pty Ltd. I refer to the continuing discrepancy between answers given by the Minister here and those given by Mr Duncan in the other place. Senator Evans is claiming that all of the relevant documents have been tabled, whereas Mr Duncan today has again confirmed that the documents to which he was referring in the answers that were raised in this place last week arose out of a part of the tender process, and that they are quite distinct from the later documents which were tabled in this House. —Is the Special Minister of State aware of the most recent disclosure by the Australian Privacy Foundation that information on individuals is to be recorded on two different computers in relation to identity card details, one to contain the basic details of the individual and the other to hold the more private information, such as race, convictions and mental health? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am having a bit of trouble with Senator Bishop's nautical metaphors, but I will put those to one side. ANSWER.PARA: As has been pointed out, repeatedly, the Register will also contain administrative details which are required for the issue of Australia Cards and for the lawful operation of the Register. It will be information, as I said, such as when a person was contacted, when an interview was arranged and which documents were produced to confirm identity. It will not-I repeat not-be on a separate file but will be part of the Australia Card Register, and as such will be available for inspection by the individual. Senator Bishop's question also went to reports in one of the weekend newspapers-I think it was the Times on Sunday-about the Commonwealth Auditor-General's report on security in practices relating to computer facilities. I should point out that the Auditor-General's report does not identify any occasions on which unauthorised access has been gained to the Department of Community Services and Health central computer installation. There has been no such incident. The protective security issues raised by the Auditor-General covered only physical security, that is physical access to rooms within buildings, and had nothing to do with computers at all. Physical access to computer terminals is only the first, and a low level, form of defence against unauthorised access. The Department's computer systems are protected by a highly sophisticated password and access control software which has not been subject to criticism by the Auditor-General.

I remind honourable senators that the Australia Card computer system will be highly secure, with dedicated leased communication lines using the latest encryption devices to guarantee security from physical break-in, and the most sophisticated access control software to ensure only approved officers have access to the system. So it is quite clear that the Opposition, as usual, has nothing to run on in this matter except late Sunday night beat-ups and total misinterpretations of a fairly innocuous Auditor-General's report.
