PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 September, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Senate take note of the statement and papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The importance of a debate on the present Budget was underlined by what was said by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, in Question Time today when he complained about the fact that misrepresentation of argument was going on. He said that attitudinal and behavioural changes are needed if Australia is to have economic recovery. I would respectfully agree with that statement by Minister Walsh. I believe that attitudinal and behavioural changes are required for Australia's economic recovery. Senator Walsh went on to say that he believed that those changes were threatened by opportunists. Again I agree with him, but I believe that the opportunists who are threatening economic recovery by hindering the attitudinal and behavioural changes that are required are the members of the present Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We have recently debated the fact that on the issue of privatisation the Government distorted the debate throughout 1985 and until a few months ago, and now complains about the difficulty of getting a rational debate. That is what is happening with respect to the state of our economy generally. The Government has refused to face up to reality and as a result it is hindering the changes that are required if we are to get out of our economic predicament. The debate about the Budget has gone into a stage which was not planned by this Government. That stage was commenced by the honesty of expression by Minister Walsh when he addressed the Labor lawyers in Perth over the weekend. It is clear from the reports that the Finance Minister expected his comments to be private; he did not expect them to be reported. But a reporter was present and those comments have now been widely published around Australia. The misgivings that the Finance Minister has expressed about the economic position of Australia are a contribution to a public understanding of our economic situation, and a contribution that was long overdue from a member of this Government.

It was apparently all right for the Minister to give his view to a private meeting of Labor lawyers. There is a strong distinction between the view that he expressed there and the view he has expressed in the Senate. It would appear that for the Government it is all right to tell truth to the Labor lawyers, but there has to be some rather lesser version for the public debate in the Senate and in the House of Representatives. It would appear that it was the Government's intention to have the rest of Australia and Parliament hoodwinked by the euphoria salesman Keating and Hawke over the Budget which has just been brought down.

It is unfortunate that Senator Walsh was pulled back into line by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) today. We saw Senator Walsh in Question Time reflecting the sorts of answers which he gave in Question Time in the Senate last week. On Friday Senator Walsh was trying to demolish the Opposition's claim that the Budget was complacent. On Friday, as indeed on every day at Question Time last week, Senator Walsh defended the Budget. On 16 September-and this was the closest he went to any concession about the Budget-he said:

. . . I do not think anybody is pretending that all of the country's problems are solved. The Treasurer's comment, repeated I think many times yesterday, that the country has turned a corner is, I believe, to any rational person beyond dispute. One could also add that we are making progress in the right direction at a significant rate.

I am concerned at the representations made by the Government about the Budget, for the reasons that Minister Walsh has expressed so clearly in Question Time today-that unless we can get attitudinal and other changes in Australia, we will not solve our economic problems. We will not get those attitudinal changes if we do not have a straightforward and honest debate-and, even more important, a debate that is not conducted on the basis that anybody who opposes the Government's position will be traduced in this place.

Until the weekend it was mainly the Opposition which had expressed concern about the Budget. A few commentators-and Ross Gittins of the Sydney Morning Herald stands out-warned about the fragility of the Budget and described it as `a Budget of wasted opportunities'. Mr Gittins called it a `she'll be right' Budget, a `do nothing' Budget, but he was one of the few who came out and expressed doubt and concern. I express the hope that Mr Gittins will not be subjected to the sort of personal attack that we saw on Mr Moore and Mr Elliott last week, the sort of attack that seems to be par for the course for anybody who dares to put his or her head above the parapet to criticise the policies of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —He doesn't put his head in the public money trough; that is the difference.

—I am glad to see the Leader of the Government joining in Senator Walsh's habits. But the point is that until Senator Walsh blew the whistle on his colleagues very few commentators outside the Opposition had been prepared to give a warning to the Australian people about the deficiencies of the Budget. It is important to remember that it has been only 16 months since the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said that Australia was headed towards becoming a banana republic. Fifteen months ago the Prime Minister saw fit to make a televised address to the nation about the crisis that we faced. Then, of course, 15 months later, in last week's Budget, we had the presentation of a very euphoric picture-what John Howard had described as `a lotus land picture'-of where Australia stands. The change is one which I think is worthy of comment because at the weekend Senator Walsh joined us in admitting that Australia's present path is a path which leads down the Argentinean road, that all is not well and that the Budget is not appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: Fifteen months ago the public was widely concerned about the state of the economy because of three factors: the collapsing Australian dollar; the continuous reporting of the balance of payments crisis; and the continuing reporting of our ever-increasing foreign debt. The only thing that has really changed now is that the dollar has appreciated and that is largely related to international movements of currency, changes in the value of the American dollar and so on. It still remains true that Australia is living way beyond its means. It is doing so internationally and nationally. The fact that we are doing it internationally is borne out by the fact that the Government is predicting a foreign trade deficit in excess of $11 billion. We have what is claimed to be a balanced Budget at the national level but the Government has quite clearly fudged on that and I believe that the whole of Australia is aware that the true deficit is closer to $2.5 billion. There is the $1 billion worth of assets sales and the unusually large amount which has been paid from currency transactions that makes up that difference. There is no real doubt-there was no real doubt at the time of the Prime Minister's address to the nation-that the solution to Australia's ongoing problems, with our ever-increasing international debt, involves more savings on the part of the Australian people, higher productivity on the part of the Australian work force and the attraction of greater investment if we are to get the increase in productivity which is essential for our recovery. So far that has not been produced by the Government.

If one looks at the Budget Papers one finds that the Government is telling us that productivity did not rise during the last financial year; productivity declined. There was a decline in our national productivity in 1986-87, a year in which we were told by Mr Keating that we were moving to banana republic status and by the Prime Minister that we were in a state of crisis akin to war. There can be no satisfaction for the Government or Australia and no solution for Australia when productivity has further declined. The present Budget predicts a very small increase in productivity in 1987-88. We have yet to see whether that will be achieved but the improvement which is predicted is quite marginal.

As far as investment is concerned-which, I believe, even the Government concedes is essential-our progress has been woeful. In 1986-87 business investment fell to an historically low proportion of gross domestic product, 9.7 per cent. Our national productivity is negative, national savings are falling, we have a low level of private investment and, not surprisingly, as a consequence our debt rose by around $20 billion. Competitiveness declined further as our unit labour costs grew by about 7 1/2 per cent, whereas the average for our trading partners was 3 per cent. In other words, the gap between us and the rest of the world widened and our inflation rate-a further area of concern and difficulty for us-declined to 9.3 per cent while overseas the average was less than half of that. A series of indicators shows a worsening of our fundamental position, which is masked substantially by the fact that our dollar has recovered in value, for reasons which have little to do with the fundamentals of our economy.

The Budget-the Government's summary statement of where we are-admits to some of the key areas of difficulty that we face. There is the Treasurer's assessment of labour costs. Page 4 of the printed Budget Speech states:
In particular, we must make sure that labour costs in Australia are competitive with those of our trading partners.

What is the position with respect to our labour costs? As I have already said, our labour costs are rising at more than twice the rate of those of our competitors. Although the Treasurer says that we must make sure that labour costs in Australia are competitive, the Government, in its own Budget documents, is making it clear that they will not be competitive. The arguments which are being used by the Government again lack the honesty that is required if we are to achieve genuine understanding in the community of the problems that we face and the attitudinal changes which the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) only today has indicated are necessary. On that same page of the Budget Speech the Treasurer said:
The Australian community has shown enormous maturity and common sense in responding to the trade crisis by exercising wage restraint.
This has helped sustain the new-found competitiveness of Australian industry.
The Treasurer went on to say:
Most importantly it has ensured that the difficult international trading conditions have not led to a surge in unemployment.

Of all those statements, only the latter is true. The fact is that there has not been a degree of wage restraint which goes anywhere near ensuring that labour costs in Australia are competitive with those of our trading partners. The reverse is true.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a lot of hocus-pocus. You compare our manufacturing labour costs with the United States of America.

—A little later I shall give some figures on the rate of change of labour costs in this country and in those of our trading partners. The figures are clear and there for all to see. There has been an enormous change in the nominal wage rates in Australia. The sort of interjection made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate is based on the fact that there was a substantial devaluation of the Australian dollar, which on a temporary basis changes the apparent international cost of our labour. The Government has been able to claim an increase in competitiveness. That is not based on the control of labour costs, because they have been rising at a much faster rate than in the United States or anywhere else. The increased competitiveness has occurred because of the collapse of the Australian dollar. The Government has chosen to make a virtue of that. It has been completely confused on the matter. The Leader of the Government in the Senate told us in a speech about a year ago that manufacturers could rely on an Australian dollar worth about US62c, but today's dollar is worth about 73c. The competitive labour rates to which he referred and which he has discussed with manufacturers are rather ephemeral in view of our currency movements in the past 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government also acknowledged in the Budget Speech:
. . . the magnitude of our trading problem is such that we still have a long way to go.

That is true, but the same Budget Papers disclosed that the trading problems, although slightly diminished as a share of the gross domestic product, continue to be a serious problem for Australia. The Government predicts a trade deficit of over $11 billion. Obviously, that will involve another steep increase in our public and private debt. Where is the appropriate action to reverse that serious position?

The Budget predicts wage growth totally out of line with that of our competitors and higher interest rates and higher inflation than for our competitors, yet the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, claims that we are becoming more competitive. We can become more competitive in those circumstances only if we are again subject to a devaluation of the Australian dollar. At the moment, as I said, we in fact have an appreciating dollar and therefore our lack of competitiveness is made even worse. I am sorry that Senator Button will not be participating in the debate today. It is hard to imagine how he can argue that we are going to get investment in export industries for Australia, given the combination of circumstances that I have just mentioned.

The Government has at last caught up with the rhetoric of the microeconomic reforms which the Opposition has been urging for some time. Again, Minister Walsh this morning on the AM program put some emphasis on the need for microeconomic reforms. He said, `You are not going to solve Australia's economic problems just from the Budget; there are all these other matters that have to be addressed'. Perhaps Senator Button will recall the approach which the Opposition took to the Budget last year, when we realised the fact that microeconomic reforms needed to be made if there was to be a substantial improvement in the investment climate in this country. It took the Prime Minister of Australia until a few weeks ago, when he addressed a conference of economists, to pick up the point made by the Opposition more than a year ago, namely, that microeconomic reform was also essential if we were to get investment recovery in Australia. I commend to the Government a further study of the policies we produced last year in the document entitled `Policies for Business' as a summary of the areas which require the urgent attention of this government. They required its urgent attention then; they require its urgent attention now.

A further point which is fundamental, and it relates to the sorts of policy issues we canvassed a year ago, is the essential need for labour market reform to be undertaken if we are to get economic recovery. The fact of the matter is that labour market reform is substantially stalled under this Administration. The Budget claims that productivity is important and, indeed, there are some very optimistic statements about the fact that the Government has moved to the two-tier wages system which, of course, places emphasis on negotiations which are based on productivity improvement. But I draw the attention of the Government to the fact that productivity has not improved. During this year in which the second tier wage approach has been adopted, the Budget Papers show that productivity has in fact declined, and only a very marginal increase in productivity is predicted for the current year. I suggest that the rhetoric of the Government with respect to its wages policy and the two-tier wages system is in no way borne out by the figures which the Government itself has disclosed in this Budget.

We have the further worrying fact that the trade union movement, in its publication Australia Reconstructed, has started to direct Australia down precisely the wrong course if we are to get economic recovery. It is notable that Ministers such as Mr Dawkins and Senator Button have been very cautious in their statements on Australia Reconstructed; but the document, which has been produced by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and which is clearly to be the subject of a great deal of trade union action and pressure over the coming 12 months, would add greatly to the inflexibility of the Australian economy at a time when the Government itself has been arguing for far greater flexibility. The idea that there should be a greater degree of directed investment and that there should be a proportion of Australia's national savings pre-empted by government and compulsorily invested in areas which are partly directed by the trade union movement is scarcely likely to encourage the free investment in this economy which is required if we are to achieve the productivity increases which are essential to solving our problems.

There is no proposal from this Government to remedy the moribund enforcement provisions. It is interesting that in May of this year, just prior to the election, we had Minister Willis telling the Parliament that the enforcement provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act were ineffective. He said that they were moribund, and he produced legislation which proposed to put effective enforcement provisions into the law. We now find that the ACTU is directing the Government that it will not have legislation which introduces effective enforcement provisions. So, in the vital area of labour market reform, which is so central to the solution of Australia's economic problems, we find the Government with its hands tied and we find it adopting procedures with respect to wages and productivity which are simply proving to be ineffective.

If a single significant issue arises out of the publication of the present Budget, that issue is the rate at which progress must be made if Australia is to be secure. Budget Paper No. 1 contains what is effectively an apology for the rate of change which the Government has sought to undertake. Under the heading `The Pace of Adjustment' in Budget Paper No. 1 we get a lengthy discussion about whether practical policies could be implemented to achieve more rapid adjustment. Clearly, the Government's attitude to that is that the answer is no. So, we have a rate of adjustment proposed which is perilous in the extreme and which means that Australia is extremely vulnerable to any downturns in economic activity. I will quote from what the Government published in Budget Paper No. 1. The point is made again about why it is important that we have a frank and honest debate about these issues in the Budget. It is said on page 51:

There are therefore limits to what government on its own can achieve, although political leadership is, of course, important in building community acceptance. It is critical that the community understands the forces at work in the economy and the trade-offs that are possible, particularly trade-offs that involve current restraint and changes to past practices in return for reasonable expectations of improved circumstances in the future. There are many signs that this understanding is on the move in Australia.

I wanted to quote that because it brings out the vital point that government has a lead role in this. What is said by government is important in creating the understanding which permits the changes to be made which are required for our economic recovery. The Government's statements on this Budget, with the honourable exception of the statement this weekend of the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, are statements which cloud the public understanding of the vital and very difficult issues that face Australians. There is a need to understand that wage rates that are not based on increases in productivity simply lead to more inflation and lower competitiveness. The fact is that such wage rises simply lead to no real increase in wages at all. That fact should be clearly understood, given the experience of recent years. Those simple points, which are so vital to the changes that we seek, are being clouded by the approach that the Government has adopted.

There has been debate at other times in this place about the pattern of debate on these issues. I have referred previously to the debate on privatisation, which was a classic example of the debate being distorted by the Government in a way which has made the implementation of rational policies on privatisation more difficult for the Government. It does not really sit in the mouth of the Prime Minister to complain about the difficulty of getting rational debate on this issue when we find that he has described privatisation as:
. . . a one-off fire sale, a sale of the century, of your assets-the assets of the people of Australia. That would transfer them into the hands of a privileged few, to the cost of every one of us.
The Treasurer, Mr Keating, has described it as `simply vandalism of Australia's great public authorities'.

I again express my protest and my concern that the debate on these issues has been so fundamentally distorted. In exactly the same way there has been a fundamental distortion of the debate about labour market reform, with the Government engaging in a scare campaign in May of last year on the issue of our industrial relations policy, which gave little credit to the policies that we put forward and which in fact masked substantial labour agreement with the need for a great deal of labour market flexibility in this country.

What has happened with respect to this Budget is that the Government has caught itself on its own hook and is now wriggling to get off, to the great detriment of the country. As far as I can see from the comments made by Senator Walsh, the only real quarrel that he has with the proposals that we have put forward for economic recovery is that he disagrees with us on the need for cuts in taxation. Apart from that, it appears that he is in broad agreement with the program that we have put forward.

In the limited time left for me to speak, I will pass on from the economic impact of this Budget which, in my view is a Budget which is a gamble with Australia's future; a Budget which has left the economic future in the lap of the gods-or perhaps with the gnomes of Zurich or the financiers of Tokyo would be more accurate-and a Budget that will succeed only if international circumstances, and in particular capital flows which are affected by extraneous influences, are completely favourable to us. I turn to discuss the social side of the Budget and the impact that the present Government is having on a number of institutions. For example, one could talk of the impact that the Government is having on the health system and the imbalance that it is creating between public and private health care in this country to the detriment of those who provide private health care and, more importantly, to the detriment of those who could be receiving an efficient service through the private health system but who are being thrown back on to the public health system to the detriment of the rest of the community.

That sort of fundamental imbalance in the way that health care is delivered in Australia is part of a process that has been going on for some years, which has lead to queues and which has led to the provision of ameliorative measures in this Budget. Millions of dollars have been provided to try to do away with the queues in public hospitals and so on. But the fundamental error that the Government has made in attacking the private health care system by reducing the extent of government assistance and subsidy to that system is certainly showing up in reduced standards of health care around Australia.

Even more important is the drift of circumstances against families with dependants which is continuing under this Government and under this Budget. In this Budget the Government has sought to make much of its commitment to Australian families. It has done that by extending the family income supplement arrangements that were introduced by the Fraser Government in its final Budget and by extending additional, very welcome assistance to low income families. The fundamental point I want to make is that nothing has been done in this Budget to address the question of where the burden of adjustment should lie in the Australian community. What has been happening under this Government is that a greater and greater burden has been borne by those Australians who have dependants. The Government, by failing to acknowledge in the tax system the cost of dependency, has made the burdens on families with children very much greater over recent years. The sad fact about this Budget is that the only families who are getting any assistance are those on low incomes when the reality is that a very substantial number of middle income families are feeling the strain of the economic circumstances.

That is the first complaint that I wish to make about the Budget's approach to social matters. The Government has chosen to treat the family as a welfare matter. It has chosen to ignore the advice that it has been given by observers such as Bettina Cass, who was commissioned by the Government to work on its behalf on issues affecting families. It has deserted middle income Australian families. It has said that assistance will be provided only to those people who can be classified as welfare cases.

Just as seriously, the sort of assistance provided to low income families means that many of those families will be locked into a poverty trap. Let me take the simple example of a family on one gross income of $330 per week with two children and living in rented accommodation. That family will receive considerable assistance from the Government under its family assistance package. That is a very good thing. But the negative of that assistance is that in order for that family to improve its situation by $10 per week, it would need an additional income of about $90 per week. In other words, an income earner on $330 per week looking to improve his or her position will have to get an income of $420 per week to gain even $10 per week extra advantage.

What the Government is doing in its welfare approach to families is locking them into what are called poverty traps, but essentially, it is providing a disincentive for families to improve their position by hard work and achievement. The Government's social engineering in this Budget is a disaster. The social engineering aspect of the Budget ranks with the craven failure of the Government to come to grips with Australia's basic economic problems as the great failures of the Budget.
On behalf of the Opposition, I move the following amendment:
At end of motion, add:
``, but the Senate notes:
(a) the failure of the Budget to:
(i) reduce the level of Commonwealth spending on its own programmes and therefore the Government's call on national resources
(ii) address underlying causes of our chronic uncompetitiveness, in particular the reasons for our extremely low productivity and excessive wages growth, and
(iii) create an economic environment conducive to a substantial lift in business investment;
(b) that because of these failings, the Government expects to see continuing growth in Australia's foreign debt; and

(c) the criticisms of the Minister for Finance in his speech to Labor Lawyers in Perth on 19 September about the Government's lack of courage in not further cutting spending, and his warning about the dangers of Australia heading further down the `Argentinian road',
and calls on the Government to introduce a Mini Budget during the current Parliamentary sittings to address these deficiencies in the 1987-88 Budget.''

I commend the amendment to the Senate. I believe that, at a period when Australia faces very great risks in the future, the Government has lost its nerve and failed to come to grips with Australia's problems. It has done that not only on the economic front but also on the social front to the enduring detriment of Australian families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Tuesday night the Treasurer, Mr Keating, proudly announced to the Parliament, to Australia and to the world at large, assuming it was listening, that he was presenting a virtually balanced Budget. We have all discovered since then that some of it was certainly done with mirrors; nevertheless, that was the proud claim that he made last Tuesday night. He did so, of course, not only confident-and justifiably so-that he had pulled the rug out from underneath the Opposition, which had been howling for a balanced Budget for some time, but also sure that he would receive accolades from Australian big business representatives and the national and international financial sector.

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget and its contents were the culmination of four years of moving to the right politically, economically and socially by the Hawke Labor Government. It represents the final severing of any ties at all this Government may have had to its predecessor the Whitlam Labor Government. From the beginning, the Hawke-Keating alliance within this Labor Government has been determined not to make the same errors as the Whitlam Government did when that Government remained true to Australian Labor Party policies and philosophies and, in doing so, attracted massive opposition from the domestic business community and foreign investors. So, over the last four years, the Hawke-Keating Government has implemented cuts to Australian welfare expenditure demanded by the business community; it has abandoned its commitment to Aboriginal land rights; it has ignored the practicalities of the needs of Australian women; it has introduced tertiary fees, albeit by another name, and it looks set to introduce tertiary fees properly fairly shortly if some of the reports in today's papers are true; it has largely ignored, as Senator Chaney said, the problems of Australian families; it has abandoned its commitment to freedom of information, privacy protection and civil liberties; and in a thousand other ways it has become the doyen of the New Right.

In this Budget the Government reintroduced negative gearing for property investors on the thin and very fallacious ground that this would provide low income housing in Sydney-only in Sydney and only because an election in New South Wales is looming. It also flagged further deregulation policies and a plan for privatisation. The first question that we need to ask ourselves is whether a balanced Budget is necessarily a good thing. The answer, of course, lies in the way in which the balance is achieved. Of course this Budget has been applauded by the Australian business community and foreign investors whom it was designed to please. The Government's almost balancing trick has been achieved in part by selling off some government assets and in part by higher than expected taxation revenue. However, the real price for the balanced Budget has been a series of expenditure reduction programs announced in last year's Budget-things like the postponement of pensioners' consumer price index increases, the postponement of the poverty traps legislation and so on. This situation was further exacerbated by the contents of this year's May economic statement.

This chamber-indeed, this Parliament-did not get a proper chance to debate the May expenditure cuts which were made in the health, social security and education areas, and which were announced as part of the May economic statement because we went to an early election. But I need not remind this place, nor the community at large, that despite the fact that we did not have a chance to debate those issues and point out the problems, those expenditure cuts, which people are beginning to feel now, will in fact reduce the availability of education, social security, community services and health to low income households and to those two million Australians living below the poverty line. They will feel the effects of the cuts made in the last Budget and the last mini-Budget, notwithstanding the fact that few of us got the opportunity to point out exactly who was going to be hit and how hard. At a time of massive levels of unemployment and falling living standards for average and low income families, further expenditure cuts will create a class of permanently homeless, under-educated, poor and unhealthy Australians.

Along with expenditure cuts, the big business sector, of course, regards further deregulation of financial markets as vital-vital, that is, to its short term interests. Public interest questions and, in particular long term public interest questions, are rarely raised and answered, or rarely listened to if they are raised and answered, when issues like privatisation, foreign investment and ownership and negative gearing are mentioned. Where is the long term sense in reducing our foreign debt by selling Australian businesses, farms and property to foreign investors? Why has there been no official Government response to the statement of the Chairman of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd that he would be happy if 40 per cent of the big Australian were foreign owned. When I raised that question in this place last week the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) chose not to answer the challenge in that question, and I hope that at some stage during this debate on the Budget somebody from the Government benches will come up with some sort of response to that problem.

Why does Australia not have, for example, a public register of foreign ownership? Why, in our desire to drive down the foreign debt-at least on paper-by whatever means possible do we not realise that we run a real risk of being the pawn in foreign boardrooms? Our resources, our labour, our markets and our economy will be manipulated to the best ends of overseas decision makers. The last thing they will be concerned with is the ultimate well-being of the majority of Australians. Even without ownership of our resources some of our allies have sacrificed Australia's economy to their own short term political ends. Protectionist policies, illustrated by the United States wheat subsidies implemented to meet the political ends of mid-term elections, are a classic example.

Australia's economic well-being is further threatened by the moves that are being made in the United States at the moment with regard to doing something to sort out America's trade imbalance with Japan-the solution for which could well be very seriously detrimental to this country. Yet, is the Australian Government prepared to take steps that are likely in any way at all to halt the process that the United States Government has embarked upon? With the enthusiastic support of the Opposition it is refusing, at the moment at least, to retaliate by using, for example, the only effective means available to it; that is, the bases, the so-called joint facilities. Even the Philippines manages to get a substantial rental out of the use that the United States makes of its land, and we sit back and watch the American Government, the American Congress, play with our economy without retaliating in any way at all.

A further problem of deregulation, of course, comes from the increased investment overseas of Australian savings. When this also involves a tax concession to the companies and organisations concerned, the problem to the Australian economy is exacerbated. One of the few things that the Australian Democrats welcomed in the Budget and post-Budget announcements by this government was the Treasurer's statement that he has decided to reconsider the tax exempt status of superannuation funds as part of its review of company tax. We have deplored in this place time and again the tendency for superannuation funds and the big life funds to invest overseas. We have sought from the Government a commitment that it will encourage those funds to invest in Australia to create jobs in Australia. That they are incapable of investing off-shore, speculating essentially in the Australian dollar and retaining tax-free status, should have been reconsidered by this Government some considerable time ago.

The Australian Democrats, therefore, believe that the Government should implement a tax on superannuation funds' assets which are invested overseas, and only on that portion which is invested overseas. Funds which invest heavily overseas would therefore be taxed quite significantly and at a much higher rate than those which invest predominantly in Australia, that is, those funds which invest in a way which means that Australia's best interests are being looked after. Such a tax on the profits from overseas investment would give superannuation funds an incentive to invest in Australia, rather than going off-shore.

We would want the revenue generated by taxing superannuation funds to provide socially useful things such as better education, social security improvements and health and housing services. This would raise the living standards of those Australians who have borne the brunt of the Government's expenditure cuts and who are not wealthy enough to benefit from the negative gearing incentives which the Government restored to the wealthiest Australians in this year's Budget. One of the greatest sell-outs to the prevailing economic spirit of courting the wealthy at the expense of the poor was the decision to reinstate what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) himself has called in the past the `rort' of negative gearing. It is a classic case in which the corporate welfare sector is being pandered to at the expense of the social welfare sector. It is a classic example of the Government arguing that it is giving assistance indirectly to those who need it when it could far more effectively give that assistance directly.

The draft White Paper entitled `Reform of the Australian Taxation System' gave the powerful equity reason to support the Government's original legislation to abolish negative gearing for rental property. Table 22A/3 of that document makes it pretty clear who will benefit from this newly-announced sell-out, represented by the reintroduction of negative gearing for rental properties. The table, which was drawn up by the Treasury when the Government was still concerned about making the tax system equitable, showed that in 1982-83 14 per cent of individuals with negatively geared properties would have had taxable incomes of over $100,000 if negative gearing were allowed, and less than 2 per cent with negatively geared properties would have had incomes below $20,000. One wonders how many of those were the people mentioned by the Opposition in recent days-millionaires, at least on paper, with nominal income of $5,000 per annum.

So one needs to ask why the Government chose to reinstate negative gearing for rental property when it could have acted in a more direct way to stimulate the housing market, particularly in low income areas, thereby reducing a very significant problem for low income earners and low income families in particular. The answer that the Government gave was ostensibly to increase the supply of rental accommodation-as I said earlier, especially in Sydney, where the Australian Labor Party is facing an election. Apart from making wealthy Australians even wealthier, this action will do very little indeed to provide more housing for average and low income Australians. The Government has produced no statistics to show that the majority of money spent on negatively-geared properties is spent in those areas where low income families are likely to seek or get a roof over their heads. It cannot and it will not assist those sorts of people to get rental accommodation in either the short term or the long term. Even if it did, as I have already said, it could not possibly do so as effectively as giving direct assistance to people in need. Had the Government directed the money it saved by abolishing negative gearing towards the provision of low cost public housing or to subsidised rental the people who most desperately need assistance to get housing would have been given that opportunity in a far better way than this measure is likely to do.

Property values have already risen. Looking at real estate advertisements over the weekend I was not surprised-rather I was somewhat disturbed-to note that almost every advertisement for a sale or rental opportunity in the property market, that is for investment rental property, indicated that negative gearing had come back in. Great play was made in both Saturday's and Sunday's real estate markets of the fact that the Government had done an about turn. Stories appeared in the economic sections of most of the daily newspapers on the weekend to encourage people to enter the housing market. What happened? Housing prices went up by about 10 per cent within days of the Government's announcement. This morning's newspapers indicate that some properties have almost doubled in price from what they were valued at 12 months ago to what they sold for at auction over the weekend.

So it is not the poor and the low income earners who will benefit from the reintroduction of negative gearing and the abolition of the ban on it. It is the people who are already well-off and who wish to minimise their tax. So much for the Government's arguments that we need something as draconian as an ID card to ensure that people pay their fair share of tax. When it suits the Government it is quite prepared to pander to the wealthy in the community.

As property prices rise, which they have already begun to do, rents will rise. Mr Terry Burke, a Senior Lecturer in Urban Studies at the Swinburne Institute of Technology, is reported in today's Age as denying that there even was a shortage of rental accommodation.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't live in Sydney.

—The Government is flapping around with mirrors to try to justify something that, as Senator Richardson has just said, was introduced solely for the purposes of achieving some better chance of the Labor Government's survival in New South Wales, by pandering to property developers on the Sydney market. Mr Burke went on to say that the boost in property investment would not increase rental stocks. One real estate agent was reported to have said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . rents are already quite high, and they are going to stay high.

There will be no benefit to low income earners from this move by the Government. Mr Keating stated in the Budget that the reintroduction of this form of negative gearing is symmetrical in the sense that all forms of negative gearing are now permissible. Fantastic! The Democrats have been arguing that the reverse symmetry should occur. Instead of reintroducing negative gearing on property markets to make things symmetrical in negative gearing, the Government, if it were serious about equity, would have abolished all forms of negative gearing, particularly the form of negative gearing that applies to foreign financed loans for the purchase of Australian companies by Australians. That new form of monopoly in this country, based on foreign borrowings, does very little for our economy, for productivity or for increases in employment.

If the Government had abolished negative gearing for funds borrowed from overseas to finance those sorts of takeovers of Australian companies, it would have been provided with over $1 billion in revenue and would have helped to reduce our foreign debt at the same time as increasing our revenue. But apparently this Government is not interested in doing anything that would antagonise its wealthy friends. That is why there is very little difference, an ever decreasingly small difference, between this ALP Government and the Liberal-National Party alternative.

Although this Budget has been well received by businessmen and bankers, we all need to keep in mind that we still face internal and external economic problems that could push us back on to the banana republic path mentioned by Mr Keating some time ago. None of those problems have been addressed in the context of this Budget. Our internal economic problems are centred on, of course, the external economic sector as we become part of an increasingly international economic scene. We are already heavily in debt overseas and we continue to run up a big current account deficit, yet all this Government can do is set the economy to attract foreign investment so that we will exchange debts for equity; that is, we will turn our foreign debt problems into a foreign ownership problem. If the Government thinks that is clever, I am afraid I have to disagree with it. It causes a massive problem for Australia when we turn from a large foreign indebtedness to a foreign ownership situation.

Essentially, the 1987-88 Budget has ended any claim at all that the Hawke Government had to achieving what it called restraint with equity. The Government has admitted that over 600,000 Australians will remain unemployed. The family assistance package is certainly welcome, but it is a very limited start to the fulfilment of the election promise to eliminate child poverty by 1990. The much vaunted promise to lift nearly 600,000 children out of poverty by that year has resulted simply in delayed expenditure of some $250m in 1987-88. This will lift no more than 130,000 children now in poverty out of it, compared with 580,000 children in families below the poverty line, leaving 450,000 children and their families in poverty. With two years left to fulfil its promise, this Government has more than two-thirds of that task alone to achieve.

This Budget destroys the efforts of the Commonwealth Schools Commission to improve the education of children and young people from disadvantaged backgrounds; yet we hear a lot about this Government's concern for those people who are in some way disadvantaged by isolation or low income. The Government has cut back even further grants to development programs, such as the programs geared to the needs of those groups I have just mentioned: the isolated people and people on low incomes. The basic learning program and the participation and equity program are two such examples. Neither will be renewed despite recent Schools Commission recommendations that they be followed by new programs. This is despite the fact that the Government boasted during the election that it wanted to increase school retention rates to year 12 to 66 per cent by the early 1990s. It sits somewhat in line with the contradictory nature of the Government arguing prior to the May mini-Budget that it wanted to encourage training and retraining programs, and then cutting $30m off technical and further education, one of the major areas where training and retraining takes place; not just training for those youngsters who have left school earlier than they should have, but also retraining programs for mature aged people, particularly breadwinners who have found themselves redundant and therefore unemployed, with skills that are no longer useful to the community and therefore very much in need of retraining programs.

The Government's so-called commitment to industrial democracy becomes a mockery when the allocation to increase awareness of industrial democracy in both the private and public sectors is reduced by a little under 19 per cent in real terms and the allocation for occupational health and safety is reduced by almost 17 per cent in real terms.

The real increase of about 10 per cent to the adult migrant education program has been achieved at considerable cost. The English as a second language program for primary schools, which was cut in the last Budget, was supposed to be picked up by the States but it has become moribund in at least Queensland and Western Australia, and it will not be long before other States follow suit. The idea of a Federal government cutting its deficit back and cutting its expenditure back by passing on the requirement for expenditure to State governments is ludicrous. Ultimately the taxpayers must pay for the services they demand in terms of appropriate education, appropriate health care, appropriate social welfare benefits and even sufficient roads. Simply to cut back on its expenditure and to expect State government to pick up the tab is a sleight of hand that I would not have thought was worthy of a Federal Labor government that argues that it favours social justice and economic equity.

The closure of migrant centres in Queensland and Western Australia to force migrant services back into the community has of course ended, among other things, the provision of child care centres, which allowed migrant women to participate in the community, to attend English language classes and to break down their isolation. So much for equal opportunity, not just for women but for other disadvantaged groups and, in particular, migrant groups, especially those whose grasp of the English language is limited. Once again in this Budget we have seen disadvantaged and low income people suffer further hardships while the bankers and businessmen in Australia applaud the Government for its generosity in their direction.

Senator Chaney, in his response to the Budget, talked about the need for Australia to fight its way out of the economic mire. Australia will never fight its way out of the long term economic mire if it persists in promoting the theory of the trickle down effect. Making the rich richer will not lift the poor out of poverty. Encouraging non-productive development through deregulation and tax concessions will not reduce unemployment or increase exports. Pandering to the self-centred demands of Australia's high rollers will not reduce our foreign debt or improve our balance of trade problems. This Budget heralds yet another win, as I said earlier, for the corporate welfare sector at the expense of the social welfare sector. I was asked last week on television what marks I would give this Government for this Budget. I responded without a great deal of thought, saying that I would give it 10 out of 10 for appearances and, being generous, five out of 10 for effectiveness. I suspect, given the things that have happened in the property market in particular in the last few days, that that five out of 10 should be significantly devalued to something like 2 1/2 out of 10. This Government has abandoned its principles, its policies and its commitment to those in need and it no longer deserves the name of the Australian Labor Party. It no longer deserves to pretend that it represents the disadvantaged or even the workers in this country, and this Budget is its final abandonment of everything it ever stood for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence by seconding the amendment moved by Senator Chaney. I propose to devote my remarks to addressing a number of the myths which this Government and particularly its chief budgetary spokesmen have so sedulously sought to foster in less than a week since the Budget was brought down last Tuesday evening. There are many such myths but the chief ones would be as follows. There is, first, the myth of the balanced Budget. There is, secondly, the myth of expenditure restraint. There is, thirdly, the myth of the massive tax cuts that the Australian public is supposed to have received in this year of Our Lord 1987-88. There is, fourthly, the myth that the Government's policies are addressing the real issues-albeit, as the Government itself has conceded, only gradually-of the debt that Australians face to foreigners in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: There is the myth that we have turned the corner-that corner which we have been turning so regularly, every time the Treasurer (Mr Keating) makes a speech-and in particular in that regard the myth that somehow or other the key to our future prosperity, namely, the future of business fixed investment, is about to be turned by the policies which this Government has applied to that problem. There is, above all, the myth that `she'll be right' internationally. I will conclude by saying that this Budget is the Budget of an already tired Government which has already dropped the ball.

Let me take the first of the myths to which I have referred-the myth of the deficit. The Government has sought to persuade us or, at any rate, to bully us-which it is much better at-into believing that the deficit in this Budget is a mere $27m. It has done that by including in the outlays side of the Budget as a negative expenditure an amount of $1,000m which it estimates it will receive from the proceeds of sales of major-I repeat `major'-assets. Of course, for many years now the Budget Papers have contained items of minor asset sales. Indeed, if one goes back to the mini-Budget paper, the economic statement, of May this year, one will find on page 24 of the printed document, under the functional classification of `General Public Services', sales of surplus land, buildings and other minor assets estimated to yield this year $82.2m. That item is not included in the quite separate classification in that very same mini-budgetary paper of major asset sales in a program at that time of over $1 billion.

As I say, we have had minor sales of assets for many years and their treatment has, I think, changed somewhat over more recent years. One would need more time than one has this afternoon to direct one's remarks to that matter. However, I noted that last week, in response to a question from Senator Short, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who is absent from the chamber at the moment, took the trouble to quote some material which no doubt had been prepared for him by one of his more assiduous research officers. He said:
. . . in the 1980-81 Budget the then Treasurer-presumably with the approval of the then Secretary to the Treasury-presented asset sales.
He went on to say:
If one dug into the pages of Budget Statement No. 4-
underline that; `Budget Statement No. 4'-
one would find a small table and about a three-line reference to proposed sales of assets. In present values those proposed asset sales were over $300m.

It does not seem to have occurred to the Minister when making that reference that he was implicitly admitting the position of the Opposition by pointing out-I have checked the reference and he is totally accurate-that this reference does occur in Statement No. 4. However, unfortunately for the case being argued by the Minister, Statement No. 4 was then and is today the statement relating to receipts, not expenditures. So, it is perfectly true that in 1980-81 the government of the day did indeed include $300m of asset sales on the receipts side of its Budget because that is where the proceeds from those asset sales were received.

I hope that in future the Minister will not merely have these matters better researched but also think more carefully about the implications of the research that is handed to him. If one does abstract from this $1,000m of major asset sales-I repeat `major asset sales'-one is not contemplating a Budget deficit of $27m at all but a Budget deficit of $1,027m.

However, the story does not end there because, as has been remarked by other speakers, the Budget also contains an estimate of receipts of $2,659m from the profits of the Reserve Bank of Australia this year, which is slightly higher than the equally large and equally unusual payment last year. But a very large proportion of those profits has been garnered by the Reserve Bank in the year past, and is expected to be garnered in the year ahead, from sales of foreign exchange held in the coffers of the Reserve Bank-Australia's total foreign exchange reserves-foreign exchange acquired some time ago, before the value of the Australian dollar crashed so catastrophically as a result of this Government's policies.

Of course, unless the Government is contemplating a further fall in the value of the Australian dollar so that it can continue to have the Reserve Bank make these very large adventitious payments to it each year, one has simply to say that this kind of profit transfer from the Reserve Bank to the Consolidated Revenue Fund simply will not and cannot be sustained. Indeed, one does not have to believe me on this subject because the Reserve Bank has already pointed this out in its last annual report-that for 1986-87-which was published only last month and which has since been tabled.

So, in that and other ways, we are not even looking at an underlying deficit, an on-going deficit, or what sometimes used to be called a structural deficit-a phrase which, I might remark in passing, this Government was very fond of some years ago-of $1,027m. When this Government first came to office it was fond of talking about the structural deficit in the Budget. We do not hear much about that phrase these days. However, the fact of the matter is that the underlying, ongoing or, if you like, structural deficit in the Budget is, therefore, not merely $1,027m, as I suggested before one version of it might be, but at least that amount plus whatever adventitious element there is about the Reserve Bank profit transfer today. One may put that figure where one wishes, but most independent judges would put it at at least $1 1/2 billion more-$1 1/2 billion of the $2 1/2 billion profit transfer would not be likely to continue to recur.

In that case, we come-as I think Senator Chaney noted-to a figure for the real under- lying deficit in the Budget, not of a paltry $27m, but of $2,500m. So, let us have no more of this nonsense about the Budget being balanced, of the Treasurer going around the country beating his breast and telling everyone that he has done a fantastic job to bring the finances of this country into balance. He has done nothing of the kind and it is an empty, hollow and, I would even say, dishonest claim.

Let us take the next myth-the myth of expenditure restraint. On page 2 of his Budget Speech, the Treasurer has claimed that he has made a 2.4 per cent real reduction in Commonwealth spending. I very much regret to say that that claim is repeated in Statement No. 1 of the Budget Papers. There was a time when those Budget Papers had a certain claim to professional respectability and were not influenced or overridden by the political will of the Treasurer of the day. However, it appears from internal evidence that we can no longer expect that from some aspects of these papers.

Statement No. 1 in Budget Paper No. 1 repeats that false claim of a cut in real terms in outlays of 2.4 per cent. But again, as Senator Short brought out in a question to the Minister for Finance last week, the real truth is given not in Statement No. 1 but on page 61 of Statement No. 3, where, more honestly, it is revealed that, after allowance for the $1,000m of asset sales, the real reduction in outlays is not 2.4 per cent but 1.2 per cent. One might say nevertheless that the Government has succeeded in cutting its outlays by 1.2 per cent in real terms and that, after all, some would say, is some advance. However, I think the thing we always have to bear in mind with this Government is that what one sees is what one does not get. Here is another classic example of the same genre. We have a cut in payments to the States amounting to no less than 4.2 per cent in real terms. Having made that cut in that significant area of the Budget, we find when we examine the Government's own program-that is, expenditures by this Government on the Commonwealth's own programs; not the money it hands over to the States for their programs-that those payments have not been reduced one iota in real terms. They have risen very marginally, but let us say are unchanged in real terms. Where is the expenditure restraint? It is non-existent. As to the only programs that matter to these Ministers, namely their own, there has been no cut at all in spending.

The truth is that the feature of this Budget is not on the expenditure side but on the receipts side. The Budget estimates tax receipts rising by 8.5 per cent. That compares with an estimated rate of inflation-these are the Government's own figures-of 7 per cent for the year ahead and an increase in average weekly earnings of around 6 per cent in the year ahead. Against that, tax receipts are rising by 8.5 per cent, so the taxation burden is rising, not falling. It is worth noting in passing that if these estimates should prove to be correct, taxation revenues this year will amount to 24.5 per cent of gross domestic product, compared with a figure of only 23.1 per cent in this Government's first Budget in 1983-84. The tax burden, expressed not merely in absolute terms but as a proportion of the total national product, has risen throughout the life of this present Government. It hardly needs to be said that it is also greater than the proportion in the base year for the trilogy, 1984-85-the trilogy of promises by the Prime Minister in the 1984 election. But there is no need to refer to that because no-one expects this Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to keep his promises anyway.

Let us look, however, at where these tax receipts come from. Company taxes are estimated to be up by 14.3 per cent and the fringe benefits tax, which was in for only part of last year, up by 40 per cent. But receipts from individuals were up by 8.1 per cent. Where is this massive tax cut? The massive tax cut which the Treasurer and Prime Minister told us we were getting this year, and which the Budget Papers reveal is estimated to cost the revenue $4.480m in 1987-88, has resulted in no reduction whatever in the real burden of taxation. The reason is obvious to anybody who knows anything about our tax system-or so-called progressive tax system, our system of graduated and sharply rising rates cutting in at very low levels of income nowadays in a situation in which costs, that is to say, average incomes and prices, are rising sharply, and will continue to do so under the policies of this Government. We have had so-called bracket creep going on. To take the area of taxpayers whom I would have thought this Government would care most about, namely the PAYE taxpayers, the consequence is that they are estimated to pay 6.8 per cent more tax this year than they paid last year. Inflation is rising at 7 per cent, average weekly earnings at 6 per cent, and the real burden of taxation, depending on which indicator one chooses, is either unchanged or rising slightly. So much for the myth of the massive tax cuts.

Let us examine the myth that the Government is addressing our problems. The most important of those problems today is the level of Australia's international debts-debts owed by all Australians, governments, corporations and individuals. I remind the Senate of one or two figures in that regard. At 30 June last gross debts of Australians to foreigners amounted to $109 billion. Only four years ago, just after the present Government came to office, those debts were $35 billion. They have more than tripled in four years. Some people object to the use of gross debt figures and prefer to use net debt figures, which of course are arrived at by deducting from the ones I have just quoted any debts which foreigners owe to us, including those they owe to the Reserve Bank of Australia. Taking those figures, one finds that at 30 June last our net debts were only-I put that word in quotation marks-$83 billion. If one goes back four years to 30 June 1983, just after the present Government came to office, one finds that net debts at that time were only $21 billion. If one prefers the net debt basis, one finds that our net debts were not tripled but quadrupled. That is the mark of the performance of this Government in the four and a bit years it has been in office. It is that problem, and the serious problem of debt service to which it is leading, which this Government has run away from in this Budget.
On page 58 of Budget Statement No. 2-perhaps this escaped the Treasurer's eagle eye or that of his assiduous office staff-it is specifically stated that:
Australia's net external debt is likely to continue to rise faster than nominal GDP during 1987-88, and a further rise in the debt servicing ratio is expected.
For some members of our audience terms such as debt servicing ratio might be something of a mouthful. Let me say what that means.

TALK.START.PARA: —Address yourself to journalists.

—Yes, I thank the honourable senator. It is best thought of in terms of the burden which this Government's policies are bringing to bear for ourselves and our children in years to come. The debt servicing ratio is the proportion of our export income which has to be set aside first of all to meet the interest payments on our growing-still growing-external debts before we can spend a cent on buying imports. After all, the whole purpose of making exports is to be able to buy imports. We are continually depriving ourselves at an increasing rate of the capacity to buy imports with our export proceeds because we are continually having to set aside a greater and greater proportion of them to service our growing external debt.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past there have been occasions when Australia has incurred external debts. Indeed, it has been traditional throughout most of our history to incur a deficit on current account in the balance of payments which can be financed either by borrowing or by asset sales. I digress for a moment to suggest to the creative accountants who are in the employ of the Government or who are in the Government ranks that if they wish to subtract the proceeds of major assets sales from the expenditure side of the Budget to arrive at a better looking figure for the deficit, they might start to think of applying the same technique to the balance of payments. If we sell off the Regent Hotel or the Sheraton Hotel in Brisbane, why do we not subtract the proceeds of those major assets sales from our import costs on our balance of payments and come up with a better looking deficit figure? Would that not make our external creditors happier? Of course it would not, because they would see through it in the same way as the public can see through the shonky accounting produced by this Government for the purposes of arriving at its fictitious deficit figure.

In the past we have incurred current account deficits on the balance of payments and have paid for them either by borrowing or by sales of Australian assets, whether they be company shares or companies themselves or pieces of land or whatever. In passing, I would note that, although most of the debates on this terrible question of Australia's international indebtedness is about that very point, we should never lose sight of the fact that there are two ways of paying for a balance of payments deficit on current account. One is to borrow, which gives rise to indebtedness; the other is to sell Australia. Although until recently most of the financing of our current account deficits over the past few years has been effected in the former manner, that is by borrowing, there are increasing, and increasingly worrying, signs that more of our current account deficit is now being financed by selling Australia. Every weekend we pick up our newspapers and find that some new major asset has been sold to the Japanese, the New Zealanders or someone else. I do not blame any of these foreign investors and I am not in any way suggesting that they should not undertake these purchases. If our Government is so recreant to its responsibilities as to bring about the mess that we have in our balance of payments, which then has to be financed, and if, in the process of doing that, it allows our currency to fall so low in the stocks of the international world that someone can sell off his golf club membership in Tokyo and come here and buy a mansion on Sydney Harbour with the proceeds, then we only have ourselves to blame for re-electing a government that has produced that mess.

Let me again return to my point that in the past we have had balance of payments deficits and I suppose there has grown up some sort of conventional wisdom that as long as those deficits did not exceed something like 2 1/2 per cent of gross domestic product, they were in some sense sustainable. Of course they were sustain- able anyway only if that process of borrowing, or selling bits of Australia, to finance that deficit resulted in Australia acquiring productive assets which, in due time, could produce the exports to service the debt incurred or the dividends on the assets which had changed hands if that were the case. The terrible thing about the past few years is that nothing of the kind has been happening. In the late 1960s when, for a very brief time, our balance of payments deficit rose to about 5 1/2 per cent or 6 per cent of gross domestic product, we were having the greatest mining boom in Australia's history. We were building the great iron ore mines of Western Australia, the bauxite and alumina mines and smelter facilities. We were doing something at that time with the funds that we were borrowing or the proceeds of the assets we were otherwise disposing of to foreigners.

Even in that much criticised time of policy-and I criticised it to some extent-during the so-called resources investment boom, or resources boom as it was misleadingly called, of the late 1970s and early 1980s, with all the mistakes of that time, and there certainly were mistakes, a great deal of productive investment was put in place. To a large degree the great coal mines of Queensland were built at that time. Today Australia is the greatest single coal exporter in the world. At that time we produced the productive facilities to bring this about. Where would our balance of payments be today-God knows, it is in bad enough shape-without the coal exports which are the product of the investment at that time? Senator Walsh has not had the courtesy to listen to these remarks but, as he said the other day, it is true that in the late 1970s and early 1980s our balance of payments deficit rose to about 6 per cent of GDP. But we were doing something with it. We were not engaging in as much or as efficient productive investment as we should have been, but we were doing a great deal and today we are benefiting from the proceeds of having done so.

The really great criticism of the present Government in that regard is that in the past four years we have been like locusts eating the seed corn. We have simply been borrowing in order to maintain a standard of living in this country which, at our present levels of productivity-I emphasise that phrase because it is fundamental to the whole debate-we cannot sustain. We have been borrowing to maintain a standard of living; borrowing to consume, not to invest. If anyone wants proof of that he should look at the figures today for private business investment. These figures are, in total terms, only slightly higher today than the trough into which they fell during the 1982-83 recession which was brought on by the second wage explosion in 1981-82. Following that wage explosion the bottom fell out of a great many things in this country, including particularly the jobs of the members of the trade unions which had brought it about. The bottom did not fall out of the jobs of the trade union bosses, I should point out, but their members. At that time we saw private business investment sink and it has never significantly recovered. Taken as a whole, private business investment today is slightly above the trough which it reached at that time. In real terms, after adjustment for inflation, investment in plant and equipment is still below the level it reached at that time. Again, that is a mark of the achievement of this Government and the extent to which it has brought the Australian economy to a position where it is now turning the corner.

In the concluding minutes of these remarks I do not have time to pick up the fascinating comments by the Minister for Finance in Western Australia at the weekend whilst addressing the Society of Labor Lawyers. To my mind, that in itself is a term of total contradiction-to talk about people being lawyers and at the same time having political affiliations. But that is by the way. As has been reported-and perhaps it was because he was unaware that the Press was present-the Minister for Finance has done the nation a signal service by these remarks. I will not go out of my way to criticise him for them. On the contrary, I will go out of my way to congratulate and praise him for the contribution to national debate which he, and he alone, out of all the Ministers in this Government, has actually made.

In moving the amendment to this motion, Senator Chaney said that the most important thing that Australians face today is the need to be told the truth. That is the sense in which this Government is failing us most. It is also failing us in respect of actual policies but above all it is failing us in its failure to tell us the truth. In that respect I take this opportunity to say to Senator Walsh through you, Mr President-I regret that he is not here to hear me say it-that I admire what he did in Perth at the weekend. I appreciate what he said very much because he is entirely correct. This Government has squibbed it in the Budget; it has simply not addressed the issues of the size of big government in Canberra and the height of taxes to which the size of that Government in Canberra leads. The words Senator Walsh used or is reported to have used-he has not denied them-were that this Budget had been oversold and that it reflected a degree of complacency on the part of the Government which is simply not in any way attuned to the magnitude of the problems our country faces.
