TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the Senate for the first time as an Australian Democrat senator for Western Australia with a mingled sense of pride and humility. It is a great honour to be here and I thank the President and fellow senators for their courtesy and, in particular, the staff of Parliament House, at all levels, for their unfailing helpfulness. I also congratulate the other new senators on the content and delivery of their maiden speeches in this place. I am humbled by the awareness of the duties and responsibilities which lie ahead of me and I am proud to have been chosen by the Australian Democrats and the people of Western Australia to represent them. In particular, I thank my family, especially my husband Brian and my six children and step-children, Nicole, Sue, Evan, Jemma, Fraser and Enoch, and the friends and supporters who stood by me through the gruelling process which is democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: I had previously stood for public office as an Australian Democrat candidate four times-that is, for each parliamentary House for which I am eligible to stand. On each of those occasions I stood in what must be acknowledged to have been an unwinnable position. Why did I do this as a person with a rewarding professional career in technical and further education (TAFE), as a head of department at the Perth Technical College, as a person with a happy family life? What is it that time after time drives Australian Democrats to contest seats which are virtually unwinnable? I believe that the answer to that question is motivation and a desire for social justice. There are many concerns which simply cannot be ignored, and I am proud to be one of the army of Australian Democrats who have stood up and been counted in elections in recent years in a spirit of dogged determination.

In my case, I arrived in Australia as an immigrant in 1969 during the later stages of the Vietnam war, and I brought with me a commitment to peace which had led me to be part of the great swell of anti-war and anti-nuclear feeling which swept Europe and Britain at that time. My first political act in my new country was to protest at the Australian involvement in that terrible war in Vietnam, and I continue to oppose Australia's involvement in the global nuclear strategy of a foreign power-any foreign power. Western Australia is particularly abused by the positioning of foreign bases and by being repeatedly used as a berth for nuclear-powered and nuclear-armed ships of another nation and for the rest and recreation of the very large numbers of their service personnel.

There are few seekers of peace who are not also passionately concerned for the environment. I would like to quote Don Chipp, although many others have said it. He said that there is no point in saving the world if the world you are saving is not worth saving. Coming from Western Australia, I have a particular set of issues which are my concern.

I have given an undertaking to the Australian Conservation Foundation of Western Australia that I shall work closely with it on its conservation agenda. I refer to the mining of uranium in Rudall River National Park, the issue of woodchipping, which includes the conditions of licence and the role of the Australian Heritage Commission, and Shark Bay and the radioactive mineral sands dispute in the south-west of Western Australia.

As the solitary Democrat elected in Western Australia, I feel obliged to become involved in some of the issues where there is no parliamentarian at the State level who is prepared to stand alongside and speak up for concerned citizens. One such issue is the proposed new brickworks to be sited at Midland in the Swan Valley. Another is the proposed subdivision and development of 19 hectares of natural bushland still miraculously surviving within the boundaries of metropolitan Perth. Other current concerns of Western Australian citizens are the sodium cyanide plant to be sited at Kwinana just south of Perth, a polychlorinated byphenyl and toxic waste incinerator and even a nuclear waste disposal facility, destined perhaps for the Kalgoorlie area, and the synthetic rutile plant now operating at Geraldton, with devastating effects on the lungs of residents. I could go on, but observing the convention of not being overcontroversial in this my maiden speech, I shall just add that in Western Australia the connection between millionaire developers, the Western Australian Development Corporation and the State Government is indeed wondrous to behold.

Unfortunately, it is in the nature of governments and official experts to give false assurances to people concerned about their environment and their futures. Some four or five years ago, as a Western Australian State election candidate I participated in a multi-party symposium on multicultural affairs at the North Perth Town Hall. The quietest, most polite segment of the 500-strong audience was a group of migrants who had been sent to work at Wittenoom in the 1950s and 1960s and who had become afflicted with asbestosis. After the meeting, these tragic figures formed a circle around me and implored me to seek some official recognition of their plight. They had accepted that justice would be denied them until after their death. They had no reasonable hope of compensation for themselves. They were begging that the truth of their work-caused disability might simply be recognised and that some reparation might be extended to their families. These patient men with grey skin are etched indelibly on my memory. They had exhausted every avenue of communication with the Government and the Opposition of the time. They had been rejected and ignored by the politicians elected and paid to represent them. Successive governments were guilty, alongside the employing asbestos company, in dismissing medical advice which should have spared those workers their agonising fate.

Had honourable senators been there to see the expressions of pain and despair on the faces of those asbestosis sufferers, they would understand why the Democrats have maintained the principle of compassion and struggled for 10 years to give Australians a new kind of political party. We are not, as some have said, a temporary bloc of disaffected drop-outs from one or other of the bigger parties. Reason and compassion demand that at least some paid representatives turn their back on the blind forces of big capital and big unions and, as Senator Haines mentioned a short while ago, big corporate welfare. It appears that it is left to the Australian Democrats to speak up for disfranchised minorities.

In 1985, with my then colleague, Sue Paull, I was joint co-ordinator of a citizens' initiative action group, called the Castle Keepers. We waged a successful campaign to save the 1910 Perth Technical School building from demolition. In this campaign-a strictly one-issue campaign-supported by people of all political persuasions, ages and backgrounds, there was continuing evidence of backroom deals and improper procedures involving would be developers and government-backed organisations. This was not followed up by us. Our sole aim was to preserve the building for future generations of Western Australians. However, I was delighted to read in yesterday's edition of the Perth Sunday Times that a plan has been mooted to give members of the police force a three-month amnesty if evidence is given which leads to the charging and conviction of a corrupt colleague. How far could we extend this principle-to city and shire councils, to government corporations, perhaps to the Government itself?

My background is that I am a linguist and, since first living in Perth, in 1971, I have had close association both professionally and personally with non-English-speaking migrants. In 1981, as senior lecturer in languages at the Perth Technical College, I was responsible for setting up the first interpreter courses in Western Australia. I have also had considerable input into the national languages policy at State and Federal level. I therefore listened with pleasure to His Excellency the Governor-General speaking in this place when he stated:

The National Agenda for a Multicultural Australia . . . will give definition, direction and drive to the policy of multiculturalism. At the same time the Government's access and equity strategy will help ensure that Government services and programs are available fairly to all Australians.

His Excellency also stated that the Government is committed to a national policy on languages `which aims to ensure that all Australians master English, our common tongue'. It is my regret that this positive statement comes comes just a year after the Government dismantled the English as a second language program in government schools, passing the responsibility for this essential matter to the States, not all of which have picked up this responsibility-and Western Australia is one which has not. These cuts in funding for the schools' English as a second language program are both senselessly cruel and a false economy, as a glimpse backward can reveal.

Many people who came to Australia in the late 1940s and early 1950s during the period of heavy post-war immigration arrived here as children, speaking only their mother tongues. As this was the period of assimilation and integration, they were immediately placed in the classroom with native English speakers, and they just had to make the best of it.

Cio che questi bambini hanno sentito in classe sarebbe stato esattamente quello che questa frase in Italiano rappresenta per molte persone che mi stanno ascoltando al momento. E peggio ancora, perche classi in Inglese come Seconda Lingua erano quasi inesistenti nelle scuole allora, molti di questi bambini sfortunamente erano destinati a diventare semi-analfabeti in entrambi le due lingue.
These children did not have the advantage, which some honourable senators may now need, of a translation. I repeat in English what I have just said in Italian:
What these children heard in the classroom would have sounded just like what this sentence in Italian sounds to a lot of the people who are listening to me right now.

And what's worse, because English as a Second Language classes were virtually non-existent in schools at that time, sadly a lot of these children were destined to become adults who were semi-literate in two languages.
That is what I said in Italian. We must not reproduce that tragedy. English as a second language classes must be maintained in our schools, whether through the agents of Federal or State governments.

I worked in TAFE from 1972 until I was required to resign in order to stand as a candidate in the recent election-and that is another area that requires some examination. The funding for TAFE has been cut dramatically over the past few years. At the same time, the student demand for TAFE has risen equally dramatically. Where are the second chance people to go if their local technical college can no longer accommodate them? Short term skills training in the form of traineeships and other similar courses for those who have been unemployed for the requisite amount of time cannot replace the courses which must be curtailed because of cuts in TAFE funding. A lot of what we call education cannot slot readily into the category of employment or training. Courses in skills for the unemployed are necessary, but it must be realised that people who are `educated' in the real sense of the word make better employees and can be trained in skills more effectively.

As I said, I came to Australia as an immigrant, albeit an English-speaking one, and I am justly proud that this is a democracy and that all citizens have the opportunity to be educated, to be healthy and to take part in the political life of the country by voting, by joining or forming political groups and parties, by standing for public office and even by being able to be elected to this place without benefit of personal fortune, aristocratic parents or political influence.
`All power is a trust', said Benjamin Disraeli, `from the people and for the people'.

It is a political cliche that we have the best voting system in the world-the Hare-Clark system in Tasmania and the modified Hare-Clark system under which the Senate and the upper Houses in South Australia and New South Wales are elected. However, it is a pity that we still have governments in lower Houses elected by unrepresentative methods of single member seats. In my own State of Western Australia, we Democrats have campaigned for many years to remove a serious malapportionment in the State's upper House, and I can say with great pride and pleasure that the next State election in Western Australia will see the introduction of a form of proportional representation to the election of the Legislative Council, when the State will be divided into six multi-member electorates. I believe that the Australian Capital Territory would be well advised to select such a democratic system of electing its members when it is self-governing. Canberra itself has four discrete areas which, since the city planners sensibly followed natural boundaries, could provide four naturally distinct multi-member electorates.

Since 1949 the Senate has been elected by a system of proportional representation treating each State as a single multi-member electorate. This has had the effect of allowing into the Senate representatives of minority parties and Independents. It was made clear to us new senators during our orientation that it is because of the present composition of the Senate that it is now a genuine House of review. We were told to expect a higher level of debate than in the other place, and a concentration on the issues at hand rather than personal abuse. I am sure that, for the most part, that is true, and that it was not a Senate Whip to whom Don Chipp referred during his book launch yesterday when he described how one Whip used to tell newcomers to the Parliament:
Now that you are here you can forget all the--
`rubbish' is my euphemism for what Don actually said--
. . . you talked during your election campaign, about saving the world and helping mankind. Now that you're here, you will think, do, and most importantly, vote, as the Party tells you.

I am sure that none of my new colleagues were told that and that this chamber will remain a House which truly represents States' interests. However, having visited the new Parliament House, I am disturbed to see the concept of the Executive being set apart from the House of Representatives and the Senate. As stated by Perth journalist Peter Rees in the Western Mail two weeks ago:
The frightening symbolism of this is that the new Houses of Parliament will be simply an adjunct to executive government.

My very supportive running mate in the recent election, who was also my predecessor in this place as Western Australian Democrat senator, Jack Evans, suggested in an adjournment debate that democracy can function, and be expected to function, only if there is an educated electorate. Australian Democrats Leader, Janine Haines, made a similar observation during the recent election campaign, and stated that this means teaching young people how the system works, and teaching it in such a way that they are interested in what they are learning, so that they see how vitally important politics is to every aspect of their lives.

If democracy is to survive in Australia, then it must involve the people, not repel them. The people must be given the option of voting meaningfully for the party of their choice from a range of parties and individual candidates who represent the whole range of opinion in the electorate and in both Houses of Parliament-and they must know what they are doing. This, of course, demands of the government of the day a conscious policy of enlightenment. It demands also of the media in Australia that owners and editors raise their eyes from the account sheet and accept some measure of responsibility for the political process which they so freely criticise. Twenty years ago Don Chipp wrote that true democracy cannot survive without a free Press and electronic media, and he expressed unease about the concentration of Australian media ownership even then. He wrote:

It is safe to assume that Parliament in present circumstances is little protection for peoples' rights. The media seem to have given up hope of improving Parliament. The electorate is becoming inactive and less informed. . . .

It is perhaps surprising that Don Chipp expected the media to do any such thing as improve parliament, but he remembers a time when this was the case. The Australian Democrats have been in existence for 10 years-10 years of urging people to become vocal, critical and distrustful of the official experts. We have urged people to become involved, on the one hand, to resist the officially sanctioned monstrosities of so-called development and, on the other hand, to be staunch in the defence of our own civil liberties; to resist, on the one hand, the ugly racism which is the darker side of our multi-racial nation and, on the other, the Orwellian computerised society in which one's number becomes one's name.
I am proud to be here in this place as an Australian Democrats senator in this distinguished company, and I am proud and humble to be able to give what service I can to my State and my country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator McGauran, I remind honourable senators that this is his maiden speech. I would ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, in commencing my remarks I wish to extend my congratulations to you on your re-election to your distinguished office. As I rise to speak for the first time in this House I am conscious of the fact that I am the youngest senator in the chamber. It is appropriate then that I acknowledge the youngest senator ever to have been elected to this House, the Hon. Hattil Spencer Foll, elected to the Senate for Queensland in 1917 at the age of 27 years. Prior to taking up his commitment to public life, the honourable senator was distinguished by the military service he gave his country during the Great War. He served in one of Australia's most historic and well-remembered encounters: the Gallipoli landing of 25 April 1915. The Hon. Hattil Spencer Foll brought to public life not only the vision and vigour of youth but also a philosophy of courage and will for a country then fighting for its beliefs and freedoms. It was at this time that a foundation stone for traditional Australia was truly laid.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, as we prepare to enter our bicentennial year, it is a time to reflect on and reaffirm our belief in traditional Australia and in the wisdom of past Australians: the Aborigines, the convicts, the early settlers and, more recently, the immigrants of the post-war period. All these men and women have made us a country lucky in history and a people strong in will, with a fine spirit of mateship. If Australians should ever doubt the respect in which they are held in the world today, let them remember that in the east of France, in the quiet township of Amiens, one can enter a quiet and picturesque chapel dedicated to the Australian diggers who so gallantly defended their beliefs and fought for freedom not just for themselves but for all people in all places.

It would be a weakness if in the bicentennial year we do not stop to reflect on our traditional beliefs and be willing to defend them. Today, whether we live in city or country, we can all personally relate to the hardships of our pioneering ancestors. The effects on our natural environment of bushfires, drought and floods, the effects of economic hardship and the effects of the evil of war are all forces that threatened not only the economic survival but the very lives of so many Australians and their families. We do not have to look too far back in time to know the effects of these forces on the Australian character. I remind my fellow senators of the impact of the Ash Wednesday bushfires of 1983 upon the people of Victoria. It is those same harsh realities faced by past and present Australians that have allowed the qualities I have mentioned to be passed on through the generations to this moment in time. This should be the pride of our past and the foundation of our future.

I stand for traditional Australia and its belief in the family structure as a source of strength to a society which is presently sorely tested by an array of social pressures. I stand for an Australia which accepts the recognition in law and policy of the status of marriage and its preferred treatment. I stand for an Australia that wishes to reassert its long-held belief in small business and the farmer as the essence of free enterprise, which itself is the primary contributor to our economic welfare. Finally, I stand for traditional Australia's belief in the working man and woman's dignity of contribution to our economic welfare, with recognition in law and policy of their individual rights to work, fair payment and freedom of association. It is the family and small business, the working man and woman and the farmer, who are the real contributors to Australia. It is they who have been forgotten in this time of economic decline and economic change.
In addition, I reject the philosophy espoused by so many now in public office and best exemplified by Professor Manning Clark, who, when speaking of the late Justice Lionel Murphy, said:

. . . there was a man in Australia who believed passionately that the morality of Judaeo Christianity had ceased to be relevant. I see Lionel Murphy as a man who in that context strove to end the domination of God over human beings . . .

I say again that I not only reject this view but stand against it. I believe that at the heart of public service there resides a deeper sense of social responsibility than that statement lays claim to.

It is, then, for all those reasons that I take my position in the Senate with great honour. I recognise the true role of the Senate to be that of a House of review with the aim to protect the rights of States-rights that are enshrined in our Federal Constitution and which represent not an echo of a past age but which continue to provide the basis of a decentralised and responsive political and economic system.

Again, our past and its legacy are under siege. The Constitution is too often under attack by those who seek change for in vogue reasons or, more deviously still, to advance centralist objectives. But it is this Constitution that I respect, that I will defend and that I am committed to uphold. It is worthy to reflect that the wheels are now in motion to introduce major changes to our Constitution in the bicentennial year, the vehicle being the Constitutional Commission.

I stand by the powers of the Senate to review, pass or reject Supply or any such similar appropriation Bill as outlined in the context of section 53 of the Constitution. It is an authority given to the Senate in the Constitution under the democratic principle that a second House is needed to check, balance and review the conduct of the executive arm of government. This is common and fundamental to the past and continuing ideal of our Australian democratic system of government. I oppose such tired yet persistent attempts to reduce the important and traditional role of the Senate so clearly set down by our forefathers.

It is true that we live in a changing, turbulent period which has seen some change in our social values and a decline in our economic welfare. It is a time when all of us have questioned the future and asked what kind of Australia lies ahead. It was from this question of uncertainty as to our future that I received a clear and potent message as I travelled and campaigned in many parts of the great State of Victoria. This message of frustration and anger at the lack of leadership in public life emanated from the real contributors to Australia-the working man and woman, small business and the rural community. This class of Australians has in common the carrying of the greatest part of the burden of our economic ills. They are the first and most directly affected by high taxes, high inflation, high unemployment and high interest rates. It saddens me greatly that the entrepreneurial spirit that these people have generated might be lost if the Government is not determined in its resolve to lift the economic burdens it has placed upon these Australians. These Australians settled and built this tough continent with little more than a dream before them and determined hearts. Unless we rekindle that spirit-unless governments allow the great potential of all Australians to be unleashed, and unless they offer a greater recognition of their role-we can expect no more than the development of a corporate state led by central government control, corporate power and super-unions which will at best preside over a selective recovery for this nation.

Of the major economic issues facing Australia, I believe that the most important concerns this country's public indebtedness. The gross internal and external public sector debt now approaches $113 billion. This debt has a significant effect on all our economic indicators and on our economic climate. It is a debt based solely on the philosophy of big Government. It is a debt serviced by ever-increasing taxes and it is a major cause of high interest rates and high inflation.

This Government's Budget has done nothing to reduce the existing level of public indebtedness. Its inclusion of one-off asset sales and windfall profits in calculating its deficit for the year 1987-88 does not provide the basis for a sustainable reduction of the public sector debt; nor does the Government's Budget lift the burden of tax from Australians, who will be paying an extra $3 billion into the Government's coffers in the course of the coming year. Why should a person work hard to earn an extra few dollars if those dollars are grabbed by the Government in taxes? What incentive is there for enterprise and invention if that reward and risk is lost in interest payments? Again, there is nothing in this Government's Budget to lift private investment and to encourage restructuring beyond the sagging levels of the last financial year. What reason is there for families to save for the future if inflation, still unacceptably high relative to that of our trading partners, erodes that sacrifice and makes the search for security increasingly elusive?

Failure by governments to meet the test and reduce the size of government debt will mean an Australia lurching from crisis to crisis and gradually falling further behind on the scale of international economic success. One of the most disturbing factors of this massive debt is that today's generation is leaving the expense to future generations. We must never let short term political expediency allow us to impose a lasting debt on future generations. For their sake and for the sake of their future nation, governments must exercise self-discipline. This self-discipline by Parliament must be answered with a sense of leadership from all who serve. What is called for by the electorate is leadership-leadership which replaces political opportunism with integrity, leadership which replaces political careerism with courage and will, leadership which does not discard old loyalties for new favours, and leadership which will inspire the young and quicken their heartfelt dreams.

The final issue I wish to touch on in this my first speech to the Senate is that of organised crime in this country. Just as we have the responsibility to meet the economic challenges facing this Parliament in terms of its legacy to future generations and the need for leadership, so too do we have the utmost responsibility to promote leadership and to investigate and take measures to prevent the growth and perpetuation of crime in our society. Organised crime erodes the basic harmony and foundation of our lives. It undermines the public's confidence in its representative institutions and destroys the future of so many of our young Australians. I believe the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, despite its suspiciously premature termination by this Government, highlights evidence of a quite extraordinary network of organised crime in Australia that has not yet been subject to the most vigorous pursuit by every possible means. I acknowledge the fine work by the Costigan Commission in bringing such seedy ways to public notice.

The problem of attacking organised crime presents legitimate concerns to those of us who are defenders of civil liberties. Yet it must be remembered that the civil liberties of Australians are affected by the directions of the crime bosses. Both the United States of America and Italy have realised that a drastic problem demands a drastic solution, and both have taken legislative and common law measures to preserve the credibility and the sanctity of their social, economic and political systems. The United States Government has taken extraordinary steps in electronic surveillance in order to untangle the web of serious crime. Under the La Torre law, the Italian Government has assumed the urgent yet responsible task of vigorously investigating the mafiosi. With evidence mounting daily that Australia is being absorbed into the international crime networks, we need to avoid acting on the defensive and instead be prepared to seize the initiative.

In conclusion, as we prepare to enter our bicentennial year, I have a great hope that the traditions established by past Australians have given the generation which serves in this Parliament a firm foundation upon which we might seek to resolve the serious economic and social problems before us. I have the firmest conviction that the National Party of Australia has a continuing and major contribution to make to the growing demand by Australians for new visions and fresh leadership and to take us to new possibilities of economic reform, it has been the history of our Party to speak for those who have no voice, to remember those who are forgotten and to respond to the aspirations of all Australians seeking a better life in a better country. We have never forsaken this history, and we dare not. I seek to give full service to these ideals in my term in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Governor-General, in presenting the Government's program for the Thirty-fifth Parliament, said that the Government seeks to build `a more competitive and . . . a more compassionate Australian society'. Further on, under the heading `Education and Training', we were told that we must ensure `that we build an economy capable of prospering in an increasingly competitive world'. Taking these statements together, honourable senators will notice two things. Firstly, they present a self-fulfilling prediction. We must become more competitive. Presumably, most advanced Western economies are pursuing the same goal. Therefore, we must more rigidly condition, program or adapt-take your pick of which word you like-our young people to an increasingly competitive world. But this conditioning of the next generation is what is making the world more competitive. We are locking ourselves, our children and the following generation into a more cut-throat, competitive, devil take the hindmost society, and the Government presents that future to us as though it is inevitable-as though there is no other option. I believe, and the Australian Democrats believe, that there are other and better options.

Secondly, greater competitiveness and a more compassionate society are incompatible objectives. Even assuming for the moment that growth of gross national product means more material goodies to be shared around-something to which I shall return in more detail in a moment-when growth is only a few per cent per year competition is near enough to a zero sum game. More intense competition produces a widening gulf between winners and losers. This is indeed what we have seen in recent years. Between 1984 and 1986, under a Labor government, the number of Australians possessing more than $50m increased from 16 to 56, and their average wealth to $125m each. Meanwhile, the proportion of children living in poverty grew until it reached just over 20 per cent of the child population, and in absolute numbers almost 750,000.

Several myths surround this notion of material competitiveness being good, or at least sufficiently good that it should be a major guiding principle for government. It is said, for instance, that the exercise of competitive greed, guided by the invisible hand of the market, in some way serves the common good. There is no a priori reason why the exercise of competitive greed should serve the common good and there is abundant evidence that, in practice, it does not. Moreover, the notion of a balanced, self-correcting market is a mathematical absurdity. If ever a market got to such a state it would be at its most unstable. And again in practice what do we see? We see markets-if they can still be called markets-becoming stabilised when only one or a few players remain and gain control and when their main effort is directed towards minimising competition, often excluding it altogether. The terms `economic growth', `market', `market forces', `economic competitiveness' and `competition' should become pejoratives. Further promotion of the economic model of which these terms are the stock in trade is not compatible with a more compassionate society.

Competition for material gain, both within and between nations, generates conflict, not compassion. The companion of compassion is co-operation, not competition. The Australian Democrats seek a more co-operative and compassionate society. Competition for material gain has been and is an integral part of the economic model adopted and pursued by governments of both major parties. The principal goal toward which this model is directed is growth of gross national product. Indeed, so pervasive has this model become that growth of gross national product has become not just an economic goal but the national goal. The Australian Democrats adopted in 1977 a policy which rejected the growth model and supported a model variously known as a sustainable economy or a steady state economy. This is also the model espoused by the conservation movement. Its support by the Australian Democrats provided one of the main reasons I joined the Party I now represent. The growth economy locks people into an increasingly less human and humane society, a characteristic recognised by the economist Keynes. Writing in 1930, Keynes contemplated a day when growth would have made everyone rich. Then he said that we shall `once more value ends above means and prefer the good to the useful': He continued:

But beware, the time for all this is not yet. For at least another 100 years we must pretend to ourselves and to everyone that fair is foul and foul is fair; for foul is useful and fair is not. Avarice and usury and precaution must be our gods for a little longer still. For only they can lead us out of the tunnel of economic necessity into daylight.

That is a view rejected by the Australian Democrats for there are a number of other fundamental flaws in the growth model. It is to those that I now wish to turn. Gross national product is the dollar value of all goods and services made in a country in a year. It roughly parallels consumption. Making gross national products grow means making the dollar value of all goods and services consumed each year more than the dollar value of goods and services consumed in previous years after allowing for inflation. As growth is measured as a percentage, the growth being attempted is exponential. These are just some of the flaws in the growth model.

Firstly, the growth paradigm assumes infinite wants and infinite technological innovation to produce more and more people and goods-world without end. It assumes that this is not only possible but also desirable. Both assumptions can be shown to be false. Resources are not infinite, not least the capacity of the environment to cope with the damage which the growing economy generates.

Human activity is now changing the composition of the global atmosphere faster than at any time in the earth's long history and by a multitude of processes intimately woven throughout our industrial economy. The level of carbon dioxide is increasing by half a per cent per annum, nitrous oxide by 0.6 per cent per annum, methane by 1.1 per cent per annum and freons 11 and 12 by 5 per cent and 7 per cent per annum. Broadly, what we are doing is returning the atmosphere toward the composition it had before living things crawled out of the sea and were able to survive on dry land. Attempts to address these emerging problems are running into strong opposition from the protagonists of further growth.

Nor is continuing growth desired. If it were, it would not be necessary to spend increasing amounts on promotional advertising. It is obscene that we in Australia spend between $4 billion and $10 billion each year promoting greater material consumption, while thousands of our fellow passengers on spaceship earth suffer and die for the want of the use of some of these same resources.

Several populations have been repeatedly polled over the years as technical improvements increased output. The question `Would you rather take increased productive capacity as increased wages or increased leisure?' has been asked each time. Recent surveys in Denmark showed that well over half the population preferred increased leisure. This may have stopped economic growth if it had been allowed. But the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development advised the Danish Government that to get growth going again it should increase inequity in Denmark-a very precise example of greater weight being given to an economic index than to the wishes of people, and a further example of the close link between the conservative society and social justice and equity.
The second flaw in the growth model involves its peculiar system of accounting. Gross national product counts cost as benefits. The American economist Herman Daly puts this succinctly:

We take the real costs of increasing gross national product as measured by the defensive expenditures incurred to protect ourselves from the unwanted side effects of production and add these expenditures to gross national product rather than subtract them. We count the real costs as benefits-this is hypergrowthmania. Since the net benefit of growth can never be negative in this Alice-in-Wonderland accounting system, the rule becomes `grow forever', or at least until it kills you-and then count your funeral expenses as further growth. This is terminal hypergrowthmania. Is the water table falling? Dig deeper wells, build bigger pumps, and up goes gross national product! Mines depleted? Build more expensive refineries to process lower grade ores, and up goes gross national product! Soil depleted? Produce more fertiliser, et cetera, et cetera. As we press against the carrying capacity of our physical environment, these `extra effort' and defensive expenditures (which are really costs masquerading as benefits) loom larger and larger. This creates the illusion of becoming better off when in actuality we are becoming worse off. We may already have passed the point were the marginal cost of growth exceeds the marginal benefit.
How many of us have had the strong feeling, when told that the economy has grown by X per cent, that we are really no better off?

Thirdly, the growth model measures the throughput rather than the stock. In our personal lives we do not measure our well-being by how quickly we can spend our assets, nor do we equate it with the size of the effort required to maintain our physical lifestyle. Indeed, we quite sensibly seek to minimise the rate at which assets are consumed and effort expended. Why should we adopt the exactly opposite view when we contemplate the welfare of the nation? Consider for a moment a stock of physical goods-houses, cars, refrigerators-being maintained in a steady state, that is, a constant number, by maintenance throughput. That this maintenance throughput is a cost is clearly seen by looking at each end of the pipeline. Inputs necessitate depletion. Outputs necessitate pollution. Furthermore, the maintenance of the stock requires human labour, the sacrifice of leisure to production. To increase throughput for its own sake makes no sense. Seen in this light, gross national product becomes a largely irrelevant number, something to be minimised for a given stock and not maximised.

A fourth flaw in the growth model is that it is inconsistent with one of the most fundamental laws of physics-the second law of thermodynamics. For present purposes this may be read as the law of diminishing returns. Each increment of growth costs more than the last. Of course, in the fairy tale system of national accounting where costs are counted as benefits, the signals that the second law gives to stop are misread as encouragement to attempt to grow even more. I cite an example. There are many services, such as unpolluted air, which nature provides free. Because these services do not cost anything, they are not counted towards the gross national product. However, as these services are destroyed and we must pay dollars for their replacement, these dollars are counted as an addition to gross national product.

The role of women as mothers is a very important-perhaps the most important-role in our society, the nurturing of the next generation. Because women are not paid, their work is not counted towards gross national product. As we force more women into the work force and women are forced to pay for their nurturing role to be taken over by others, that amount of money is counted as an addition to gross national product. It should be asked whether we as a society are better off.

There is no a priori reason, nor any support whatsoever from science, why growth of gross national product should be accepted as a national goal. The growth model hangs in an intellectual vacuum unconnected with anything save its own corollaries. Arguments about growth conducted within the growth paradigm are tautological. A number of studies show that, as a measure of human welfare, gross national product is largely meaningless and frequently misleading. For example, in the late 1970s Morris Morris, an American sociologist, compared countries using an objective measure consisting of equal parts of infant mortality, literacy and longevity scaled from one to 100. In 1977 Saudi Arabia had a per capita gross national product of $3,529, while Sri Lanka had a per capita GNP of only $179. But on the quality of life index Saudi Arabia scored only 28 while Sri Lanka scored 82.

The Australian Democrats seek to put before the Australian people a better model: a sustainable or steady state economy. A sustainable economy is one in which the total stock of population and physical wealth is maintained at some desired level with a minimum throughput of both human and material resources. It is this minimum which must be sustainable in the long term. This steady state contrasts fundamentally with the growth mania model. The steady state seeks to maintain some generally desirable level of material welfare while using up the least resources. The growth model simply seeks to consume resources as fast as possible and mistakenly equates the speed of consumption with welfare.

The demands of the growth economy and the empty promise of trickle-down, to which Senator Haines referred earlier, have allowed us to put off facing the real question of equity: the sharing of stock, not just a fraction of the throughput. The adoption of this steady state will force us to stop begging the question of equity. The steady state will involve a slower flow of both human and material resources through the economy, less depletion, less labour required for maintenance, more leisure, less waste in the economy, less pollution, more durable longer life goods and human activity directed towards more durable ends. Finally, but most importantly, it will leave for our children and our children's children a living, interesting, self-sustaining environment which is an essential element in a fully human heritage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I sense that perhaps the period of calm and quiet associated with our courtesies to our maiden speakers may be over and we may be reverting to the norm. Before proceeding with the remainder of my speech, which was interrupted on the adjournment of the House on Friday evening, I remind the chamber of the essential principles which I had then outlined. I would like to take up the philosophical line of argument which my colleague Senator Coulter has just left with us. He was saying that we need to be careful about the future and that there are warning signs regarding environment and conservation matters which we must urgently attend to. I think in many respects the debate concerning the projected future with the Australia Card is of a similar nature. We need to be warned about the future and about the propositions which are being placed before us by the Government. On Friday I drew attention to the fact that I believe there is a myth about the facts associated with the Australia Card proposition. I do not think we have any facts before us; we have only a series of suggestions as to what the future may hold.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3] tells us the beginning of a story; it does not tell us the middle or the end of that story. We have an obligation to Australians of the future to try to capture the middle and, although it obviously will not have an end, the future. I challenge the Government to present us with any facts about what lies ahead in terms of this legislation. I believe it is acceptable for us to react at the subjective level. It is acceptable for us to ask questions about things in the future which are obviously totally subjective and cannot, by their very nature, be rendered objective.

I suggested that this Bill should be rejected on four grounds. First of all, it is unnecessary and never has been necessary. I outlined that it is not necessary to have an Australia Card to catch the tax avoiders and the welfare frauds, and I hope I substantiated that argument. Secondly, I suggested that I believe that the Bill is dangerous and destructive in that it will inherently push us across a critical line from a society which is fundamentally libertarian and free into one which will be essentially authoritarian. I cited examples of the authoritarianism of the Bill. The words `authority', `authorities' and `agencies' occur most throughout the 130 pages of the Bill.

On Saturday I was in my home city of Gosford at a rally concerning the ID card and somebody asked, `What happens if you do not want your photograph to appear on the proposed ID card?'. One of the lawyers located the appropriate paragraph in the Bill, and I quote it as an example of the way in which this piece of potential legislation is worded:

as to the making of a photograph of a person, if the issuing agency or the Authority is satisfied that the making of the photography may reasonably be expected to cause an unreasonable amount of distress to the person or to a member of the person's family.

In such circumstances a person is exempted from having a photograph taken. The key words, of course, are that the issuing agency or authority has to be satisfied of how somebody feels. I am not sure how it satisfies itself that this is reasonably distressing to an individual. Does it measure a person's pulse or take his blood pressure? How do the agencies and authorities that are given so much power in this Bill establish all these magical dimensions of what is out there in front of us. It is incredibly dangerous to propose that we should place ourselves in the hands of such agencies and authorities.

I mentioned that I believe this is inherently a dishonest Bill. It has been brought before us dishonestly through a double dissolution. It in fact suggests dishonest circumstances which will confront the average Australian. It implies that we in fact have a choice as to whether we want to be card carriers. Yet it states that if we choose not be card carriers we will be deprived of our access to employment and to resources and we will become worse than second class citizens. It suggests choice when in fact there is not choice at all.

My first three reasons for rejecting the Bill are, first, that it is totally unnecessary; secondly, that it is inherently dangerous in that it will change the whole Australian lifestyle, and it will render us an authoritarian society when in fact we are now predominantly a free and libertarian society; thirdly, it is dishonest in two respects; and fourthly, it is illogical. The very government which places this Bill before us today is the same very government that several months ago placed before us a Bill of Rights, albeit an inadequate Bill of Rights. The two Bills contradict one another in spirit. The Bill of Rights has been withdrawn because it was a shoddy piece of work and it was revealed to be inadequate. This Bill is an equally shoddy piece of work and it is now being revealed as such and reacted to by Australians in such a way that, hopefully, it also will be withdrawn.

Let us look at some of the other inconsistencies and illogicalities. The Bill stands in contradiction to another Bill enacted by this Government, the Freedom of Information Bill. It is so much in contradiction to that Bill that it is actually exempt from the provisions of that Bill. The Government says that people should have access to information, particularly about themselves. It concedes that, so through the Freedom of Information Act I could look at the records held in the Department of Defence about my service as an Army officer; yet I am not entitled, under the same Bill, to have access to information about myself. I believe that there is an inherent contradiction there. Let us suppose that I choose as a senator to be a non-card carrier and I find myself denied access to my savings. I believe that I could in fact challenge under the anti-discrimination legislation whether or not I should have access to my hard earned assets. I believe that in fact it would be difficult to untangle the inherent contradiction between this piece of legislation and anti-discrimination legislation. I contend that in fact this piece of legislation is logically inconsistent with legislation which has been brought before the Parliament by this Government and enacted.

I believe that not only are there legal and logical inconsistencies, but also there are philosophical inconsistencies. At a rally in Gosford on Saturday a gentleman stood up and asked a question of the Government representative. The honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) was asked, `Sir, when was the Eureka Stockade, what was it about and what was its outcome?'. It appeared that the question that he was posing at the time was extremely irrelevant. It was really only later that we realised that it was an absolute pearl; that in fact numerous exponents on the Government side of the chamber so often in so many rallies wave in front of us the flag of the Eureka Stockade. The truth is that the Eureka Stockade was an action in defence of civil liberties. It was in fact an action defending the right of individuals not to carry licences, not to carry pieces of paper. It was a reaction against authorities demanding to see those pieces of paper on frequent and unnecessary occasions. This was the occasion a little over 100 years ago on which we came closest in the history of our nation to civil war. In fact, it was virtually the same set of circumstances that now are being contrived by those who wave before us so frequently the symbol of freedom-the symbol of Eureka. I suggest that by doing so they are being philosophically inconsistent as well.

Another gentleman stood up at this rally and posed an interesting question. He asked: If, as we are told by the Government, the ratio of Australians in favour of the ID card is 60:40, why do we not see more people at these rallies crying out for the Australia Card than we see people denying and rejecting it? The fact is that the Australian people do not favour this proposition. The fact is that the statistics that have been obtained through recent surveys, indicating 80 per cent rejection, are nearer the truth. The fact is that the people who voted for this Government are embarrassed by the proposition. They are not prepared to come out in large numbers to defend it. The fact is that the Minister responsible, the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan), is not going through the process of calling rallies in support of this concept because the Government knows that it has no public support.

In conclusion, I cite the extraordinary contradiction that I referred to in my maiden speech of the situation in Australia where everybody in this chamber can go to a special place called a Totaliser Agency Board, pull down off the wall a piece of paper and express his opinion about the most irrelevant garbage, about what will win the third race at Randwick on Saturday. That sampling of opinion is processed by the most sophisticated computer in the land and the results are displayed on every television screen at night. Yet we cannot have a say in a referendum about whether we want an Australia Card.

TALK.START.PARA: —We just had it.

—Rubbish, we did not have it. We cannot have a say about whether we want a new Australian flag or nuclear ships in our harbours because this Government in fact does not have a commitment to democracy. It has a commitment to autocracy and that commitment is embodied most profoundly in this Bill. The Government has conned the Australian people into the deception that they had such democracy at the recent poll.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment before the chamber today relates to the referral of the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3] to a Senate select committee. One might wonder at first blush why that might be necessary after the extraordinary campaign of silence by the Government on the one hand and the extraordinarily effective campaign by its vast multitude of opponents on the other. But the answer is that the Government has nonetheless chosen to ignore what is clearly a massive shift in public opinion and a demonstrated range of concerns and wishes to proceed with this iniquitous legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment, therefore, is that the Bill be referred to a committee. We should bear in mind that no such Bill has previously been examined by any parliamentary committee. It is simply a proposal in vacuo. The committee will be asked to examine something of the order of 11 new areas of concern and all Australians will need very satisfactory answers to each of them. It is probably instructive that even the Deputy Prime Minister, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), perhaps in speaking off the cuff at the weekend, indicated that if the Senate were to come up with a more satisfactory alternative the Government would listen. That is the first chink we have had in the armour at the top but it is certainly not the first chink we have had in the armoury of Labor Premiers and acolytes around the nation because there is not a Premier who will speak in support of the card.

All we have had in recent days is that champion of civil liberties, David Lange, weighing in, lending his support, so-called, to the Government proposal on the most specious of grounds-a most simplistic and dishonest justification which was trotted out several years ago and which has been utterly discredited since then. In other words, the original justification for such a draconian proposal was that it would somehow eliminate welfare cheating and somehow catch up with tax avoidance and evasion. The answer to that is now quite clear: it will do nothing of the sort.

We have had an intensive investigation mounted by a joint select committee which very critically and carefully examined those very areas. It is probably worth noting that that committee had the benefit of advice from the two major departments which are in a position to understand these concerns and give advice on the best method of dealing with them. What did the Australian Taxation Office say in its submission to the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card? It said that it favoured increasing the integrity of the present system. It was on that basis that the Committee came up with its recommendation-a majority recommendation, it might be said-that the taxation identification number which currently applies to all citizens should be used as a method of detecting tax evasion and avoidance.

The real problem in the taxation area is the black economy. If one is not prepared to have a broad based consumption tax, that great panacea which so attracted the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the wake of the Tax Summit but which ultimately was thrown out of the window, if one is not prepared to have something that ensures to a considerable extent that there are not large numbers of people making black profits, using black money and paying virtually no tax, one is left with proposals that are very much second best alternatives. However, the Australia Card will do nothing to catch up with any form of cash economy. People will still continue to pay the gardener in cash, to pay for home duties in cash and perhaps to engage more in the barter system then they have to date. However, there is no way in which all those myriad personal transactions are somehow going to be detected or overridden or that people will be frightened off simply because there is this draconian legislation with all those massive penalties attaching to it. No, people are not going to be deterred in that way. They will simply vote with their feet, they will vote with their pockets and they will continue to do what they have always done. We can decry that but to the extent that it is a function of a personal income tax system that is too oppressive, the answer lies in re-forming that system. It does not lie in introducing a Big Brother surveillance technique that is meant to detect all the minor transactions and to blow them up into cases of high treason against the State. One might think that the onus of proof will be reversed and that we will all be required to disclose any peccadilloes.

An examination of the legislation would suggest innumerable grounds for concern on a civil liberties basis. For instance, the range of fines bears examination. If a person fails to report loss of an ID card within 21 days, the penalty is a mere $5,000. That is chicken-feed because the bulk of this legislation has penalties of $5,000 to $20,000. If the Tax Office wants to see one's card and one refuses to hand it over, the fine is $20,000. A person can be compelled to attend a compulsory conference. The significance of that is that if the State Premiers go along with the approach they have taken to date-perhaps the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) would merely call it pusillanimous, but others might say that they are displaying more integrity than their Federal colleagues-what will happen if the State Premiers refuse to co-operate? It is clear that they have refused to date, because the South Australian Legislative Council was recently invited to vote in support of this proposition, and the Labor Government declined to do so. The Victorian Legislative Council similarly was asked to make its births, deaths and marriages register available to the Federal Government in due course, but the Government refused to support the Liberal Opposition, which said that the register should not be made available.

It is clear that State Premiers are sitting on the fence. But let us say that they have the courage of their convictions and ultimately decline to make those records available. What recourse will the Government have? Under clause 74 of the Bill to date the Federal Government or the Health Insurance Commission, the card authority, is entitled to record all manner of personal information obtained by means of registers made available to them or otherwise. If it is able to obtain information from the Australian Federal Police, the National Crime Authority, a range of lower level institutions and organisations, it can compel attendance at a conference to verify the accuracy of that information. If that is not the greatest invasion and intrusion into privacy, I do not know what is. But the Government could go down that path because the legislation allows the use of information obtained from the registers or otherwise. It does not say `legally obtained'; it simply says `or otherwise'-in other words, by any means possible. Is that not an open invitation to circumvent the law or to take advantage of material that might be provided by the bloke over the fence who wants to blow the whistle on a neighbour for having a second job, or by others who are dissatisfied at what they think is welfare bludging? One must bear in mind that there is a lot of this whistle blowing going on.

Before the Committee of which Senator Puplick was a member was set up, I remember reading that the Department of Social Security was concerned about what it called Saturday night concerns. Obviously people got together in the pub and thought they knew people who were cheating on the system. They would ring the Taxation Office on Monday morning and the office would have to investigate those people. What was the result of those investigations? The result was that the figure of 72 per cent of people alleged by outsiders to have been illegally obtaining unemployment benefits was found to be unsubstantiated. In other words, there was a massive mythology that had grown up around a range of welfare benefits. There are people who improperly, as it turns out, provide information to the authorities.

What is there to stop the Taxation Office saying, `We have to be careful about this. We cannot just act on the say-so of some disgruntled citizen. What we will do is to call Puplick in and ask whether he is working two jobs or three. We will ask him whether he has been disclosing the income, we will ask him how long he has been doing this sort of work and will verify the accuracy of the information. Having done that, we can rest assured that it can go on our national register.' That is what the legislation allows at present. If one fails to attend a compulsory conference, one can be liable to penalties from $5,000 to $20,000. If an employer fails to see one's identification card, he can be liable for penalties of $20,000. This might be felt to be somewhat cute, but I would point out that the legislation imposes no penalties on the government. In fact, the Government goes through this elaborate charade of saying that cards are not compulsorily required; they could simply be asked for. But they have got to be asked for by employers and a whole range of other agencies under pain of paying very large penalties.

The onus is put on honest citizens and organisations to do the Government's dirty work for it. If they do not, they will pay the penalty. If stockbrokers, bankers, accountants, lawyers, real estate agents fail to record an identification card number after each and every financial transaction, they cop it in the neck with fines of up to $20,000. The Government is having all this surveillance work undertaken for it free of charge by people who can pay massive penalties if they fail to co-operate in a so-called voluntary scheme. It is fair to say that if the legislation is supposed to have the support of the community, it should not need to impose those sorts of financial penalties on ordinary law-abiding citizens.

The civil liberties and privacy aspects are at the forefront of the debate and have brought out of the woodwork a whole range of strange bedfellows-ones who, for various reasons, were unprepared to voice their concerns in public prior to the election. No doubt that occurred because many well-intentioned and honourable card-carrying members of the Australian Labor Party did not want to see the Party embarrassed by the truth before the election. We have had card-carrying members of the ALP in this very chamber who have found themselves compelled to disown their own honest statements. Undoubtedly there will be more of them who will go around wringing their hands in private saying how shocking and how horrible this is. They will say, `Do not misunderstand my personal position, my friend on the other side, because I personally am against it and so is my faction, but I am sure you understand the rules of the game and that we cannot say that in public. When it comes to a vote in the chamber, we will not be able to voice our opposition'. What sort of situation is that? It probably reflects very poorly on the political party that imposes that sort of iron law of politics on its members. It is interesting that it would not contemplate a conscience vote on an issue such as this when its own members regard this as one of the ultimate conscience issues.

My colleague Senator Puplick rightly said that one of the criticisms that other factional groupings in the ALP would have of their left colleagues is that sometimes they are guilty of a propensity for telling the truth. Large numbers of them have told the truth to their colleagues, to community groups and occasionally to the media, but they will not be telling that form of truth where it counts in this Parliament. They will not be indicating the extent of their concern in the proper and constitutional manner by voting against it. It is clear that such security concerns are not fatuous or unreal.

Senator Ryan would wish privacy concerns away. She would claim that there will be compliance and that dedicated landlines will be unable to be broken into. We all know, as I am sure the community well understands, that it is one thing to compel people to honour a system; it is another to enforce it. It can be said if that there were a whole set of safety requirements in aviation, if rigid standards were imposed and policed efficiently, and if those requirements were complied with on every occasion, no plane would ever fall to the ground. But that happens and tragedies of massive proportions occur, in many instances because of human error. There is no reason why human nature will not take its course in this area, too. It does not just stop there. People for their own reasons will be disgruntled with former employers, the Health Insurance Commission or otherwise, and they will have all sorts of reasons for wanting to embarrass the Government, for wanting to tip the bucket on colleagues or on ordinary law-abiding members of the community. One simply cannot guarantee the integrity of that data. One simply cannot ensure that there will not be sabotage taking place within government instrumentalities. One cannot be sure that for all sorts of reasons people will not plant devices in the so-called protected data protection area that will blow the whole scheme apart.

It is clear that there are very many reasons why we should have concerns about privacy and I do not need to traverse the ground that has been well harrowed before in relation to the McGoldrick case where records of young girls who had had abortions were made available to the Australian Federal Police so that prosecutions could be launched. Not an eyelid has been batted, no explanation and no apology have been given by the authorities. I suppose that they would say that the end justified the means. Why were the records of doctors made available to the Sydney Morning Herald in the course of an industrial dispute? It was to try to embarrass those doctors, to try to frighten them off somehow so that they would capitulate. Again, the end justified the means. How can we be sure that that will not happen again? The simple answer is that we cannot. We should never take the word of any government that says that it can be sure. Senator Ryan wanders around making vacuous threats about large penalties which we know will do nothing to deter people who are in the business of leaking information, accidentally or deliberately. The Crimes Act is supposed to stop people from leaking to the media, yet leaking is probably one of the few growth industries under this Government. It will be ever thus. The fact of heavy penalties in the Crimes Act does nothing to deter leaking, nor will the sorts of penalty regimes in this Bill do anything to stop that sort of conduct, of which we have two classic examples to date.

I turn to the question of costs because that is obviously one of the matters that drives this Prime Minister. He thinks that somehow at the end of the day if he can coerce and cajole his colleagues into passing a highly unpopular and intrusive piece of legislation, there will be a pot of gold at the end of the rainbow and that his Government will be able to deliver tax cuts because this legislation will recoup massive amounts of revenue for the Government. All these tax cheats and welfare frauds-people who are presumably the traditional Labor Party constituency-will be caught red-handed in their thousands and forced to disgorge their ill-gotten gains. As a result the Government will have an abundance of riches and it will be able to hand on these wonderful and illusory tax cuts which we saw last July.

This legislation will cost about $750m in start-up costs. It will require the employment of some 2,000 additional public servants. The cost to banking alone will be $100m to $300m. The cost to the private sector in general cannot be determined, but the Confederation of Australian Industry thinks it will be about $377m. I wonder whether honourable senators know why we cannot be more precise. The material is available. The Business Regulation Review Unit has looked into this matter very carefully and it provided a report to the Government some 18 months ago. Where is that report? It will not be tabled, disclosed or released. Despite a freedom of information application made by Mr James Porter, the Government has been consistently stalling. It has provided all manner of irrelevant material but on the crucial issue it has refused to hand over that report. On what basis? It comments on a co-ordination submission to Cabinet and by definition that is supposed to mean that it is a Cabinet document. One does not have to be a flash lawyer to see that that is a fairly large leap of logic. In other words, the Government is putting up the shutters for as long as possible because it does not want the community to know the full extent of the cost of this intrusive and divisive legislation.

It is clear that there are mammoth costs that will not be justified in recoupment. More importantly, when this idea was first proposed it was thought that somehow it would do magic things to catch all sorts of moneys that were not being handed over within the tax system. But it is worth remembering that at long last the Australian Taxation Office has undergone a fundamental upgrading of its resources-$700m of computer systems have belatedly been installed. After many years of turning blind eyes to bottom of the harbour schemes, Slutzkin schemes and the like, the Tax Office has decided to get down to business and has engaged in a fairly professional series of spot audits and all manner of measures to frighten the daylights out of taxpayers in order to ensure that this sort of money is no longer able to be avoided and evaded.

The Auditor-General had some fairly terse things to say about the effectiveness and efficiency of the Tax Office. After a number of audit investigations he made it very clear that he was dissatisfied with its performance. Whereas the Government claims that large revenue gain will derive from this legislation, the Auditor-General, who conducted five efficiency reports, estimated that the amount of tax revenue forgone because of undisclosed dividends and interest income was in the range of $300m to $500m per annum. He went on to say that the non-disclosure arose because of two fundamental problems-lack of information and inadequate matching capabilities. The Tax Office claims that only 18 to 20 per cent of all interest paid is reported. Of that amount only 50 per cent is successfully matched. The Auditor-General claimed that if the Taxation Office had adopted a more active approach-proactive instead of reactive-to demanding more information from financial institutions, in particular trading and savings banks, the appropriate information should have been more readily available. The Tax Office lacked the necessary capacity to process and it had not had sufficient resources. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure was astounded that the Tax Office had persevered for so long with a labour intensive approach when funding for automatic data processing acquisitions had been so significantly underspent over recent years.

The Tax Office is getting its act together at long last. As a result we are seeing a whole range of additional revenue that the Government had not even budgeted for, be it $535m from fringe benefits tax or large dollops of capital gains tax as a result of a share market boom which is largely artificial. People are not prepared to sell their shares at the moment because they bought them before September 1985. As a result the Government will get even more revenue from the more efficient methods that are being adopted by the Tax Office. The gains that one could project from the Australia Card legislation will be largely illusory. Therefore, one should have the greatest of concerns about the effectiveness of that approach.

The Australia Card will do absolutely nothing in the area of organised crime. The Australian Federal Police, Mr Costigan, QC, and Mr Doug Meagher, QC, are in heated agreement that the cash economy will continue and that organised crime will thumb its nose at this type of legislation. One does not have to be in the business of forging cards but we know that some 20,000 false Medicare cards exist. It is estimated that it would be just as simple to forge cards in this area if one were in the business of doing so. People in organised crime, if they turned their minds to it, would have no difficulty at all.
I will read the recommendation of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card. It sums up the fundamental concerns that we have in this area. It reads:

The majority believes the creation of a new bureaucracy of 2,000 public servants within the Health Insurance Commission, with the sole task of identifying every man, woman and child in Australia, is a wasteful exercise which will not address the problems of tax evasion and social security fraud but will provide the mechanism by which the very fabric of our society will be irreversibly altered, opening the way for the greatest attack on the privacy of individuals as the `Identity Bureau' identifies, monitors and updates information on every person-
or should I say `card subject'-
in Australia.

If that is not the most sweeping and comprehensive damnation of this scheme, I do not know what is. That was the considered finding of a committee that took evidence from a large number of well-informed people. It did not have the benefit of overseas experience but I am sure that in due course when we have people such as the former head of the data protection agency in Sweden, who was prepared, no doubt, to make known to the Australian community why the system has been such an unmitigated disaster in Sweden, we will have an even more widespread body of informed opinion able to rail against this card.

Whether one looks at the costs, revenue gains, the ability to deter organised crime, the invasion of privacy, the draconian penalties or the ability to catch up with welfare cheats, this legislation is found wanting on every score. One would have thought that Mr Keating's new culture of compliance would be another potent argument why this legislation is already out of date and will not achieve its purpose. He would have us believe that we are now an honest tax paying society, which is why he has been awash with funds and able to deliver an illusory balanced Budget. One cannot have it both ways. If he is right, there will not be too many more loopholes to be plugged and revenue detected by this identity card.

The Department of Social Security gave evidence to the Joint Select Committee on the Australia Card that one per cent of social security fraud involved false identity. We already know that the Government is calling in 104,000 long-term unemployed to put them through the wringer to make them explain-no doubt with the onus of proof on them-why they should continue to receive unemployment benefits and, if necessary, social security benefits. Undoubtedly, those sorts of actions will result in an increase in revenue and a decrease in welfare fraud, but they do not require an Australia Card.

The Joint Select Committee reported that an Australia Card would do nothing to deter illegal immigration. My colleague, Alan Cadman, the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, recently pointed out yet another mess of deficiency in the legislation. He said that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs had confirmed that officers of his Department would be unable to ask suspected illegal immigrants to produce their ID cards. In fact, if they did, they would face fines of $5,000 or gaol. However, employers who unwittingly engage the services of an illegal immigrant can be fined up to $20,000 if they fail to require the production of the card. Again, this is a classic example of employers being asked to bear the brunt, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs standing by, wringing its hands and not being able to do anything about it and, in the meantime, illegal immigrants being entitled to carry on as they have to date.

Any compulsory identifying numbers system which will bring together information in a manner never contemplated or achieved in any other civilised country can be justified only if it meets all the necessary criteria which were found to be wanting by the Select Committee. In other words, such a system would be justified only if it were effective in dealing with tax evasion and avoidance-it is not. Such a system would have to be effective in preventing welfare fraud-it will not. It must have an impact on the level of illegal immigration in Australia-it will not. It must provide adequate privacy safeguards-it will not. The proposals must be cost effective-they are not.

On every count it can be seen that this legislation is nothing more than an ideological vendetta, a misguided notion on the part of the Prime Minister, with precious support from others in the Government, to impose a fool's pot of gold on the Australian community.
