In mindlessly chasing some additional revenue down the track, the Government is determined to perpetrate a massive invasion on civil liberties and a massive and unnecessary exercise in enlarging the size of the public sector, in threatening invasions on personal privacy on a scale never before contemplated here or elsewhere and in imposing massive personal inconvenience on large numbers of Australians and huge and unnecessary costs on the private sector and ordinary taxpayers-all for the sake of a crusade which is entirely unjustified and will do nothing to address the real economic issues in Australia.

If we are intent on turning this country around and seriously want to address the current account deficit, which will still be about 4 per cent of gross domestic product-$11.6 billion a year-and to lower the gross foreign debt of $109 billion, we must become more efficient and productive, by encouraging a culture of productivity, not one of invasion and intrusion and of wanting to look over peoples' shoulders to ensure that they are not somehow cheating on the system. The way ahead is not to have an Australia Card. It is to have a commitment to working harder and smarter. The last thing that this card will do is unite Australians behind that sort of worthwhile and constructive approach to right the wrongs of the economy. Instead, it will divide Australians in a way they have never been divided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It falls to my happy lot to speak after that extraordinary contribution by Senator Alston, who managed to smear the integrity of just about every Commonwealth department. No doubt, I shall have the opportunity in my speech to pick up some of those points.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us be clear why we are debating, for the third time, the Australia Card Bill. It is because the legislation was twice rejected in the Senate. That was the reason for the double dissolution. It has been necessary to submit that legislation for the third time to the House of Representatives, where it has been passed, and the Senate. If it is passed in the Senate, there will be no need for a joint House sitting. On the evidence from the Opposition, it seems clear that the legislation will be defeated in the Senate. Opposition senators are intent not only on defeating it but on passing a staying motion and referring the legislation to a further inquiry, despite the comprehensive inquiry into this whole matter by the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card. It is edifying to read what Opposition senators said during that inquiry. A deferral motion, instead of outright opposition, is a particularly curious ploy by the Opposition. Is the Opposition or is it not intent on defeating this legislation? That is not clear. If the Opposition is, why move amendments to provide for yet another inquiry into something that has been so comprehensively debated and considered?

The Opposition has sometimes said that the Government is not dedicated to introducing this legislation and that it did not raise the matter much during the election campaign. Of course, like almost everything else the Opposition says, that is false. The Government made it clear that the Australia Card was the issue about which it was going to the people, along with any number of other issues. It was included in the Government's advertisement material. Indeed, the first advertisement placed by the Government referred to the Australia Card.
It is important to quote from the second reading speech of the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan), who said:
It is the clarity with which a government makes its future intentions clear, not the extent of the debate, that is the crucial issue in mandate theory.

The Government's intention is clear. The legislation will be passed. If one wants to argue that the debate has not been extensive, one only need read through Hansard, particularly Senate Hansard before the election. Honourable senators and honourable members have been asked many questions on the issue. I have spent much time talking about it to people with queries at various community meetings in South Australia. I am sure that the same is true of most of my parliamentary colleagues in Government. I suspect that the Opposition has been talking, too, judging from the organised campaign with which we must now deal.

Why did the Opposition not raise the issue often during the recent election campaign? It is easy enough to kick the Government. I am happy to redress that imbalance by suggesting that one reason why the issue was not raised too much during the election campaign was that the Opposition was running scared. In a report on Thursday 20 August 1987 the Australian Financial Review stated:

According to Liberal sources, the Opposition did not campaign strongly against the ID cards in the last election, mainly because market research showed 64 per cent of the electorate were in favour of the cards and it was judged too difficult to turn around during the election campaign.

On the Opposition's head be it. Now that honourable senators opposite are happily in Opposition, they have something to do with their time-is that what I can judge from this? It was too hard during the election campaign. They lost so, as a filler, they will now get back to the issue.

The Opposition's intentions are curious. It is fuddled and muddled about what the argument is. The Opposition is not clear whether it wants to oppose the legislation or to inquire into it further. The Opposition is not clear about how the legislation will work or the card's intention. If one listened to Senator Alston one would think that we were bound on the most divisive campaign that ever was. One would also understand that it is a process of defaming government departments-almost every one of them, according to him. I think that is part of the misinformation and mischief that are characteristic of the Opposition's position in this debate, as they were in the previous two debates. Nothing new is being offered from the Opposition in justification for defeating this legislation for the third time.

I think it is important for anybody listening to this debate to understand that the Hawke Government has been absolutely consistent on the Australia Card; it is the Opposition that has made a complete somersault. I shall quote two earlier statements from the Opposition. A media release dated 5 June 1985, by the Hon. Ralph Hunt, then Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, said:
The proposed national identification system offered dual benefits to the Australian people . . .

The use of plastic cards for an effective means of identification would streamline the collection of tax revenue, imposing a greater accountability on that small minority of taxpayers who sought to evade their responsibilities to the community . . .
The second major benefit would be to cut down on fraud affecting Government outlays, especially social welfare payments . . .
I will be making representations to the government strongly supporting this aspect of the `White Paper' proposals.
A media release of 8 June 1985 by Mr Charles Blunt, the honourable member for Richmond and at that point shadow Minister for social security, stated:
The introduction of a national identification system, using ID cards, offered benefits to the Australian people, which outweighed any civil liberties considerations.

The use of plastic cards as a means of identification would streamline the collection of tax revenue, imposing greater accountability on that small minority who seek to evade their responsibilities to the community by not paying taxes.
Another major benefit would be a reduction of fraud affecting Government outlays, especially social welfare payments . . .
The introduction of an ID system should require people to quote the same identity number to both the Tax Office and the Social Security Department.

That was the view of two members of the Opposition in 1985. Subsequently they sort of had that view and sort of did not. To elaborate further, somewhere between November 1985 and November 1986 the Opposition switched from an ID card approach to favouring an alternative identification number system, that is, an expanded tax file number. Charles Blunt, James Porter and Senator Chris Puplick all signed the majority report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, which supported the introduction of an upgraded tax file number identification system for tax and social security purposes. This is the only substantive point on which the majority and the minority reports disagreed-that actual form of the identification system rather than whether or not there should be one.

More recently, however, the Opposition has apparently abandoned its support for either the Australia Card or the tax file number system. The Opposition dumped Senator Puplick, the then Opposition spokesman on health-James Porter-and Charles Blunt, who had all supported the tax file number system. The tax file numbering proposal was dumped despite recommendations supported by Senator Puplick, Mr Porter and Mr Blunt and despite the recommendations of the all party report which said:

. . . with or without the adoption of the Australia Card the Australian Taxation Office take the necessary steps to establish a high integrity identification system which would ensure maximum taxpayer compliance.

In the last debate on this matter the Opposition opposed an amendment by the Australian Democrats to introduce a tax file number identification system-the very thing the Opposition had opted for only a couple of months previously. I wonder just how cynical one can get. The Opposition has modified its position. It has moved from being all in favour of an ID system to being in favour of a tax identification number system, and is now totally opposed to either. We know what Opposition members really believe. They believe that it is an excellent idea. They say, `Let us object to it while the Government gets it in place', hoping that they will one day be in government to reap the benefits. On this performance, they should never make the Government benches.

Mr Howard is another whose view of this whole proposal has changed a great deal. It was reported in an AM interview that Mr Howard had instituted an inquiry into the investigation of an ID system as early as 31 May 1979. The report said further that Mr Howard wrote that an interdepartmental committee under the auspices of the Public Service Board had been established to report on an identity card system and that the committee at one stage went overseas to collect information. The interview progressed and Mr Howard was asked whether that was true. He said, yes, it was true, and that the investigation has started. When asked what had changed, Mr Howard said, `I don't have that view now'. When asked why not, he said that the first reason was the enormous invasion of privacy, the second was that the savings and advantages were not great, and the third and most important was its cost. He said that it would mean 2,000 extra public servants and a $2 billion extra cost on small business. As I said in my speech in the earlier debate on 1 April 1987, on all three of those points Mr Howard was wrong. On all three of those points the Opposition is wrong. On all three of those points the campaign against the Australia Card is wrong and is based on misinformation and, of recent times, a very coherent campaign of fear-mongering.

I would like at this point to take up the invasion of privacy issue. What will the Australia Card do? The Australia Card will require that a person be identified with the Australia Card, which will have on it a photograph, a name, a number and a signature. It will be supported by the information in the Australia Card Register on date of birth, sex, private address, work address and other names under which a person may wish to operate, as in the classic case of many married women who would like to continue their current practice of using two different identifications-that is, their maiden name and their married name-for the purposes of their work and their private lives. Both of those names would be kept but the identification number for those people would be the same, under whichever name they operated.

One of the most important scare tactics being employed is the suggestion that the Australia Card will allow a dossier to be collected on people. Let me say very clearly that there will be no dossier collection under the Australia Card. There will be no amalgamation of information into one central computer. Tax information will stay with the Australian Taxation Office, social security records will remain with the Department of Social Security and Medicare information will remain separate and secure. I will say that again. For people who are concerned that the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you regard the McGoldrick thing as secure information?

—Will the honourable senator wait? I will come to that point in a minute. There will be no dossier gathering under the Australia Card and under the Register. There will be no amalgamation of detailed information about people into one central computer.
—How can you say that?

—Tax information will stay with the Tax Office, social security records will stay with the Department of Social Security and Medicare information will stay with Medicare. Senator Alston asks how I can say that. They are precisely the terms of the legislation. The only interchange of information will be precisely that which is allowed at the moment-nothing further. As to the McGoldrick case, it is very mischievous and misrepresentative of the Opposition to suggest that that was due to a breakdown in security in the Health Insurance Commission. The facts of the matter indicate quite otherwise. The misrepresentation in that case is very mischievous, almost to the point where the Health Commission ought to be able to sue--
—Tell us how it happened.

—I can tell the honourable senator that, but I will come to it in due course, if he does not mind waiting. The interesting thing about this debate is that as soon as one point is raised the argument slips to some other point. The first point that must be made is that the Australia Card Register will contain a person's name, a person's signature, the number associated with that person and nothing further. There will be no central dossier; there will be no gathering of information on a person into one file. There will be nothing further than is currently the case. The integrity of each department will continue. Unless that is understood, unless that is believed, unless that is accepted by the Opposition and by the people of the community, the fears will continue. But it is very mischievous-in fact, it is blatant lying by the Opposition and anybody else campaigning in this identity card debate-to suggest that other than that is the case.

SPEECH.PARA: The very important matter of privacy has been of the gravest concern to the Government. Indeed, it has established the Data Protection Agency to overview the privacy of information to be held. Not only is the legislation establishing that Agency the most extensive to have been put in place to this point but it is also to be added to by privacy legislation shortly to be introduced into this place. The Government is acutely aware of the debate and the tension arising from it, about the rights of individuals as opposed to the rights of the community.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to continue my remarks on the third time that the Senate has addressed itself to the Australian Card legislation. It is important to recall exactly what this legislation is about. In summary, it can be said that the Australia Card program is a simple and effective means of validating a person's identity specifically for taxation, Medicare and social security purposes. It is the single most effective measure that can be introduced to combat tax evasion and welfare fraud. It is important that we keep in mind those two principal aims of this legislation. This Government absolutely objects to any methods that continue the promotion of tax evasion which, as has been said in other places, became the largest growth industry under the seven years of the Fraser Government. It is a matter of the gravest concern that steps that can be taken to reduce tax evasion are not taken. It is also true that social welfare fraud continues despite considerable efforts and considerable improvements over the past 12 to 18 months to redress the imbalance.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, the essence of the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3] is well put by recalling what the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, said in the other place when he introduced the legislation for the second time. He said:

This Government believes that the people of this country have a fundamental right to expect that their elected representatives protect them from those who are operating dishonestly within the tax and welfare systems. They have a right to expect that the Government ensures as best it can that all contribute their fair share of tax. They have a right to expect that welfare benefits are paid only to those who are truly entitled to those benefits. They have a right to expect that immigrants to this country who are operating within our system are here legally. Finally, and very importantly, they have a right to expect that, in going about achieving these fundamental goals, governments do everything within their power to safeguard the rights to privacy and civil liberties of the individual. It is because the Government is convinced, as is the majority of the Australian population, that the Australia Card program will significantly achieve and enhance all of these I am today reintroducing the Australia Card Bill 1986.
I strongly endorse that very pithy summary and outline by Dr Blewett of the intentions and purposes of this legislation.

I recall the last remarks of Senator Alston who, in his contribution just prior to mine, said that the legislation was a distraction from increasing the productivity in this country. I ask Senator Alston how one measures productivity of a country if not in terms of, at least in one dimension of, the revenue collected from those people who contribute to productivity through the work force and through paying their taxes. Through a proper collection of taxes a country can have one measure of its productivity. It was precisely because under the Fraser Government so many people were unable to be productive and were forced out of the work force and the resultant great increase in unemployment that not only did tax receipts fall but also social welfare expenditure increased. If Senator Alston is serious about that, he should appreciate that the Australia Card, as a proper and comprehensive tax revenue collection method, will be a measure of the productivity of the country, not a campaign against it.

I turn now to make some comment about revenue collection. I notice that the Opposition is totally unaccepting of the Government's estimate of return over the 10-year period of $4.7 billion. But the Opposition has absolutely no doubt at all in accepting the estimated cost figure of $759m. I ask why it believes in the cost outlay but does not accept the estimate, which is conservative by any criterion, of revenue gained. It is a matter of discredit to the Opposition that it believes one figure that suits its argument-that is, the cost of implementation of the program-but does not accept the huge return to government conservatively estimated at $4.7 billion over the first 10 years of operation. I have heard nothing from the Opposition to justify why it believes in one figure and totally disregards the other.

The important thing about this legislation is that it will provide a high integrity method of identification of Australians. That will be dependent on the establishment of a national births, deaths and marriages register. Of course, the Opposition has complained fairly often that it will be easy to establish a fraudulent identity. The principal way people have established a fraudulent identity is by claiming to be, and therefore seeking a birth certificate of, another individual, particularly someone who they know has died, helped by the fact that at the moment the time lapse between when a person's death is reported and when the corresponding birth certificate is removed from circulation is considerable. Under the proposed national register of births, deaths and marriages that time lapse will be reduced very significantly to almost no time at all. The opportunity to obtain fraudulent identity by seeking and claiming a false birth certificate will be dramatically reduced. That is the first point about the higher integrity of the identification system.

The second point is the way that identification will be established by, as far as is possible, an interview with every citizen in the country. Of course, that is why the estimated 2,000 public servants will be needed only for the initial establishment of identity. The higher the integrity of the identification in the first place, the less likely will be the prospect of fraud and fraudulent identification and the more the integrity of the system can be relied on down the line.

Of course, this goes to two of the arguments used by the Opposition against the Australia Card. Firstly, curiously enough, Opposition members do not address the difficulties of identification of people under a tax file number system, for which they have strongly argued in the past. I have not heard from them and I have no way of understanding how they expect to have a high integrity on a tax file number and yet somehow suggest that the Australia Card will be of less integrity. Very importantly, the Australia Card will be comprehensive; it will cover every Australian. A tax file number system does not address the problem of what happens to people who do not pay tax. Will they have no identification and in what way will that lack of identification go against them? At the moment, because of this Government's rebate for pensioners, the large majority of people who do not pay tax are pensioners. Pensioners who receive no other income do not pay tax and therefore they would be excluded from the tax file number identification system proposed by the Opposition. The Opposition's proposal will also not help the many people who currently do not earn any income, have perhaps never earned income and never had a tax file number. In fact I have had brought to my attention by a number of constituents their eager anticipation of at last being able to be eligible for some kind of identification system. In particular, I mention the non-working spouses in a single income family. Those people have asked of me what sort of identification they would be eligible for under the tax file number system. The answer is none. But, of course, under the Australia Card system they would be eligible for identification and that would be beneficial to them in the way that the majority of them would use it, that is, through Medicare.

The other important constituent problem that has been brought to my attention on a number of occasions is the difficulty of identification for people receiving welfare benefits, in particular for those people who travel or cross State borders. The necessity to re-establish identification in order to receive social security benefits in another State or office requires recipients to go through the whole business of identification once again. They have to find some kind of documentation. The requirements of the Department of Social Security are very significant, very special and precise because so many people have created false identities or tried to and successfully rorted the social security system based on false identity. It is very difficult to achieve a balance between the need for proper identification and some appreciation of the difficulties for people in establishing identification. As I have said, a number of constituents have raised with me that problem and I am in considerable sympathy with them, although I must say that the last constituent who appeared in my office, very distressed about the requirements of identification needed by our Department of Social Security in South Australia, turned out to be a gentleman on the lam, as one says, from prison in New South Wales. He had been charged with fraud and other associated misrepresentations of identity. His case simply gives the evidence why the Department has to be so tight and serious in its identification processes. It is also why the Australia Card would very much relieve the eligible social security recipients of that kind of constant problem.

In fact, I think the fear-mongering campaign that has been pushed to the community over the last little while-but also in the previous debates, I might say-has been a cause of great anxiety for many social security recipients. I think it is very important to lay to rest the arguments used in terms of the invasion of their civil liberties and so on. In fact, exactly the opposite will be the case. Those people will be enormously advantaged by having a secure identification system that relieves them and the Department of the chronic problem of re-establishing identification. Those matters need to be put into the debate thoughtfully and responsibly. The Opposition is not arguing on the facts; it is actually arguing on the basis of fear, making wild statements about infringements of civil liberties and so on. The Government is acutely aware of the difficulties associated with civil liberties. That is why its Data Protection Agency legislation is presented along with this legislation; that is why it has looked at the national register of births, deaths and marriages and has set in train processes for it to be established; and that is also why its privacy legislation, soon to be introduced, will address those issues with particular significance with increased powers-more than have ever been provided for in the past.

I was asked by some honourable senators opposite whether I could explain why the recent information in the so-called McGoldrick affair is not relevant to the discussion of the legislation, and I am pleased to do so. The release of that information was approved by the General Manager of the Health Insurance Commission via a delegation devolved from the Minister under the public interest provisions of the Health Insurance Act. There are no similar provisions in the Australia Card legislation. The comparisons are without any validity. It is not relevant to the Australia Card legislation and it has been a matter of gross misinformation-I should say almost wicked misinformation-to try to tie those two matters together.

The case involving the Health Insurance Commission concerns the public interest provisions of its Act; there is no parallel in the Australia Card legislation. That must be clearly understood. In fact, further, the Health Insurance Commission's delegation to release information on this ground has been revoked by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) pending a review of secrecy provisions in the Health Insurance Act. It is a matter of concern. It is also quite clear that this Government takes that concern very seriously and is taking steps as it always does to seriously address that issue so as to be sure that the criteria for any further release of information under that heading will be thoroughly examined and made very clear.

To conclude my contribution, I can only say that this is the third time around: we have been through all of these arguments before. It is quite clear that an orchestrated campaign can arouse fear and anxiety in the community. The challenge for the Government is to allay that fear and anxiety. It will certainly be able to do that because once people have the facts-I know this from my own experience-they will be reassured. People in the community will then be very able to return to giving the considerable support they were giving to the Australia Card prior to this very mischievous and misinformed campaign. The legislation deals with the question of equity. It deals with the importance of collecting proper tax so that those people who contribute and who are honest in our community are not disadvantaged compared with the unscrupulous people who rort either the tax system or the social security system. It is a matter of great importance that we have those proper collections of tax and the right allocation of welfare or people cannot have a belief or trust in the system. The Australia Card will go a long way to ensuring that that proper collection of tax, that proper equity, is in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the third debate in Parliament on the Australia Card Bill. I want first of all to comment on some aspects of the debate so far. I am pleased that the Government is entering into debate at least in this forum. Having attended a great many meetings on this issue and having in my diary several more, it has been a matter of disappointment that all too often Government members have not made themselves available in the public arena for debate on this issue. I would like to comment on the contribution to Friday's debate by Senator Schacht from South Australia. I quote what he said from the Hansard. He remarked that in his view:

SPEECH.PARA: It is ironical in a sense that the Democrats, who are back here with seven senators, are here because of a Bill which they used to trigger a double dissolution. It is a Bill which has enhanced their survival and some of us in the major parties might think that that is one of the unfortunate circumstances of the double dissolution.

I can assure Senator Schacht and anyone else that on this issue in particular-along with a number of others, of course-there is no irony in that fact. It is the case that out there in the electorate there is a mandate on this issue, and that mandate belongs to the Australian Democrats. We were the people who were instrumental in keeping this debate open all of this time and we are committed to continuing in that debate. There is no irony in our being returned in increased numbers and with an increased national vote for the first time since 1977.

Towards the close of the debate on Friday when my colleague Senator McLean was referring to the many public meetings which he along with other Democrats have addressed, particularly during the election campaign, Senator Ryan interjected by saying:
This is not a public meeting; this is the Senate.

I think it is important to point out that the Australian Democrats are saying in the Senate the same things that we have been saying in the public meetings. What we are saying is what we will do and what we have done; that is, we oppose this legislation. Many other speakers opposing the Australia Card Bill have commented on the depth of feeling which we are finding out in the community. Speakers on Friday were able to point to a lunch time meeting in Adelaide of some 5,000 people which had just occurred at the time when, I think, Senator McLean drew it to the attention of the Parliament. That meeting reflected the same sort of move that had taken place in Orange just the day before. Last week in Bendigo in Victoria there was a very well attended meeting, and on Sunday I attended and spoke at a meeting in Geelong.

In Victoria the coalition which has been formed against the Australia Card-a coalition typical of the movement against the Australia Card which is representative of people across the board-is regionalising, forming itself in regional areas. That meeting in Geelong on Sunday, along with the other meetings, gives the lie to the view which apparently has been expressed by the Government, and which was noted in an article in the Australian Financial Review on 2 September by Gregory Hywood, that it considers that opposition to the Australia Card has a shallow base. The Geelong meeting, which packed out a fairly modest hall which had seating for some 300 people, was called on three days notice. There was a little radio publicity but basically people just leafleted in the city of Geelong for three days and mustered over 300 people on a very sunny, very warm Sunday afternoon. There were people from across the board-young couples with their children and elderly couples who had come along after, I think, attending church in the morning and having lunch. The meeting was organised by a group of concerned unionists. That seems to me not to demonstrate a shallow base. People came to the provincial centre of Geelong from country centres around, including in particular the Colac area. As I said, that meeting was organised in three days.

These meetings are going on and they will continue. They demonstrate that the Government's claimed support for the Australia Card has indeed fallen sharply. The problem is that the support which the Government had claimed prior to the election was based on perhaps two weaknesses. Firstly, many of the questions that were being asked in the public opinion polls were loaded. Secondly, the polls may have been canvassing the people but they were not canvassing the depth of the people's feeling. Once the information becomes available-much information has already been given in this debate-many of the people who in the past have said, `Yes, it is all right, there is nothing to hide, nothing to lose' become concerned and, when polled again, give a different opinion.

Today an instance of this change in opinion came to the attention of the Australian Democrats. My colleague Senator McLean concluded his adjourned speech this afternoon before the sitting was suspended for dinner. A call came to Senator Jenkins's office from Western Australia where a member of the public had heard the last four minutes of Senator McLean's speech. He or she-I am not sure which it was-phoned Senator Jenkins's office to let us know that, whereas previously he or she had been a supporter of the Australia Card, he or she had now decided that there was sufficient additional information given in those few minutes to change his or her mind. This is indicative of what is happening.

Perhaps we should consider some of the figures. A Saulwick Age poll on 8 September found that 39 per cent of people favoured the introduction of the Australia Card, as opposed to 65 per cent of people who were in favour of its introduction in June 1986-quite a swing in public opinion. Then there are the telephone polls conducted during television programs. Channel 10 recorded a figure of 86 per cent of people against the card and the Willesee program recorded a figure of 85 per cent against it. I certainly concede that telephone polls of this kind are able to be distorted easily. However, that very fact in itself is an argument. The fact that people were prepared to go to the trouble of mustering forces in that sort of instance clearly shows the strength of feeling that exists. Even if we cannot take the figures on face value-although if one compares them to the Saulwick poll the distortion is not significant-they demonstrate the strength of feeling and how much people want to get that feeling on the record.

As has been pointed out frequently in this debate, the opposition to the card is extremely broadly based. A further demonstration of the breadth of opposition to the card occurred in the Australian this weekend. At the bottom of the letters page were published the figures between 3 September and 19 September relating to letters about the ID card received and published by the newspaper. There were 818 letters received-732 against the card, 43 in favour of it and 43 unspecified. The Australian has bent over backwards to give balance to the debate in regard to the letters it has published. It has published 312 letters against the card, 280 for the card and 17 unspecified. Again that is an interesting demonstration of the depth and breadth of opposition to the card.

We must not dismiss the very broad base of the opposition. As other speakers have said, the national body which has been formed, the Australian Privacy Foundation, comprises people from across the political and social spectrum. The fact that Professor Lauchlan Chipman and Professor Ted Wheelwright share a concern must be significant and must not be ignored. Senator Haines is proud to join them and Frank Hardy, Alan Jones, the Hon. James McClelland, Tim Robertson, Dr Bruce Shepherd, Nadia Weiner, Professor Geoffrey de Q. Walker, Dr Michael Aroney, Ron Castan, Dr Peter Catts and the others who have joined together to form the Privacy Foundation. That is not forgetting the trustees of the Foundation, Sir Reginald Smithers, Bridget Gilling, Peter Garrett and Ben Lexcen. To dismiss that kind of community support would be very foolish on the part of any government perhaps in regard to any legislation.

We must not forget that, as I found in Geelong at the weekend, within the union movement there is considerable opposition to the card, some of which ought to be causing the Government to think again. As always, it is very important to have union support if one is going to push through action on a matter like this. Of all the unions at State level, the South Australian unions appear to be the most organised. As I have said, my experience at the weekend demonstrated that unionists in one area after another are getting organised.

South Australia has said that it is going to charge for data which might be necessary. I certainly hope that the Government has readjusted its costings on that basis. Obviously, New South Wales is extremely nervous. One is not too sure from day to day where Mr Unsworth himself stands but, as it is the next State to go to an election, Mr Hawke cannot rely totally on support from New South Wales.

In Victoria the situation is interesting. The past three Australian Labor Party State Conferences have come out strongly against the Australia Card legislation. The Victorian Opposition has a private member's Bill before the Parliament prohibiting the Government from passing over the necessary documentation. The Government in Victoria has avoided a vote on this legislation. Obviously, although the Premier is not making public statements on the legislation, he knows that it is not just members of his extreme Left, people such as Jean McLean and Joan Coxsedge, who have come out against the legislation but that there is across the board concern and opposition. The Premier does not want to embarrass himself or his members of parliament, so the Government has avoided a vote on it.

We must not forget that one of the first people out of the blocks in opposition to this legislation was the highest office holder of the Anglican Church of Australia, Sir John Grindrod, which demonstrates, as those of us who have been attending meetings in opposition to the card know, the sort of concern that exists in this sector. Perhaps we need to look a little more deeply at the reasons for this mounting opposition. Perhaps the Government can say, `We did have a double dissolution on the ID card; we did go to an election on it'. However, I do not believe that it can claim a mandate on it. I point to one reason why it cannot. Obviously, one of the reasons why people on the ALP side of politics did not oppose the card vociferously during the election campaign was their fear that the Opposition parties might very well capitalise on it, benefit from it and win government. It is always very difficult during elections campaigns for people to choose and vote on one issue. In the majority of cases people do not do so. They consider a number of issues. People have a range of concerns. They are placed in a very difficult position. That is why the Government cannot claim a mandate on this single issue. It certainly was not a single issue election campaign.

With the election out of the way and a Labor government having been re-elected we are now seeing the mobilisation of Labor Party voters and members and unionists, as I have already mentioned. One of the clearest run-downs on the sort of thinking that is going on has come to me from the Law Council of Australia. In its correspondence to me, and no doubt to other senators, the Law Council has pointed out that to date it has not taken a position on a national identification system but has opposed the Australia Card legislation in its present form. However, its most recent correspondence indicates that that position is under review and notes some of the reasons why. Some of those reasons are the same reasons why the general community is coming out in opposition to the card after having received more information. The Law Council says that it is concerned that such a system of identification could easily be expanded for use by all government departments and other data banks using the same identification numbers.

We are reminded that in original submissions, and indeed in the Government's original submission to the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, a whole range of government departments were laying claim to being part of this system. The Departments of Community Services and Health and the Department of Social Security, and of course the Australian Taxation Office, are involved in this legislation. But I have a list stating that the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the department dealing with housing and construction services, the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the Australian Federal Police, the Australian Institute of Health, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and so on-a range of departments-are interested in becoming part of this system, and this is a genuine concern. This legislation can be amended, changed, expanded or extended by any future government, and that is a major concern.

The Law Council also views as objectionable the requirement that persons prove their identity before they can enter into a considerable number of quite common transactions and activities. The Council believes that this is:
an unwarranted restriction on the freedom that individual Australians have, and should have, to engage in ordinary activities and transactions.
The Law Council also notes that:
the Government's attitude seems somewhat contradictory.
I think this comment is very important. On the one hand, the Law Council argues:

the information contained on the Australia Card and in the central data base will be limited and of such a character that there need be no concern about its being vulnerable to unauthorised access. On the other hand, the Government sees a need to establish a complex and costly system to protect that information-a system said to be the most secure available. It might be asked why such tight security is needed if the information held is as insignificant as the Government asserts.

Of course we know that it is not. It is information about the personal and intimate details of people's lives and of course we do need strong protection. We need protection from the sorts of data bases already in existence in both the public and the private sectors.

As the Australian Democrats have often said, we believe that the first job that this Government should be doing is bringing in privacy legislation, a data protection agency and a surveillance authority in this area. That must be done. A private member's Bill was introduced during the last Parliament and this is an issue that we intend to pursue doggedly. Other points have been made by the Law Council, but that is a summary of some of the points which are causing people concern. Indeed, the Government itself is concerned, particularly on that latter point, and there is ample evidence of this in a number of media comments. For instance, on 14 August Senator Ryan admitted in the Australian that further safeguards are needed. We are told that the Australia Card legislation will be altered after a joint sitting. We are asked to trust the Government-a government which has realised, after more thought and consideration, information and expert advice, that indeed this Bill which we are being asked to pass is flawed.

There are concerns about it, and even the Government has come to understand some of them. This weekend the Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) said that the Government might in fact recognise that it might have to consider alternatives. It seems to me that we have here a problem of learning curves. Obviously the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), Senator Ryan and Dr Blewett have a considerably slower learning curve than has Mr Bowen. I think the activity that is going on in the community might just jog them along a little bit and with any luck they will get on the same learning curve as the Deputy Prime Minister and we will see this legislation disappear forever.

There are a number of other particular concerns about the legislation, one of which has perhaps been sufficiently canvassed in detail; and that is the concern about the authenticity of cards from a number of points of view. One of the first concerns is the dependence for that authenticity and legitimacy on a high integrity initial base in the Offices of Births, Deaths and Marriages. I read with some interest at the weekend an item from Anne Summers in the Times on Sunday-she has lived in the United States of America for the last couple of years-pointing out that she has an identification number which she has to use for a number of purposes, such as opening a bank account and other cash transactions of that kind. She concludes her article by saying `I cannot see what the fuss is about'.

Perhaps one of the reasons for this fuss also comes from what is happening in the United States, and this was mentioned in the Australian Financial Review last November. It contained information that a fake identity card could be obtained from a Times Square shop as at last November at a cost of $15 and, with a bit more difficulty and expense, a phoney birth certificate could be obtained for $27. That sort of concern followed comments made by Frank Costigan to the Joint Select Committee which looked at the prospect of this legislation, and is a genuine concern of people in the community.

Senator Crowley has suggested that concerns about the administration of this legislation by the Health Insurance Commission are ill-founded. She assured us that the release of information in the McGoldrick case was authorised and therefore we should not be worried. But I have to say that, whether the release of that sort of private information, is accidental, authorised or corrupt, it does not alter the fact that an individual's privacy is something to which that individual has an inalienable right; and in all humanity it should not be the reason for its release and is quite irrelevant. I think people have a perfect right to be genuinely concerned about the prospect of the Health Insurance Commission being the major administrator of this program.

I would like to make one contribution against the argument that if a person has nothing to hide he has nothing to lose. I do so by way of quoting one verse from a poem against the ID card by Les Murray-one of our foremost contemporary poets-which Peter Garrett used in his campaign against the card:
`If you've nothing on your conscience'-any dero could shout Nonshense.
Black folk could tell you how it used to feel
to be licensed like a dog just to keep your kids, drink grog,
cash a cheque or vote, but never be quite real.
That perhaps answers the question to whether one has nothing to hide; at least it certainly answers it for me.

I will be moving amendments, which have been circulated in the name of the Australian Democrats, to the Opposition amendment which we are debating along with the motion that the Bill be now read a second time. The Democrats feel it necessary to move these amendments for a number of reasons. We believe that this Bill should be referred to a standing committee of the Senate, which differs from the proposal of the Opposition to refer it to a select committee. From our point of view, it is important that this Bill be referred to a committee constituted for the purposes of the long term operation of the Senate and not specifically for this particular issue, particularly in terms of the composition of Government senators.

We also believe that the reporting date, which the Opposition has suggested in its amendment as the first day of sitting in February-in other words, when we begin out sittings after the Christmas recess-is far too soon. In fact there is a history of Senate committees being forced to sit over the silly season. We do not believe that that gives adequate time for the community and concerned people to make their representations, not to mention the ability of senators involved to have their normal Christmas break and perhaps make adequate judgments. For instance, the original Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card was formed towards the end of November and its hearings were conducted during December, January and February. The hearings were extended to April and then to May. The Committee reported in May. I was a member of the Senate Select Committee on Television Equalisation, most of the hearings of which were held in January. A number of community groups felt that certainly there was not adequate time for them to prepare their submissions. This issue is too important to the Australian Democrats to be rushed through whichever committee it is referred to.

The Australian Democrats amendments seek to add to the terms of reference that are set out in the Opposition's amendment. They do so for a number of reasons. We have looked at, and taken account of, areas of duplication. We have added to paragraph (j) of the Opposition's amendment the question of the differentials in penalties which apply to breaches by private citizens, corporations and the authority itself. We think it is important that that be done. We are also proposing that the Opposition's paragraph (l) be changed in recognition of the fact that no overseas country has the same system. We believe that the committee which will look at this legislation should draw on the experience of comparable countries which have had proposals for such a system before them.

As I said, we have added a number of points which we believe need to be in the terms of reference, and perhaps I should just refer to one or two of them. We believe that the committee should examine the implications for the system if a significant number of people fall within the activities for which the card and a number are required. Of course, we would be talking here of general day to day activities of the vast majority of people, particularly adult people, in the community. We think the implications of a significant number of people refusing to have the card and number should be known.

This is not a light-hearted suggestion. There are people in the community at the moment who are saying that they will in fact take up the offer of the Government, which is in the legislation, to make possession of the card voluntary. Of course, this is fiction. However, that fiction may very well be tested by a number of people in the community. We believe that that matter needs to be considered. We also believe that there should be a comparison of the costs and benefits of the Government proposal, the Joint Select Committee proposal and a number of others. I seek leave to move several amendments together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Leave out the words ``this Bill be referred to a select committee, the powers and composition of which be contained in a subsequent resolution,'' insert:

``this Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for inquiry and report, upon the establishment of that committee or, if a committee of that name is not established, to a committee specified in a subsequent resolution,''.
(2) Paragraph (f) of the proposed terms of reference, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
``(f) assess the direct cost to the private sector in establishing and maintaining the system;''.
(3) Paragraph (j) of the proposed terms of reference, at end of paragraph, insert:
``, including the differential in penalties which applies to breaches of the legislation by the Authority and breaches by private citizens and corporations''.
(4) Paragraph (1) of the proposed terms of reference, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:

``(1) examine the experience of comparable countries in the adoption or rejection of an ID card system such as the one proposed, this comparison to include the USA, West Germany, Canada, Netherlands, France, UK, Austria, Belgium, Italy, Denmark;''.
(5) Paragraph (m) of the proposed terms of reference, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraphs:
(m) assess the constitutionality of the Government's proposed Australia Card and personal identification system;
(n) examine the implications for the system if a significant number of people whose activities fall within those for which the card and number are required refuse to apply for the card;

(o) consider the financial implications and administrative delays in the public and private sectors in complying with the system and the impact of this on Australia's economic situation, consideration of these matters to include assessments of the system's impact on transactions specifically affected by the legislation-e.g. auction sales;

(p) assess the likelihood of more cards and numbers being issued than there are entitled card-holders (as has already occurred with Medicare cards) and the implications of this if the Medicare number is to be used in the Australia Card system;

(q) determine the need for privacy protection legislation and a data protection agency and what form such protection should take, with particular reference to legal remedies for such matters as refusal to correct incorrect data; failure on the part of the Authority to perform its functions; and compensation for damage suffered;

(r) make a comparison of the costs and benefits of the Government proposal with Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card majority recommendation for using a high-integrity tax file number to combat tax and social security fraud;
(s) assess the appropriateness of linking sensitive personal information such as medical data with a system which is designed to address financial matters;
(t) examine the constitutional implications of the legislation's use of terminology such as `The Authority' and `card-subjects' in a common law country such as Australia;
(u) examine the problem of distinguishing between requiring someone to produce a card as a means of identification (which attracts a penalty if it is unauthorised) and `requesting' someone to do so;
(v) determine the adequacy of protections against misuse of the unique personal identification number, as distinct from misuse of the card;
(w) examine the appropriateness of fees being charged for card-subjects to have access to their details on the register, other than the annual inspection permitted under the legislation;
(x) assess the likelihood of increased access to the register by government departments and the private sector in the future;

(y) examine the ease of linkage between information on the register and information on the computer files of other government departments, agencies and private sector bodies where those bodies use the unique personal identification number for purposes required under the legislation;
(z) assess the usefulness of the card and numbering system in achieving the objectives claimed for it, with particular reference to the cash economy, organised crime and large-scale tax evasion;
(za) examine any matters relevant to the preceding; and''.
(6) At end of the proposed terms of reference, add the following paragraph:
``(zb) present a final report on or before the first day of sitting in March 1988.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not the first time that I have spoken on the Australia Card legislation although it is the first time that I have spoken on the legislation in the new Parliament. However, I had the opportunity of speaking last week on a matter of public importance which was raised by Senator Puplick who led for the Opposition. I want to say once again that I oppose this Government's proposal for a card numbering system. Instead of being persons we will all end up being numbers. I support Senator Puplick's amendment and the reference of this Bill to a committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government claims that because the National and the Liberal parties oppose this legislation we are friends of tax cheats and all the people who defraud the social security system and that we want to protect them. I consider that that is absolute rot. Frank Costigan, the former Royal Commissioner who headed the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, said that the Australia Card will not and should not work to catch tax or social welfare cheats. He said that the major areas of tax fraud could be attacked in different ways under existing laws and that the Australian Taxation Office was already beginning to receive a lot of lost revenue.

I do not believe that this Government has a mandate to inflict this most un-Australian piece of legislation on our country. Statistics have a way of being used and abused for the sake of an argument, but one set of statistics clearly shows that this Government has no mandate to implement the most dangerous threat to privacy ever seen in this freedom loving country. Once again, I remind the Senate, as I reminded it last week, that more Australians voted for the anti-identity card parties during the election than for the Australian Labor Party. The anti-ID card parties won more votes than the ALP in every State and Territory except for the Australian Capital Territory. For the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to suggest that the return of his Government is proof positive that Australians want the ID card shows that he has lost touch with the average Australian.

During the election campaign I put out quite a number of Press releases about opposition to the ID card. As a matter of fact, I believe that many members did likewise. However, the media just did not seem to want to know about it. I am quite sure that most honourable senators have been bombarded with letters and petitions from people who are very concerned about this ID card proposal. We can gain knowledge of that from the number of petitions and signatures that have been presented to the Senate and to the other place.

People talk about what the ID card is to be used for, who will have access to it and what one will not be able to do without it. There are the very real concerns about the ability of hackers to infiltrate the system. The people who have signed petitions have not been organised by slick lobby groups. They are men and women who are very worried about the direction in which this socialist Government is taking them. I believe that the Government has failed to demonstrate convincingly that the ID card will achieve its stated aims.

I want to put on record some of the facts about the ID card. This card will not stop tax fraud or evasion. The Tax Office has said this. Indeed, it is a known fact that tax evasion occurs in the cash economy and the ID card will not stop that. The ID card will not stop welfare cheats. The Department of Social Security has said that certainly the welfare cheats will not be caught through the ID card. In fact, the Department of Social Security says that it will not accept the card on its own and that there must be some other proof of identity for social security purposes. The ID card will not catch illegal immigrants. The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has told us that. Organised crime will benefit from having ID cards because they will be able to forge them. Most importantly, many people in Australia believe that civil liberties and privacy are threatened by the ID card.

I was interested to read in one of the papers just a couple of days ago that Mr Allan Nelson, a leading private investigator in Brisbane, said that there is no such thing as private and secure information. He said that there is nothing he could not find out about anybody. He said:
Don't worry about computers. It's the people in charge of the computers who spill the beans.
One has to rely on the people who are operating the computers. On 2 May 1985 Mr Justice Michael Kirby said:
What is at stake is nothing less than the nature of our society and the power and the authority of the state in relation to the individual.

The concept of an ID card is a blatant attempt on the part of a socialist government to impose a Big Brother watchdog system on all Australians and give the Federal Government even more control over private people's lives. In other words, it would become a type of internal passport. We all know that this happens in communist countries where they have these documents. The Toowoomba Chronicle on Friday, 11 September, contained an interesting editorial which I should like to quote:

Three-quarters of a century ago, United States President-elect Woodrow Wilson reminded his countrymen that liberty has never come from government. The history of liberty, he said, was a history of resistance . . . of limitation of governmental power, not the increase of it.

Such fundamental truths do not change with the passage of time, and Wilson's words are just as apposite today in regard to the burgeoning national debate on the Hawke Labor Government's proposed universal identity card.

Mr Wilson's 1912 comments are fitting in the context of the Australia Card debate because the Prime Minister and other Government backers of the card are seeking to win back dwindling public support with soothing words of reassurance that they will act to protect individual privacy.
The catch is that they say they will take such action after the card becomes a legislative fact.

The Government is pressing ahead with the proposal, despite the fact that it was rejected by the majority report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card which was tabled in the House of Representatives on 8 May 1986.

We must also remember that the costs to all taxpayers are excessive with the introduction of the ID card. Its implementation would cost taxpayers around $1 billion and 2,000 new public servants would be required for its administration. In addition, the private sector would have to spend about $2 billion to change systems to comply with the card's requirements, and the banks also have said that they will be put to a lot of extra expense to change their system of accounting. New personal penalties and fines will be used to try to ensure the ID card's complete acceptance. It is appropriate to consider some of the heavy fines and penalties that are to be imposed. The Government has said that some of these are wrong, but they have been listed on a number of occasions. If a person fails to report the loss of an ID card within 21 days, he or she will be fined $500. If an employer-this includes the employment of a baby sitter or somebody who comes to work on a property-fails to see, record and report to the Government the employee's ID number, he or she could be fined $20,000.

If an employer hires a cardless person, he or she will be fined $20,000. If a banker, stockbroker, accountant, lawyer or real estate agent fails to see and record an ID number when a person enters into a financial transaction, he or she will be fined $20,000. These certainly are very large amounts of money. If one destroys or defaces one's ID card and cannot prove that it was accidental, one will be imprisoned for two years, fined $5,000 or both. If one fails to attend a compulsory conference ordered by the ID card agency, one will be fined $1,000 and/or imprisoned for six months. So it goes on and on.

Democracies closest to our own such as Britain, the United States of America and Canada have all rejected ID card proposals. Even the director of the Swedish Data Protection Agency has resigned in protest after 12 years in the job. One wonders why he did resign. The gentleman concerned, Mr Jan Freese, resigned because of the failure of the board and the Data Act to stop:
. . . our shrinking privacy and the extremely new vulnerability of the computerised society.
I continue to read what he said:

The Data Inspection Board, acting unanimously, found in its annual report this year that privacy protection had continued to become still more limited. The Swedes had been more or less stripped to their souls.

In the United States a Congressional report released in June this year says that the United States Privacy Act is failing to give privacy protection to United States Government Records. It is this privacy aspect that is of paramount concern in this debate.

When the Australia Card was first debated, 17 government agencies lobbied for access to the central identity register. The decision by the Government to allow three departments access has not fooled anyone. Once the card has been introduced, no doubt other departments will subsequently be allowed access. It was interesting to hear Mr Ben Humphreys, the new Minister for Veterans' Affairs, speak about going one step further and adding veterans' affairs information on the card. I believe that is an aspect we should look at. Senator Ryan has virtually admitted that the ID computer system will not be secure against hackers who wish to gain access to our personal information. Indeed, during the senator's recent trip around the country, she was interviewed on a Brisbane radio station. The interviewer asked her if the system would be absolutely safe from hackers wishing to obtain personal information for whatever reasons. Senator Ryan was unable to give a categorical assurance. I imagine this would have been the case on other occasions also.

We know that even within the Labor movement there are those opposed to the card's introduction. We have read a good deal about them. In fact, there was comment in the newspapers recently about what Senator Bolkus said on the subject. He said today that he had been misquoted. The Victorian ALP rejected the proposal for a national identity card at its State conference in October 1985. The South Australian ALP opposed a national identity system in 1985. Senator Schacht informed the Senate that in 1986 it changed its mind. I heard him make that comment when he made a speech the other day. The Premier of New South Wales, Mr Unsworth, has warned the Federal Government that it should drop plans for the Australia Card because of the widespread and growing opposition. Mr Unsworth told the Prime Minister that he should re-evaluate the proposal and take it back to the drawing board. Well, Mr Unsworth suggests it should go back to the drawing board, but I believe that the Bill and the idea of the ID card should be thrown out completely. Certainly I support Senator Puplick's amendment that the Bill should be referred to a committee. We do not want an identity card in which we will all be numbered; all the numbers of course will be linked.

One of the prime purposes of the Australia Card Bill is supposedly to crack down on welfare cheats. Yet on the Ray Martin show recently Senator Ryan admitted that an ID card would not prohibit obtaining employment. So if a person who is on the dole wants to go off and do some seasonal work, bearing in mind that they will not have to produce an ID card, then they will still be able to work under a false name and collect their unemployment benefit or invalid pension, or even both. Under the legislation to get a government ID card people will have to get themselves photographed, attend an interview, provide proof of identity and sign documents. I believe this will be an enormous logistical exercise-and an inconvenient one, particularly for those who live in remote areas. I do not know why we need this card as there seems to be so many different and varying cards for many and varied reasons that we all have to hold for one reason or another. We have a Medicare card, we all have a tax file number, as is obvious every time one puts in a tax return, and we have bankcards. If there is not enough money to pay bills, bankcards come in very handy. We all have a number for our bank accounts and, of course, in Queensland we have a driving licence with our photograph on it as well. I believe that we really have plenty of cards which we carry around and that we can prove our identity to people who need to know exactly who we are.

Parents of children under 16 years have to hold ID cards on behalf of their children. Each parent may hold a card on behalf of his or her children and when they reach the age of 16 those children can get a card in their own right, the previous card supposedly having been cancelled. Of course, there is the possibility of a 16-year-old effectively having three cards in his or her name. The opportunity for bureaucratic bungling and duplication is enormous. The Health Insurance Commission concedes that there are about 20,000 excess Medicare cards in circulation as it is. There have been occasions when for some reason or other people have not been issued with a Medicare card at all.

The Confederation of Australian Industry has claimed that the ongoing costs to both the private and public sectors of complying with the proposed national identity card system would far exceed its benefits in recouped tax revenue and diminished social security fraud. Mr John Fowler of the Small Business Association has stated that the Australia Card will cost every small businessman $2,000 in unproductive time when it is introduced. The National Party of Australia rejects the identity card. Not only will the card cost both taxpayers and the private sector billions of dollars to set up but it will also result in the greatest ever intrusion into people's private lives and will not achieve its stated aims of cracking down on tax avoidance, social security fraud, organised crime or illegal immigration.

The Government has not been able to guarantee that there will not be massive abuse and duplication of the card. In my opinion the key factor in this whole debate centres on freedom-the gradual erosion of the freedoms we have enjoyed in this country. The question really comes down to whether we are going to let the Government of this country become so all important that our freedom to choose not to have an identity card is completely ignored.

Of course, the Prime Minister says that it is not compulsory to have an ID card. I mentioned earlier all the fines and penalties that have been listed if one is not able to produce an ID card when asked. It might not be compulsory but it will be very difficult to operate without it. The people of Australia will not stand for it and I do not believe they should. I believe, along with millions of Australians who have been to protest meetings, signed petitions and written letters to their senators and members, that the Australia Card-I believe it should be called the ID card-should be rejected. In the meantime I certainly support the reference to a Senate select committee moved by Senator Puplick.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Major cracks are beginning to appear in the Government's presentation of the Australia Card because all around Australia people are turning against this proposal. They are turning in their droves and even supporters are now asking, `What are these unknowns? What are these quantified amendments that the Government says it will introduce if the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3] is passed?'. There are many people on the Government benches who are denying their consciences and true beliefs by voting for this identity system. I invite them now to be true to themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: Even the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), the second most senior Minister in the Government, said at the weekend that, if the Senate could come up with a reasonable alternative to the ID card, the Government really would be prepared to look at it. I believe that the Senate should rise to this occasion and to this challenge because a system of high integrity tax file numbers can be established which, coupled with a modified cash transactions reports Act, could tidy up the system without invading the privacy and liberty of all Australians. I quote from the minutes of evidence given by the Australian Taxation Office to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in relation to a proposed computer acquisition. The Taxation Commissioner, Mr Boucher, said:
. . . use of a high integrity number of one kind or another is somewhat central to a number of the things we hope to achieve from this project.
That project was a $700m computer installation.

A major plank of this Government's justification for the Australia Card has been the amount of money that the Australian Taxation Office will actually recoup. Earlier this year it was revealed that this $700m new computer system, to be installed by the Tax Office, would mean a great deal of recoupment. The benefits of this new equipment will be applied to income tax return processing, income tax matching, income audit systems and automated collection systems. We are all aware of the Auditor-General's criticisms of the Australian Taxation Office for its lack of matching and some of the other pitfalls. A lot of this has been put down to the fact that the Tax Office has been overworked, has had to work with antiquated systems and so on. But we are now allocating $700m to a sophisticated new computer installation that will achieve many of the purposes for which the Australia Card is designed.

In effect, there is an element of double counting. If we spend this $700m to improve income tax return processing and matching-one of the criticisms, after all, was the lack of matching of interest, dividends and so on-and to introduce an automated collection and audit system, the Government's statement that there will be a taxation revenue benefit from the introduction of an identity card is very misleading. I submit that there is an element of double counting.
In the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card there is a quotation from American Supreme Court Justice Brandeis. He said:
The greatest dangers to liberty lurk in insidious encroachments of men of zeal, well meaning, but without understanding.

I believe those words really encapsulate the reasons why this Senate, this House, this Parliament and all concerned citizens of Australia should reject this Australia Card. It will be enormously costly; it will be insidious; and, despite its proposed name, it will be un-Australian. After lengthy investigation and deliberation the majority of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card rejected the proposal. The Committee found that the card failed to adequately address the major problems which were to be overcome by the introduction of a national identity system, namely, tax evasion, welfare fraud and illegal immigration. The Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support, Mr Peter Duncan, admitted in a written answer in the House of Representatives:
Dedicated data systems can still be compromised by someone physically tapping into an exchange or transmission line.

This answer was obviously provided for the Minister by experts who knew the true situation. Notwithstanding that, Mr Duncan's honesty is in complete contrast to that of some of his superior Ministers. Those who are technically qualified in such subjects therefore advised Mr Duncan that the identity card system could still be compromised, yet the Government, in the wake of popular opinion, expert advice from public servants and others and the outcry to the effect that the card is blatantly wrong, still says that it will bulldoze this legislation through the Parliament without giving the people of Australia the opportunity to voice their view.

One of the identity card system's most fundamental shortcomings is its failure to tackle the problem of the cash economy. On the contrary, it provides a positive incentive for more and more Australians to direct their activities to this part of the cash economy. But it is not wholly an identity problem, and on this point I differ from my colleague on the other side, Senator Crowley. The identity card will not prevent large-scale tax avoiders from defrauding the revenue. Mr Frank Costigan, QC-perhaps this country's foremost authority on organised crime-is on the record as saying that the identity card will not stop large-scale tax avoidance, simply because it is based on the false assumption that evasion is primarily a result of false identity. The Australian Labor Party fails to acknowledge that feature and, time and time again, that comes through in Labor members' speeches. The point is that the big fish will continue to evade their tax.

There are far more effective ways of combating the significant problems of taxation fraud, welfare cheating and illegal immigration. These alternatives may be implemented without recourse to a national identity system that poses a threat to the privacy and liberty to which we in Australia have become accustomed.

The costs involved simply do not equate with the so-called benefits. The original estimate of the costs involved was $1,046m over 10 years, but that figure was quickly revised downwards to $733m. Whatever the true figure might be, it must be remembered that cost estimates in this place and in government have an uncanny tendency to blow out. The Government's Australia Card proposal will involve the employment of more than 2,150 new public servants and the upgrading of existing Medicare offices and the opening and staffing of 42 new offices-all in the name of fiscal restraint.
Many costs have been omitted from the Government's estimates. There has been no allowance for the replacement of capital equipment and no costs have been included for private sector compliance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or State governments.

—Or even State governments. What are the benefits? As the costs of the implementation of the scheme are a matter for some dispute so, too, are the benefits. Revenue estimates relating to the expected gains from the implementation of the system received from the Australian Taxation Office are highly questionable. It has been revealed that they were made on a `qualitative assessment of how tax evaders operate'. What an unusual phrase. I submit that it is not very scientific. Surely it is not a sound foundation on which to base a claim that the Australia Card is the best way to solve our tax and welfare fraud problems. The Government would be better advised to look at more ways of tightening procedures within existing departments and to shelve its plans for yet another arm of the bureaucracy. It has been said, and I believe correctly, that the introduction of the Australia Card system will solve our current taxation, welfare and immigration problems, but that is just like using a jackhammer to crack a nut-in other words, it is excessive in the extreme.

SPEECH.PARA: There is growing opposition to the Australia Card.
