That opposition has spread widely and quickly in recent months as more and more Australians have become aware of the reality that it is not necessary. Public meetings have been called, lobby groups formed and petitions circulated. Whole communities have joined in opposition to the Australia Card. many hours have been volunteered to the task of persuading the Government to reconsider its ill-conceived proposal, and the voices of these people must and will be heard.

Early last week I tabled a petition from 5,702 Tasmanians opposed to the card and, on average, I have added hundreds of names daily. Some of my colleagues are saving them up so that later in the month they can submit petitions from 10,000 to 20,000 or even 30,000 people. I think that petitions containing 6,000 signatures were lodged today in the Senate. Many of my colleagues have presented similar petitions rejecting the introduction of the Australia card.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one from 23,000 people.

—I am told that one petition alone has 23,000 signatures which have yet to be submitted to the Senate. I thank Senator Knowles. An ever-increasing number of Australians from all walks of life do not want the Australia Card. The Government would have us believe that those who oppose the card are tax cheats and welfare frauds. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) went so far as to classify them as a bunch of eccentrics. Let us see who is among their ranks: the Primate of the Anglican Church of Australia, Archbishop Sir John Grindrod; Mr Justice Michael Kirby; Mr Frank Costigan, QC; and the distinguished author, Morris West. Eminent Australians from all walks of life have joined in this chorus against the Australia Card. Even the New South Wales Premier, Mr Unsworth, has been having second thoughts about the value of the Government's proposal; yet our Prime Minister says that he knows best. He will persevere and bulldoze this measure through. I submit that Mr Hawke is in danger of losing contact with the Australian people-something which he has claimed as very special to himself. In his high office, he is becoming increasingly remote from the aspirations and needs of ordinary Australians, particularly if he chooses to ignore the flood of opposition to the card.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the problems with the legislation is clause 37. This aspect has not received enough public exposure. Clause 37 requires visitors to Australia to hold a visitor's version of the identity card. A man or a woman touring Australia for less than six weeks will need not only to have a valid passport, or in some cases a visa, but to give further details of his or her name, home address, address in Australia, et cetera. If tourists choose to stay longer than six weeks-which is a common practice if people are visiting several States and, say, central Australia and the Great Barrier Reef-they will be required to present themselves at an identify office and have their photograph taken, a number allocated, specimen signature recorded, their eligibility for Medicare benefits and for work assessed and recorded and they will be given an expiry date.

The Labor Government praises itself for encouraging and supporting the vital tourism industry, but it proposes a totalitarian measure, monitoring everybody making an extended visit here. One would have thought that pure logic makes it clear that the Government should encourage tourists on longer stays, but the effect of clause 37 will be not only to sour short-term visitors' experience of this so-called `free' Australia but to give a greater incentive to tourists to leave Australia before the six-week limit is up. Clause 37 is only one of many aspects that make the Bill unAustralian, insidious and bad legislation and give further reasons why Parliament should reject the legislation.

What about the mandate for the card? Mr Hawke and Senator Ryan claim that the last election gave them the mandate they required to introduce the identity card. But I and many others beg to differ, and there is a growing chorus of people around Australia who also beg to differ. In the weeks preceding the election very little was said about the identity card. In fact, Senator Walsh, while visiting my home state of Tasmania, is on record as saying that the Australia Card `would not be a high priority on Labor's return to government'. Yet, what do we find? We find ourselves in this chamber debating the issue in Budget week, the first week back. We should not be duped by the promises to amend the legislation once it is passed. The Prime Minister is studiously avoiding revealing the nature of these elusive amendments, and so is Senator Ryan, the Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health, who is responsible for this Bill. In fact, there are no guarantees that would be acceptable. In the interim, Parliament is being forced to pass what the Government has tacitly admitted is a piece of imperfect legislation. Should this be the function of an Australian Parliament? Should it be the function of the Australian Senate to pass legislation which is deficient, which is imperfect? I submit that we are going down the wrong track if we choose to pursue this course of action. Where is our integrity if we decide to follow that course?

By way of contrast, last week the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Steve Hatton, announced that Territory voters would have the opportunity in either 1988 or 1989 to vote at a referendum on whether they supported statehood for the Northern Territory. This announcement may not seem to be directly related to the Bill that we are considering, but I am submitting it by way of contrast. The difference is that although the Hatton Government is keen to pursue statehood, and it recently won a further term, it does not share the arrogance of our Prime Minister, Bob Hawke. The Northern Territory voters will be asked to put their views on this vital issue.

In other words, Mr Hawke assumes a mandate for this Bill but, unlike the Country Liberal Party Government in Darwin, this Government is not prepared to ask the opinion of the electors. What could be more democratic, more honest or more straightforward? Any student studying elementary political science will see through the Prime Minister's so-called mandate. It is a charade. Governments are elected on platforms, on policies. The Prime Minister mentioned not one word about the Australia Card in his election speech. He has no mandate for this Bill and therefore it must be rejected not only by the Senate but also by the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that any issue that brings together the Right and the Left must have some substance to it. I believe that such a coalition is imperative if we are to defeat the proposal for the Australia Card-a proposal that will make us the world leader in data surveillance and thus open to abuse by the state in a way so far without precedent. Two key questions have to be asked in relation to the proposed card will it deal with the concerns its introduction is supposed to meet, that is, tax cheating and welfare frauds, and can the ordinary citizen trust the state or the bureaucracy with a system that gives it such enormous potential power?

SPEECH.PARA: The card is allegedly meant to deal with various tax evasion schemes, dole cheating, illegal immigration and non-disclosure of income. We are told that the card would generally assist government agencies to carry out their functions more effectively, aid the fight against organised crime and drug trafficking and, in the longer term, rationalise the many government identification systems currently in operation. It would also simplify dealings with government for all Australians. Great play is made of John and Jane Citizen's dislike of social security frauds and tax cheats, of illegal migrants stealing jobs from Australians, and of the Government getting a lot more of the income that is due to it-$800m annually within three years of the card's introduction, or so we are told, although there can be no cast iron guarantees about that.

The Parliamentary Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, which delivered its report in May 1986, rejected all proposals for the issuing of identity cards and proposed an alternative scheme based on extending the use of the existing tax file number, combined with means of increasing the integrity of that number. The Joint Select Committee majority warned that if the Government's proposal that 13 agencies have access to the Australia Card Register were adopted, it would be difficult, if not impossible, to stop the uses of the card extending, given the wide range of initial uses. This then, becomes the crux of the matter. There are alternative ways of dealing with the issues that Australian citizens are justifiably concerned about. I would like to know why the Government does not follow up some of those alternatives, in particular the ways in which some of its millionaire or even billionaire friends pay such extraordinarily low taxes.

What is so dangerously new about the card is the concept of one card and computerised number linking together all the existing cards and numbers. The one number which will act as a linkage number will be the key to the system, and the reason why so many Australians are opposed to it. How will Australian citizens know whether they can trust the government of the day and the bureaucracy not to abuse the power which is afforded them by centralised computerised information on every citizen in Australia, along with visitors staying more than a few weeks? I was interested that Senator Watson referred to that, and I agree that it has not been given enough attention.

In that regard I also question the status of United States service people. This is a matter that has not been raised but I believe it is worth consideration. Such people are here for more than the six weeks that is afforded tourists. Would they have to be processed, put on file and use an Australia Card if they conducted any financial transactions in this country? Amongst the United States personnel is an unspecified number who are members of the National Security Agency (NSA), intelligence personnel, along with many members of the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), including the Director of Operations at Pine Gap. Would such spies have ID cards? If not, why not? Surely they would not come into the category of diplomatic immunity. I do not see why they, as spies working for a foreign government, should have immunity, and I very much doubt whether members of the NSA and the CIA would be willing carriers of an Australian identity card.

Various conservative politicians call the card the Moscow Card but the Soviets would be envious of our system if it were ever introduced, as would other countries such as South Africa and even some Western democracies. We know perfectly well that bureaucracies are not geared to the protection of the rights of the individual. They are geared to the promotion of their own systems. We often hold up Sweden as the example of a highly controlled welfare capitalist democratic society, but even there, Jan Freese, architect of Sweden's data protection laws and their chief enforcer since the 1970s, recently resigned because he felt the system was out of control.

The Government chose to ignore the proposals of the majority of the Joint Select Committee and took up the minority report, though inexplicably selecting the Health Insurance Commission to operate the limited scheme of giving access to the data by three agencies: the Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Social Security and the Health Insurance Commission itself. It is quite obvious that other agencies will want access to this centralised information in this computer age. No amount of government legislation or threatened penalties will stop the abuse of such valuable data on every one of us. I am particularly concerned that government or private security agencies should be able to tap into the system, as they would presumably be sheltered by what is usually known as national security. If school students can break into the computer network of the United States Department of Defense, with all the penalties for tapping into such vital national security networks, why should not computer criminals or hackers get into a system here?

There are other impracticalities too. Does the Government really think that 16 million of us can be smoothly identified and documented? Will we all get time off work to be processed? What will happen to those of us who cannot prove our identity to start with? There are many such individuals in Australia today, either born here or born overseas. What about our children? As soon as parents want their children to have a bank account, an option which many parents choose very early on in their children's lives, these children will have to have an ID card as well. Do we really want them given a number at birth and frequently photographed by and for the authorities as they grow and develop? Will we condemn our children to that unacceptable level of official interference in their private lives?

Then there is the problem of lost cards. Six per cent of Medicare cards were lost or stolen in the first two years of operation-a total of 670,000 cards. We will have to carry the Australia Card around with us a lot more than we do the Medicare card. It will also cost a lot more to replace and we are not told who will pay the replacement costs. It is possible that thousands of people will somehow deliberately lose their cards as some tactic of resistance.

The Government says that we do not have to have a card, which is quite ridiculous unless one happens to be an eccentric hermit living in the desert on fruit and honey and in perfect health; nor, apparently do we have to carry it all the time, although it is quite obvious that many people will carry it with them all the time. Predictably, quite a few will lose it as a result of carting it around, if they do not lose it at home. A person in authority or in a strong bargaining position could in effect require the card by rejecting all other identity documents. Teenagers will carry it to prove their age to get into bars or cinemas. Many individuals will simply not know the rules about when to produce it, who can demand it or the penalties for abuse. They will carry it around just to feel secure. Losing it could also cause acute distress to many old or insecure individuals. Another aspect that concerns me greatly is the work of community groups which will be hampered by their having to register with a government department before they can open a bank account. Arguably, Australia is already one of the most over-governed, over-regulated countries in the world. With the introduction of an identity card we run the risk of throttling our individual freedoms by pulling the red tape too tight.

There are many justifiable fears about privacy. Six per cent of telephone subscribers pay not to have their names in the phone book. What will happen to a woman estranged from a violent husband who changes her name and address in order to start a new life and whose anonymity can be destroyed by any one of thousands of clerks who have access to the Australia Card Register? What will happen to the informer or political refugee who changes his or her identity to escape retribution? The First Secretary at the Swedish Embassy in Canberra said:
It is quite easy to change your name in Sweden, but you can never change your number.

Under the Australian system, access to a number will give someone the ability to know everything about a particular individual. If the system is controlled by thousands of public servants and their minions, can the Government really claim that the system is 100 per cent foolproof forever when all evidence from similar systems around the world indicates to the contrary?

Given that a substantial number of Australian Labor Party members, trade unionists, parliamentarians and members of the public are against the idea of an Australia Card, we need to consider that public opinion in the last year has swung from 62 per cent in favour to only 50 per cent in favour and from 29 per cent against to 41 per cent against. I imagine that the numbers against the ID card are picking up day by day. I think we have a good chance of defeating it. Contrary to what the Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, would have us believe, it is not too late to stop the introduction of the ID card. It was not an election issue, although it was the paltry excuse given for the double dissolution. The fact that the ID card was hardly mentioned by the ALP during the election campaign was disgraceful. It proved that the ID card had little to do with the calling of the totally unnecessary, outrageously expensive and very boring election. What was even worse was the fact that members of the Opposition chose to ignore it also. It was an opportunity squandered. The public education campaign now being waged by community groups should have been part of electioneering for the Liberal Party of Australia, as I gather most of its members are opposed to the ID card.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you mention it?
—I certainly did-absolutely.
—When?
—In my election speech, in the opening of my election campaign--
—I did not see anything.
—No, one would not have seen it in the media because not much was reported.
—I had the same problem.

—Maybe we did share the same problem. It is up to the people to demonstrate clear opposition to the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3]. It is with the people that power is vested; if only they will use it. The huge majority of Australians who want the Government to catch tax dodgers and welfare cheats want those things done by other means and, if necessary, they will demonstrate by non-violent civil disobedience. Masses of Australians will refuse to comply with the Government's orders to be processed and photographed.

SPEECH.PARA: I will quote from two eminent jurists, James McClelland and Michael Kirby. In the Sydney Morning Herald last November James McClelland wrote:

In the field of medicine a specific cure is sometimes discovered for a human malady, but which turns out to have such dangerous side effects that its use is rejected by the scientists who discovered it, or by the practitioners to whom it falls to dispense it. I believe the same considerations apply to the I.D. Card.
Michael Kirby observed:
What is at stake is nothing less than the nature of our society and the power and the authority of the state in relation to the individual.

What he means is that, instead of a government being elected to serve the needs of the people, the government and its bureaucrats will become the people's masters. Instead of the government being accountable to the people, an individual will be accountable to the government from cradle to grave.

I am very glad to be joining the Liberal Party, the National Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats on this issue, but, mostly, I am very pleased to join the hundreds of thousands-by now probably millions-of Australians who are strongly opposed to the ID card. A huge public meeting in Perth earlier this month demonstrated overwhelmingly that Australians will come out on an issue about which they feel very deeply. There is a street rally coming up in Perth this Wednesday, the 23rd, at lunchtime, which will no doubt demonstrate once again the massive opposition to the card. What is happening in the west is being mirrored all around the country as people are joining in public meetings and public demonstrations against this outrageous invasion of our civil liberties.

It is not too late to oppose the Australia Card. We do not have to accept the view that the Government has a mandate on this matter. Such a significant issue as the identity card, which infringes on our civil liberties and goes to the very root of our parliamentary democracy, should be dealt with separately. Therefore I support the call for a referendum and I also support the call for a Senate committee to review thoroughly the identity card proposal along the lines suggested by the Australian Democrats. I also call on Australian people to write to all Labor parliamentarians-they need not bother with the rest of us who are already opposed to it-telling them that public civil disobedience will be committed if the Government presses on with this in its pig-headed fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not often that I rise to support the peace senator from Western Australia, Senator Vallentine. But the Australian Democrats, the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and those in the peace movement are all totally opposed to the introduction of an identity card.
—And half of the Labor Party.

—So is half of the Australian Labor Party. This is the fourth time that I have spoken against the introduction of an ID card. I am speaking tonight to confirm that I am opposed to the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3]. I cannot understand why the Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, who is normally regarded as a political animal, could fall for such a trap. If I ever I have seen a party on a losing board--
—We all make mistakes sometimes.

—We all make mistakes, but no one should be silly enough to make a mistake as large and as comprehensive as this one. I suppose that Senator Ray and the rest of the Labor Party are saying to themselves, `Well, I suppose we have two years to go and we can ride this one through'. But I say to Senator Ray and the other members of the Labor Party that, in 18 months time when people have to turn up at their friendly health insurance office to register, to be photographed and to sign forms, they will be within six months of an election and the smile will be well and truly taken off their faces.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Australia Card is introduced every Australian will attend at his local Medicare branch for an appointment with an ID card public servant. Every Australian will be required to bring some proof of identification, have his photograph taken and sign various documents. The interview will last 10 to 15 minutes. With the way that public opinion is swinging now, no doubt by that time 90 per cent of the people will not be in favour of an identity card and people will leave it to the very last minute to go and get their identification number. There will be queues backed up around the block and people will be very annoyed. Their rage will be expressed in the ballot box. In the six months leading up to the election that rage will continue.
I believe that the Labor Party will back down on this issue. We will see the biggest retreat since Napoleon left Russia and it will be led by Senator Ray.

TALK.START.PARA: —And look at all the casualties.

—There will be a few casualties, too. Let us look as what will happen if the Labor Party is silly enough to carry through this threat to the Australian people. Without an Australia Card the public will be unable to open a bank account; start a new job; buy real estate or receive rental income; use Medicare or be admitted to a hospital; apply for any social security benefits; make investments; or deal with the Australian Taxation Office. We have heard all these things before ad nauseam. Yet I believe the public is only now starting to come around to seriously considering this terrible ID card that is going to be forced upon it.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that our duty as elected representatives is to safeguard the freedom and privacy that this nation has enjoyed for 200 years. We are the custodians and guardians of the freest country in the world, and it is our job to fight to protect that freedom, not to see a massive erosion of it on the eve of our Bicentenary. Those who surrender Australia's freedom in this House or the other place will not be treated lightly in the future. Everyone of us has a responsibility to see this nation as free when he leaves here-or freer if it is possible-than it was when he came here to represent the public, our constituents, in both Houses of Parliament. But if this Australia Card goes through we will have been negligent in our duty. Everyone of us will have failed his country, and I for one do not wish to have the responsibility for that laying on my head. Therefore, I will do everything that is possible to oppose this card. I will go out to rallies around Queensland every time I receive an invitation.

There is uproar, confusion and panic in the community. I do not believe I have ever seen such a number of petitions flooding into this place from people who are concerned. I will suggest to the people who are concerned about the ID card that they write to, picket or otherwise contact Labor members of parliament. We will present the petitions; we will speak up against the ID card; but it is the Labor people who have to be convinced that they are in grave danger of being thrown out of office if this ID card goes through.

Privacy is a volatile issue. Unless we have rigorous protection we will find that gradually, inch by inch, our privacy is eroded. I saw Senator Ryan the other night on television debating with a member of the Australian Privacy Foundation who suggested that the ID card was not secure. He had diagrams to illustrate his point. Senator Ryan told that person from the Privacy Foundation that those computer diagrams were old hat. She said that they had been considered by the ID card people but had been rejected. But what surprised me-it even floored me-was the answer Senator Ryan gave to that person's question: `Senator Ryan, what are you going to use?' Senator Ryan replied, `Well, that hasn't been decided as yet'. I am quite willing to get the transcript and show it to the members of the Labor Party. This was a case of a senior Minister responsible for the implementation of the Australia Card admitting that she does not know what data process will be used. Here we are in the Senate debating the matter for the third time. Obviously we are debating legislation that the Government has not fully considered. I suggest that the best way out for the Labor Party would be to scrap the whole thing and to start again. I believe that that is what will eventually happen.

The majority of Australians are afraid and angry at the Government's explanations. They have not allayed their fears; they have been inadequate, and the opposition to the ID card is accelerating. I will give honourable senators an example of what we see coming from this legislation-perhaps not immediately, but gradually. As amendments to this Bill are added and as more government departments claim and receive access to the centralised database, this card could distort and restrict freedoms perhaps taken for granted in the post-war years. People are becoming terribly concerned. Let us examine this scenario of what could happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —They might march in the streets in Queensland if they can get a permit. Is that what you are saying?
—People are so concerned that they have taken to the streets and marched. Let me point out that people can march in the streets in Queensland as long as they get a permit from the traffic office.
—Your Deputy Leader said the other day that people could march only if your Government agrees on the issue.

—Organisations are permitted to march in the streets in Queensland if they go to the trouble of getting a permit from the appropriate department. But let me not become diverted on these minor issues. Let me address the problem in the time available to me. Let me take honourable senators through a scenario of what could happen, because I believe that this is of major importance. Let us consider a person who opens a bank account in September. The details accessed by his identity number will include how much money is put into that bank, on what day it is put in and the interest rate that applies to it. In October that person might fall ill and the identity number will enable access to information on the illness he has, which doctor is consulted and which drugs he is prescribed. He might decide to write a cheque for a donation to a special interest group whose activities he personally supports, but which he does not brag about. He could even be a member of the Labor Party. Access to this information may be available as well.

SPEECH.PARA: Come December, he and his spouse may be having some family problems, so he formally enlists the assistance of a social worker or counsellor from the Department of Social Security. At a New Year's celebration he is having such a good time that he has one too many. He is charged with driving with a blood alcohol level of more than .05. Philosophically he pays for his mistake and never touches the stuff again. In February, his teenage son is in a group of youngsters arrested at a party where police find some marijuana hidden in the bathroom. He is eventually found not guilty as he did not know there were any drugs on the premises. March sees the Australian Taxation Office after him for extra tax, which only happened because he was given some bad advice regarding the claiming of deductions for expenses for some weekend work. He decides that one learns from one's mistakes and pays the money back even though it means that the next two mortgage payments for his home will be quite late.

The average man is scared that all these details can be accessed by a centralised database, as an ID card or number would be used on at least one of each of these instances. Even though all of these things are quite common and ordinary and every family has its ups and downs, these details allow a comprehensive personal profile to be built up which could identify this person as a financial member of some organisation; as a person with a history of family problems, alcoholism and tax avoidance; as a person who had a son charged with drug offences; as a person with a poor credit history. And many other things could be included. This is what must be avoided at all costs. These things are not beyond the reach of possibility. One or more of them happen to many families. This is what terrifies me about the ID card-not the fact that it will not work. Mr Costigan has said that it will not restrict organised crime. The Department of Social Security has said that it will not stop social welfare fraud. It will not stop illegal immigration. It will cost $700m to implement. It will require 2,150 public servants. Those things are frightening. We should oppose the ID card for all those reasons.

However, we can live with that. It is only a matter of financial mismanagement, something the Labor Party is very good at. What frightens me and what makes me want to fight the introduction of this card more than anything is the fact that it will carry a person's financial history and profile on a silicon chip that can be called up at the push of a button by some Canberra bureaucrat. That is completely unAustralian. It is what we must oppose.
A number of other speakers wish to make their contribution on this very important issue. I certainly do not want to take up all the time of the Senate. There is a very comprehensive speakers list.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are very few Labor senators on it, though.

—Yes, very few Labor senators want to speak on the ID card because in their own minds they are opposed to it. We have seen the Labor Lawyers come out and oppose the card. We have seen a number of State ALP conferences oppose it. We saw Senator Georges make a courageous stand in the Senate. He had to resign from the Labor Party because of his principles after nearly 20 years in the Senate and probably a lot longer in the Labor Party. Senator Georges is a man who stood up for his principles and resigned. I have never admired Senator Georges's politics but I have always admired his principles. He could give every member of the Labor Party a lesson on principles.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen so many people on the Labor side of politics come out publicly and oppose the card. Yet, pigheadedly, Labor Party members plough on like a bunch of lemmings going over a cliff. This debate will not end tonight or tomorrow night. It will go on until there is a joint sitting of Parliament, maybe in six months time. By that time public opposition will have built up to a frenzy. Sixty to seventy per cent of people will be opposed to this legislation in six months time.

Then there is the problem of how to get people to take out a card. The legislation does not force people to take out a card. It merely invites people to apply for a card. There do not appear to be any penalties in the legislation if one does not apply for a card. There are penalties if one has a card, loses it and does not report it missing. Tonight I will investigate the clause of the legislation which merely says that members of the public are invited to apply for a card.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you understand that that is the basis of it? If you want to get government benefits you show your card. If you want to go without them that is fine.

—I note the interjection by the senator from Tasmania but I do not see how one can survive without a card. Without a card one cannot get medical attention, one cannot get a job and one cannot apply for social welfare benefits. The card is really an internal passport for all Australians. The Government may have made a mistake. It may have given the public a loophole in the legislation's drafting by merely stating that people are invited to apply for a card. If one does not take up that invitation there do not appear to be any penalties involved. There are penalties if, once one receives a card, one loses it or defaces it, but there do not appear to be any penalties if one does not receive it. I am opposed to the ID card. I will fight it until the last breath in my body. I urge all Australians to do likewise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —A matter of such importance as this needs a detailed and lengthy examination. It is unfortunate that the examination so far given this legislation, the Australia Card Bill 1986, on two occasions in this place has nonetheless not deterred the Government from pressing on with it. I would like to draw attention to some elements of that examination. In particular, I refer to clear evidence given to the Senate that the Bill is defective in various areas. The Government has admitted in correspondence to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills that the legislation is defective, yet it continues to press on with legislation which it knows needs amendment, which it has refused to amend for purely cosmetic and dishonest reasons and yet which it expects the Parliament to pass unaltered for the most crass and defensive political reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: It is absurd that the Parliament is being asked to pass legislation when the Government has acknowledged that changes must be made to it. The changes I have referred to which emerged from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee are only part of what I understand to be a host of changes which the Government promises to introduce later. But we do not know what these changes are to be. We are assured that they will meet the quite proper objections of so many members of the Australian community who are concerned about this Bill, but we do not know what these changes will be. We are being asked to trust Bob Hawke, the Prime Minister, and to trust the responsible Minister in this place. I must say that I would feel most reluctant to do so, not only on this matter but on any matter, certainly on the track record of the Prime Minister.

Should we apply the same trust to the Prime Minister on this matter as we placed in him when he said there would be no capital gains tax and no early election or on any of the host of other issues on which he has shown himself to be unworthy of any trust whatsoever? Here we have a man with a reputation second to none for breaking his word, for deliberately deceiving the Australian people before elections, a man who has set out to mislead, to deceive and to promise when he has had no intention of fulfilling his promises. Here we have in this legislation promises from the Prime Minister and the Minister in this place that appropriate changes will be made, provided we pass the Bill unaltered. Let us recognise this: anyone who rests his confidence in the Prime Minister fulfilling that obligation if this Bill is passed is flying in the face of bitter experience over the last four or so years of the Prime Minister's untrustworthiness in the matter of doing what he says he will do.

Let us look to the areas we know the Government will have to change because it has said, if we can believe it of course, that it will make some changes. They emerge from the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. Let us see how significant they are and consider whether we should trust the Government to do, at least in these areas, what it must do because it knows that the Bill is deficient. The changes relate basically to three matters. The first is whether this Parliament has a proper capacity to disallow regulations made under the legislation. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee, a bipartisan committee, quite clearly said not only last April when we discussed this but in the previous November, when the Opposition was strongly opposed to this legislation, that there should be greater power to examine regulations for the purpose of potential disallowance. The Committee drew to the attention of the Senate clause 12 (15) and stated:
. . . it might be considered to subject the exercise of legislative power insufficiently to parliamentary scrutiny.

The important thing about this is that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), who was then the Minister in charge of the legislation, admitted that that was so, and wrote to the Committee saying that he appreciated: the committee's concern in this matter. He went on:

Although the provision was devised as a method for the Minister to exempt a person, included in a class of persons specified in the notice, from one or more of the requirements in clause 12, in the event that it appears unreasonable for the person to have to comply with the requirements, I agree that there should be Parliamentary scrutiny of such notices and that they should be subject to tabling and disallowance provisions.

There is an admission from the Minister that there was a need to correct the legislation. He said first of all, `Yes, I accept that it has to be fixed up, but we will do so in a subsequent Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill'. In other words he said, `Yes, it is wrong but pass it the way it is and we will fix it up later'. As I said, with the Prime Minister's incredible record for breaking promises, who would trust any government under him to proceed as undertaken? But that is not all. The legislation is clearly deficient in other areas, such as the question of requiring people to be at a place to perform various functions at a reasonable time. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee pointed out that there was no requirement for people to be at a place at a reasonable time. The Committee made the point that by failing to contain an appropriate stipulation these clauses may be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties. The Minister replied:

. . . I appreciate the viewpoint expressed by the Committee that the provisions specified should include a proviso that the times and places referred to in notices should be reasonable-and I undertake that this test of reasonableness will be made explicit on the face of the legislation.

In other words, that was not there, but it needs to be there. This Government is saying, `Yes, it needs to be there but we will not in fact amend this legislation to include it because we have our own agenda. We just ask you to trust us. After you have passed it in this inappropriate, imperfect and flawed way, do not worry; we will fix it up'. I have heard lots of mirth from the other side of this chamber when suggestions of `Don't you worry about that' have been made as a way of political life. I have heard jeers from the other side when that sort of approach has been adopted from the north. Yet here we have the Prime Minister of this country introducing and supporting some of the most serious, significant legislation that will affect the way of life of those in this nation on a `don't you worry about that' basis. How incredible it is that this Parliament is being asked to pass flawed legislation on grounds such as this when the Minister has admitted that the legislation needs amending. It is cynical, disgraceful and intolerable that this legislation should come back to us yet again in a form that the Government has acknowledged and admitted is flawed.

Another flaw in the legislation, admitted by the Minister, relates to the power of delegation. One would think that in such a sensitive matter, in an area where offences carry severe penalties, the capacity to delegate powers would be strictly and properly limited. Not on your life! As the Scrutiny of Bills Committee pointed out, sub-clause 186 (1) `might be considered to make rights, liberties and/or obligations unduly dependent upon insufficiently defined administrative powers'. The situation was that any person could be on the receiving end of delegated powers under this provision of the legislation. It is not limited to staff. According to the proposed law itself, it could be anyone. It is clearly very sloppy drafting. If the intention is that it should be limited to staff, that is not what the Bill says. It says that power may be delegated to a person. The Minister responded as follows:
I am willing to undertake that the legislation should be amended so that the intention to restrict the scope of the delegation in this way appears on the face of the legislation.

The Government has promised to fix up three clear errors but it has not done so. It has come back to us with flawed legislation. As I said, it is intolerable that it should do so. The mechanical mistakes and flaws in this Bill which this Government is trying to ram through this House are evident.

Let us have a look at more important things than the mechanical errors, the flaws in the legislation. Let us ask what the legislation itself really is all about. Let us see why this Government is progressing in this way with this ridiculous, oppressive, unnecessary, dishonourable and flawed piece of legislation, particularly when we recognise that the bulk of members of parliament-that is members of the House of Representatives and the Senate-and the bulk of Australians all reject it. Let us just assume that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was talking honestly-and I recognise that that is a great assumption to make-when he said that the election was a referendum on this matter. In fact, I heard him say during a radio interview on 2GB, when rejecting the concept that there should be a referendum on the Australia Card, that the election we had was better than a referendum. He said that it was the issue on which the election was fought and that the people determined that by returning a Labor Government.

I do not know what kind of integrity is involved that enables a man to look at an election result and happily say that, even though 720,000 more Australians voted for parties that were clearly and publicly opposed to this legislation than voted for his party, which was the only party in favour of it, he has received a mandate. What kind of integrity is it that enables a man to say that when almost three-quarters of a million more Australians voted for the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats, all of which publicly and overtly stated their objection to this legislation? More than three-quarters of a million people voted for those parties than voted for the Australian Labor Party, the only party which supported the Australia Card legislation. So, on Mr Hawke's criteria, his proposal-the Australia Card legislation, the ID card, the unAustralian card-was massively defeated, if the election were a referendum. In fact, few issues which have been the subject of referendum have been so thoroughly rejected in every State as was this issue. It was defeated by three-quarters of a million Australians. I do not remember the last time a referendum issue was rejected quite as effectively. Mr Hawke has gone through the charade of pretending that he has a mandate because he has been re-elected. However, in many instances Labor seats were won as a result of preferences which clearly did not involve a first preference in favour of the ID card. Yet, this is the criteria which has been used by Mr Hawke. For example, the Australian Democrats first preferences would clearly have been against the ID card. As I said, 721,000 more Australians voted against the ID card, on Mr Hawke's own criteria, than voted for it.

Having acknowledged that most Australians oppose the ID card on Mr Hawke's criteria, let us have a look at the Parliament itself. The only way that this tainted, flawed bit of legislation that has been dishonestly presented here as the will of the people can become law is for both Houses of the Parliament to sit and pass it at a joint sitting. Mr Hawke tells us that the majority of parliamentarians will vote for and pass this dishonest and dishonourable legislation. But let us have a look at what the real desires of the majority of Federal parliamentarians are. We know that the Australian Democrats, who vote of their own free will--(Quorum formed) Mr Acting Deputy President, now at last we have members of the Labor Party in this chamber. There were none here in the chamber when the quorum was called. It is a disgrace that this should happen when we are considering such a vitally important piece of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your own mob? How many of yours?

—We had infinitely more of our members in here than members of the honourable senator's Party. There were no Labor senators. It is totally dishonest and disreputable of the honourable senator to try to make that kind of point. Not one member of the Labor Party was in the chamber when the quorum was called.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me get back to this vitally important issue, an issue which does not worry the Labor Party whose members do not even attend the debate. However, this is a vital issue. As I was saying, in the Joint Sitting the Australian Democrats will have the capacity to vote as their conscience dictates. They will all be voting against the ID card. Liberal Party members have the capacity to vote as their conscience dictates. They will all be voting against the ID card. National Party members have the capacity to vote as their conscience dictates and they will be voting against the ID card. Labor Party members do not have the capacity-most of them do not have the intellect either-to vote in this matter as their conscience dictates. I say to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that there are 25 of them who, given the opportunity to vote as their conscience dictates, would in fact defeat this legislation in a joint sitting. I quote:

Because of our determination, because this was a matter of principle, our stand enabled Mr Hawke to have an untimely and improper election in which he once again broke one of his many promises. After I made a speech in this place, I tried to interest the Press Gallery, the people who are in charge of communicating to Australia what happens in this place, in the fact that the Minister admitted in a letter to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee that the Bill was flawed and would be corrected. TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise the matter of the future of the Montessori pre-school at Yarralumla in the Australian Capital Territory. To put the matter in context, I need to point out to honourable senators that this program is run by the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority and started off in 1982 as what I regarded as an imaginative program within the Authority which indicated that the Authority was doing what it could to diversify the educational opportunities offered in the system in the Australian Capital Territory. I shall not take the time of the Senate this evening to go through all the events which have occurred. There were problems last year about the school continuing; there are problems this year about its continuing next year.

SPEECH.PARA: Briefly, the Montessori program works on the basis that it has within it children aged from three to five years. I shall not develop the philosophy of the Montessori program now, but ask the Senate to accept that that is its basis. The Schools Authority has a policy of providing a full year of pre-school education for all four-year-old children in the 12 months prior to their starting school and going into kindergarten. The Authority has said that there cannot be three-year-old children in the pre-school program. It is not suggested by any of the parents that they should get favoured treatment or government funding for three-year-olds in a different manner from what occurs everywhere else. They want to provide for the three-year-old program so that it can be a full Montessori program and can proceed as it has done. But the Schools Authority has said that the parents cannot have three-year-olds in the program, they cannot pay for them themselves and they cannot provide the school teacher. We are now faced with the situation that the school may have to close.
In a letter published recently in the Canberra Times, the Senior Director, Programs, of the ACT Schools Authority said a number of things, including:
The authority has no legal mandate enabling it to accept donations from parents to employ staff, nor is it possible under the ordinance for the parents to employ staff to work in schools.

Since then we have had this year's Budget and in that we find that the Schools Authority itself is imposing a fee for children who attend pre-school-the sum of $6 a week. I find it hard indeed to comprehend how the Government can maintain a policy whereby four-year-olds will pay a fee but three-year-olds may not attend pre-school and pay a fee even though, of course, it would be a higher fee than $6 a week. If we are charging for pre-schools what is the difference between the amount we may charge for four-year-olds and the amount we may charge for three-year-olds?

In a sense the argument goes much deeper. Within the school system in the ACT we have a number of ways in which parents can participate. We have the school boards. We have other programs and I wonder whether these are being placed at risk. For example, we have a ballet program at the Ginninderra High School. Students attend this program and the Betsy Sawyer ballet program at the same time. It is a combined program which also exists in other parts of the world to enable ballet students to get the best opportunity for their ballet and their schooling. The students pay for the Betsy Sawyer ballet program which is not precisely within the school program but which operates with it. It is very little different from what is proposed for the Montessori program to enable the three-year-olds to attend the Yarralumla School. Are we to conclude that the ballet program at Ginninderra will be next to come under attack?

Mr President, you would know that we have an imaginative program in the ACT with a French-Australian pre-school and a French program at the Telopea Park School. Teachers are provided by the French Government. What is the difference between providing teachers other than through the budget of the Schools Authority in that manner and the parents at the Montessori pre-school providing teachers to have three-year-olds included in the program? Those parents were not even suggesting that they went as far as charging fees for the three-year-olds. They were planning to run it as a `parent program' whereby the parents would contribute the cost, but we now have the example of all four-year-olds having to pay a fee to attend pre-school in the ACT from next year. The Government has got itself into a corner. It must resolve the situation and allow the parents at Yarra- lumla Montessori to contribute the cost of having teachers for the three-year-olds. The Government must make this decision soon and see that it is put into effect so that there is no further disruption to the program.
The interesting conclusion to the letter that I referred to from the Director of Programs is as follows:
Furthermore-
this is in addition to it being impossible to employ staff or charge fees-
such precedents would be philosophically unjustifiable, as they would establish a basis for an inequitable system of education provision for public schools in the ACT.

This flies in the face of the stated policy of a diversified education system. It flies in the face of what the Government has now done and, I think the attitude threatens the two programs to which I have referred. It seems to me that it is time the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) took a close look at what is happening and made a decision which determines the future of this pre-school in a way that is reasonable, sensible and will give those children whose parents wish them to take part in it, an opportunity to do so. I hope that the Minister will look at it soon and come to a decision which now fits in with this new policy of charging fees to attend pre-schools.
